PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ADERMANN; CAMERON; CHARLES; COHEN; EDWARDS; WRIGHT
PETITION.TITLE: National Day of Prayer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, House of Representatives, and Parliament assembled.
`Righteousness exalts a nation, but sin is a disgrace to any people.' Proverbs 14:34
Considering:
1. the loss of hope among the youth of the nation.
2. the breakdown of the family unit.
3. the increase of corruption in our society.
4. the increasing weight of our national debt.
5. the emerging divisions in our community.
we petition you to:
1. encourage every Australian to see his/her responsibility to live uprightly before God and others;
2. encourage commitment in marriage and encourage fathers and mothers to love and cherish their children;
3. encourage the Members of Parliament to live and legislate according to Biblical principles;
4. encourage business in Australia to pursue their transactions in generosity-without greed;
5. support the Christian Church in expressing the friendship of God, and in carrying out its practical responsibilities to the poor, needy and dispossessed.
by calling a National Day of Prayer for Australia, to seek God's help to heal our land.
We as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 1,553 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 12 citizens), Mr Charles (from 28 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 22 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 10 citizens) and Mr Wright (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration (Electors Initiative) Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectively showeth:

that while having some reservations on individual aspects of the Constitutional Initiative (Electors Initiative) 1987 your petitioners wish to express our strong support for the concept of people's democracy implied in that Bill.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will

Refer the above mentioned Bill to an appropriate Parliamentary committee and will examine the operation of direct democracy procedures overseas with the intention of passing legislation granting such facilities to your petitioners during the Bicentennial year.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie (from five citizens), Mr MacKellar (from 10 citizens), Mr Leo McLeay (from six citizens) and Mr Peacock (from nine citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the members of the house of representatives in Parliament assembled-
The humble Petition of the undersigned Electors showeth:

That any proposed redistribution of funds for Nursing and Personal Care staff costs in Nursing Homes will detrimentally affect the quality of care given in Nursing Homes in South Australia and the quality of life of the residents in those Nursing Homes. The Outcome Standards for Nursing Homes, so recently established, will not be achieved and elderly people will not receive the standard of care or quality of life that they need.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will raise the funding level for Nursing and Personal Care staff hours for all States to enable at least the number of hours of care for Nursing Home residents in South Australia. To be achieved by all States.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 387 citizens), Mr Steele Hall (from 116 citizens) and Mr Porter (from 198 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:

That we express grave concern about the public release of confidential medical information by the Federal Government, sufficient to enable the public identification of Doctors and their patients, and call upon the Parliament to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 91 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from five citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 252 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Public Release of Confidential Medical Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned electors of the Division of Corangamite, respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely concerned about the public release of confidential medical information, sufficient to enable the public identification of doctors and their patients, and call upon the House to censure all those involved in this gross abuse of the privacy of all Australians.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that the House ensures that there will be no further public release of such private confidential medical information.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the urgent need, in this Bicentennial year, to acknowledge that Australia was occupied by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders for thousands of years before British Settlement in 1788, and to acknowledge the importance of their culture and heritage.
Your petitioners therefore request that our federal parliamentarians pass unanimously a resolution in the presence of the Queen on May 9, at the opening of the new Parliament House stating:
The Queen, and the Senate and the House of Representative of the Commonwealth of Australia acknowledge that:
Australia was occupied by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years before British settlement at Sydney Cove on January 26, 1788.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied legal recognition of their land rights upon acquisition of their traditional lands by the British Crown.
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders were denied full citizenship rights of the Commonwealth of Australia prior to May 27, 1967.
And affirm:
The importance of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander culture and heritage.
The entitlement of Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to self-management and self-determination subject to the Constitution and the laws of the Commonwealth of Australia.

And consider it desirable that the Commonwealth negotiate the terms of a compact with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander citizens providing recognition of their special place in the Commonwealth of Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free (from 27 citizens), Mr Hand (from 13 citizens) and Mr Katter (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the House to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of goods here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent (from 45 citizens), Mr Milton (from 53 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 10 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
The irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Punch (from 162 citizens) and Mr Scott (from 200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, being appalled that the Government has set no penalty for the possession of child pornography, and has set no penalty for importing unclassified child pornography, do ask that Parliament urgently legislate to:
1. Make the importation of child pornography, and the possession of child pornography, and all tapes and goods banned by Customs, to be a criminal offence with deterrent penalties, and
2. Close the Customs barriers to pornography in the A.C.T., in respect to X-rated videos.
Because:
(a) X-rated videos have been banned in all States;
(b) without action by the Federal Government, there is no way the States can prevent the distribution of X-rated videos from A.C.T.
(c) there is a strong link between pornography of all kinds and sex crimes; and
(d) there is a need to protect the children of Australia from being victims of child molestation and pornography.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Identity Card
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled.

We the Undersigned oppose and object to the introduction of the Australia Card Bill on the grounds that it is an infringement of personal freedom, an invasion of privacy and has the potential of being abused by this and future Governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject any I.D. card proposal.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker of the House of Representatives and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Australian families are highly dependent upon telephone communications.
2. The Australian community needs an extensive and reasonably priced telephone system.
3. For many Australians, especially the aged and infirm, the telephone provides a ready means of communication especially at times of illness.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the aged, infirm and other fixed-income groups that are dependent on telephone communication are in no way disadvantaged by any changes to the system of charging for local telephone calls.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Export Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable speaker of the House of Representatives and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The French Government is not a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
2. The future generation of Australian residents are at risk due to French nuclear testing in the Pacific.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House of Representatives will take measures to revoke Australian Uranium export licences to France, until such time that the French Government becomes a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and adopts a policy of Nuclear Disarmament.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport: Flight Paths
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the speaker and members of the house of representatives assembled in parliament:

The petition of certain electors in the Division of Griffith draw to the attention of the House the increase in noise pollution and the subsequent effect on the quality of life of residents in certain southern suburbs of Brisbane, caused by the opening of the new Brisbane domestic airport.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to take steps to minimise noise levels and alter aircraft flight paths to enable a return to the lifestyle previously enjoyed by the affected residents.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Safety
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners, members of the Apex Club of Zone of Australia showeth:
1. We are concerned that insufficient publicity is given to promoting bicycle safety and awareness.
2. Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives will further promote road safety by direct education for bicycle riders and road users.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We are opposed to the proposed restructuring of the A.B.C. We believe that the A.B.C. is one of the most important public services in Australia and a mainstay of democracy.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House of Representatives will take measures to ensure that the A.B.C. is permitted to continue to offer ``comprehensive'' broadcasting services under its present charter.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
Grave concern with the insufficient level of Government grants provided for carrying out improvements to the Canberra/Batemans Bay (MR51) Road.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that your House will call upon the Government to take whatever steps are necessary to allow for and provide special substantial direct funding to carry out the necessary improvements to the road, and, further, call upon the New South Wales State Government to accept greater financial responsibility for the upgrading and maintenance of the said road.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That in spite of many petitioners and other communications, we are dismayed and disgusted at the lack of will on the part of the Parliament to restore to retired Commonwealth Public Servants and Defence Force Personnel, pension benchmarks which were affected by a two per cent discount as part of the budget brought down in 1986.

Having regard to assurances given by the Government that the base will be restored, your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, act to ensure that this is done without further delay so as to remove the permanent and compounding effects of this discriminatory action taken under the guise of the entire community sharing the economic burden.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Section 52, part Block 5, McKellar, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

The proposal by the National Capital Development Commission to change the land use policy for Section 52 Part Block 5 at McKellar from a primary school site to that to be used mainly for residential subdivision is wrong and not in the best interest of or in accordance with the wishes of the majority of the residents of the suburb of McKellar. We strenuously object to the proposal.

The residents of McKellar were deprived of a meeting place when the A.C.T. Schools Authority reneged on its proposal to build a primary school on Section 52 and it is believed that McKellar is one of the only suburbs (if not the only suburb) in the A.C.T. without a meeting place for its residents.

If section 52 were used for residential purposes and the land on the corner of Owen Dixon Drive and William Slim Drive were developed as proposed the suburb of McKellar would have less open space and recreation area then any other suburb in the A.C.T.

The whole of Section 52 should be set aside and developed as a recreation area for the residents of McKellar and should incorporate a multi-purpose meeting place and other sporting and entertainment facilities.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to:
(a) Prevent the use of Section 52 Part Block 5 McKellar for residential purposes and;
(b) Ensure that Section 52 Part Block 5 McKellar is developed as a recreation area for the residents of McKellar.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Murray respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Ballarat respectfully showeth that:
1. Roads form a valuable part of the Nation's infrastructure;
2. The road construction industry is an important employer;
3. Roads support the social fabric of country communities;
4. Roads are a vital part of a district's commerce;
5. Country roads are deteriorating;
6. Deteriorating roads threaten the lives of Australians;
7. Road surface maintenance affects the efficiency of road transport;
8. Insufficient funds are being spent on roads.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:
1. The Parliament recognise the importance of roads to the economy;
2. The importance of roads to country people;
3. The Parliament increase funding to maintain the road system; and
4. Grant a greater proportion of fuel taxes to road funding;
5. The Parliament continue to grant specific federal funds for roads.
and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Draft Convention on Mutual Assistance in Tax Matters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of certain electors of the Division of Corangamite, draws to the attention of the House that:

The transfer of information on Australian taxpayers as a consequence of Australia becoming a signatory to an OECD international tax treaty, would place Australia taxpayers at risk by virtue of the fact that the Australian Government would have no control over access to, or the continued confidentiality of, information of the most private and confidential nature.
Your Petitioners, therefore, request the House to urge the Government to:

Refrain from signing the Draft Convention on Mutual Assistance in Tax Matters, thus preventing the Government from an obligation to exchange the tax files of any Australian taxpayer at the request of any co-signatory country.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Violent Videos, Books and Toys of Violence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The sale of violent videos, books glorifying violence, and toys of violence encourages violence in the community, and has a deleterious effect on the more vulnerable members of the community who are easily influenced.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ban the sale of violent videos, books and toys of violence, in an effort to put an end to the increasing number of violent crimes committed in this country.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Electorate of Wide Bay respectively showeth that:

The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would seriously disadvantage thousands of elderly and disabled together with their housebound carers and families and would add a further burden to the already prohibitive cost of living borne by every Australian.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Reject out of hand any plans by Telecom which will adversely affect the ability of the elderly, sick and disabled to effectively function in modern society.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Piano Rolls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House that:
Sales tax was reimposed on the sale of piano rolls in Australia in the 1985 budget.
The Mastertouch Piano Roll Company (`Mastertouch') of Crystal Street, Petersham is the sole surviving commercial manufacturer of piano rolls in Australia.
The machinery used by Mastertouch in the piano roll manufacturing process has been classified by the National Trust.
Mastertouch is the sole remaining entity in Australia possessing the expertise and information required to perpetuate the art of piano roll manufacture.

The imposition of the sales tax and the consequent price rise in piano rolls, has placed in jeopardy the continued commercial viability of Mastertouch and if not removed will lead to the closure of Mastertouch and the cessation of piano roll manufacture in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Public Order and Safety: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows: We oppose the advertising of alcohol in any form.

Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism. Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness. Alcohol also causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio because of its persuasive effect on children and young people.

PETITION.TITLE: Lord's Prayer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that we support the retention of a christian observance at the commencement of each sitting day of Parliament.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will take appropriate action to ensure that the Lord's Prayer is retained for all future sittings.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows:
1. Telecom's planned introduction of timed local calls will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians.
2. Timed local calls have been widely condemned throughout the community.
3. Timed local calls will severely disadvantage community groups already in the category of being disadvantaged-including the elderly, the infirm and the handicapped.
4. Telecom has produced no justification for the introduction of timed local calls.
5. Efficient, cheap communications are essential for all users in a country as vast as Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request immediate intervention by the House to ensure that the Telecom plan for timed local calls is abandoned.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
There is too much crime and violence on television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:
Urge television stations to improve the standard of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax on Soya Milk
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that placing a 20% Sales Tax on the essential food item, Soya Milk, will present unnecessary financial difficulties to families.
Where many people in the community show a marked intolerance to dairy products, Soya Milk supplies a much needed alternative.
We, the petitioners therefore request that the new sales tax on Soya Milk be rescinded.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the Committee on six efficiency audits of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Eighteen months ago the then Expenditure Committee presented a report on five efficiency audits of the Australian Taxation Office by the Auditor-General. That report, entitled A Taxing Problem, drew attention to broad issues associated with the administration of the Australian Taxation Office. The Committee's theme in that report was that `substantial administrative changes need to be made in the Australian Taxation Office if it is effectively to implement the legislation for which it is responsible'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee urged an early Government response to the report, which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) tabled on 26 February 1987. In his statement, the Treasurer suggested that the House be concerned about the performance of the Taxation Office and, accordingly, this Committee has taken a special interest in the ATO. That response by the Treasurer led to A Taxing Solution, an independent review conducted by Dr Ron Cullen on the operations and performance of the Australian Taxation Office.

In the course of this inquiry the Committee was able to discuss with the Commissioner of Taxation the results of the Cullen review. We were most impressed with the changes that had taken place within the Taxation Office, a situation that has been acknowledged by the Audit Office. It was certainly apparent to the members of the Committee who visited the Adelaide, Melbourne and Victoria North offices of the Australian Taxation Office.

The report which I have tabled, entitled A Taxing Review, deals with six efficiency audits and completes the trilogy of reports into the Australian Taxation Office. As with A Taxing Problem, it is difficult to isolate the specifics of the six audit reports of the Auditor-General from the general administration of the Australian Taxation Office. In regard to this the Committee has suggested that the Australian Audit Office should acknowledge the environmental factors that impinge on the auditee at the time of the audit. That comment applies not only the Australian Taxation Office but indeed to any other government department, statutory authority or group which is subjected to an efficiency audit and efficiency scrutiny by the Australian Audit Office.

The Committee has also suggested that the Australian Taxation Office continue to monitor progress in relation to the key outcomes set out in the Cullen review. It also suggested that the progress should be specified in the annual report of the Australian Taxation Office. This, of course, would enable proper parliamentary scrutiny of the efficient organisational structures within the Australian Public Service. Time does not permit me to go into detail on all the recommendations of the Committee's report. However, there are several recommendations which I wish to highlight, particularly in view of some recent speculation regarding tax evasion and tax avoidance. One recommendation in the earlier report, A Taxing Problem, has not been implemented at this stage. The recommendation was that the Australian Taxation Office should take the necessary steps to establish a high integrity identification system which would ensure maximum taxpayer compliance. This Committee has repeated that recommendation.

In this report the Committee notes that some improvements to the current system are essential in overcoming tax evasion and avoidance. We need to be sure that honest taxpayers are not unduly burdened to raise additional taxation revenue to make up for those who are not meeting their obligation to the nation. The Committee has also recommended that it be a mandatory requirement for the quotation of valid tax file numbers on group certificates and tax instalment declaration forms. In this regard, I can do no better than quote the Taxation Institute of Australia, an organisation which represents virtually all the tax professionals in accountancy and legal practices and academics and agents. That body has noted:
There is no question that billions of dollars of revenue are bypassing the Government by tax evasion from the fraudulent use of fictitious identities and bogus bank accounts.

The Institute went on to suggest that the use of tax file numbers in conjunction with a withholding tax on interest, unfranked dividends, royalties and rental payments to Australian residents could thus provide the Government with a method of attacking the considerable tax evaded each year. We note in the report that it is the honest taxpayers who are being disadvantaged by the current level of tax evasion.

I strongly urge all honourable members to read the recommendations contained in this document with respect to those two specific areas, as well as the other areas which make reference to improved efficiency within the Australian Taxation Office. We as a Committee would certainly commend the Taxation Office for its initiative, management structures and improvements that have obviously been put in place. However, as has clearly been demonstrated in evidence, that efficiency and effectiveness and the ability of the Australian Taxation Office to collect a fair share of tax-not more, not less-will be improved by those two basic recommendations that I just elaborated being put in place.

The Committee has also recommended that the ATO formulate a broad procedural strategy plan for use as a guide when implementing future legislative changes to the taxation system. In regard to the prescribed payments system, which was the subject of one of the efficiency audits, the Committee has suggested that the ATO formulate strategic plans not only for improvements to the prescribed payments system but also for its extension to other industries. This is also a very important point, to which I direct honourable members' attention, in the body of the report.

The Auditor-General by his report has contributed to the public discussion of these important issues. I intend that this Committee will continue to promote discussion of this important topic. The Taxation Office also has a role in this regard. The Committee has recommended that the ATO publicise its compliance strategy as widely as possible so that taxpayers are kept informed of developments and changes and as an additional way of deterring some potential tax avoiders.

In conclusion, I express my thanks to the members of this Committee of the Parliament who have worked so effectively and efficiently on these reviews and, in particular, to the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson). His contribution was outstanding. He brought a great deal of knowledge about taxation to the Committee in a bipartisan spirit. I also thank the staff of the Committee who worked on the inquiry: Barry Telford, Michael Mclean, Kelly Edwards, Kylie Freer, Sharon Fisher, Kaye Buckley and particularly Anne Hazelton, whose magnificent contribution has ensured that the report was tabled today. All the Committee's operations, of course, were coordinated by the Committee Secretary, Mr Phil Bergin.

The Committee currently has two further inquiries as a result of efficiency audits of the Australian Taxation Office. I expect reports of both these inquiries to be tabled during the Budget sittings. However, this will not end the Committee's interest in taxation matters. I believe that the Committee has established not only an interest but also an expertise in taxation matters. We will continue to monitor developments in the Australian Taxation Office.

In view of the May economic statement and of Budget strategies I believe that this report is timely. Its recommendations go a great way along the track towards providing the government of the day with opportunities to recoup tax that has been lost in the system. The Australian Taxation Office has moved in that direction and is to be commended for it. I recommend that all honourable members read the report carefully and take on board its recommendations. I look forward to the continued work of our Committee in dealing with matters of this nature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1985 and 1986 I chaired the subcommittee of the House of Representatives Expenditure Committee which reviewed five efficiency audit reports of the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). The Expenditure Committee's report, A Taxing Problem, was tabled in the House in September 1986. That report highlighted the need for substantial administrative changes to be made in the Australian Taxation Office in order to achieve a satisfactory level of taxpayer compliance. It was the Committee's view that it was important to achieve such a high level of taxpayer compliance in order to ensure that the tax burden is spread in accordance with the legislative intention of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Amongst the administrative practices requiring substantial change, the Committee identified the ATO's lack of computerisation, its continuing dependence on labour intensive work methods, and the ATO's overall management practices as three areas which required major adjustment. In the course of reviewing the six efficiency audits which are the subject of the report, A Taxing Review, which has just been tabled, the Finance and Public Administration Committee has also reviewed these issues in order to gauge the extent of progress achieved by the ATO over the last 18 months.

The Committee was pleased to learn that, as a result of the implementation of an information technology strategy and major expenditure on computer re-equipment, the inefficiencies arising from the lack of computerisation entwined with labour intensive work practices are being remedied. The Committee will monitor these moves with great interest.

A major recommendation of the Expenditure Committee in its report A Taxing Problem was that a management review should be established to investigate the overall performance and operation of the ATO. A program management performance review was conducted in 1987 and the outcomes were reported to the Parliament in the review report A Taxing Solution. The report mirrored many of the views of the Expenditure Committee report when it noted that fundamental changes were required to the traditional approach to tax administration. The review team expressed support for the thrust of changes under way in the ATO but also noted that much more remains to be done. The review team identified a number of key outcomes to be achieved over the period to July 1989 and, because they are of crucial importance, the Committee has recommended that the ATO's progress towards achieving these outcomes should be recorded in its annual report.

As was the case with the Expenditure Committee, the Committee on Finance and Public Administration has concluded that identification of taxpayers is an area requiring further attention. It is essential that the current tax file numbering system be improved if a high level of taxpayer compliance is to be achieved. The Committee reiterates a recommendation of the Expenditure Committee that a high integrity identification system should be established by the ATO. The Committee has also recommended the mandatory use of valid tax file numbers on group certificates and on tax instalment declaration forms as a means of immediately improving the ATO's ability to match group certificates to tax files and through that achieve increased taxpayer compliance. It is the Committee's view that, to further improve compliance levels, the general and other exemptions should only be available to taxpayers who provide valid tax file numbers on their taxation instalment declaration forms. The ATO now records the serial number and amount of tax instalment deductions shown on each group certificate. The inclusion of the employee's tax file number in addition to, or in place of, the serial number would facilitate matching, not only with the record of duplicates of certificates, but with taxpayers' tax files as well.

Of the six efficiency audits reviewed, the Committee devoted considerable attention to the prescribed payments system (PPS). The Committee commends the initiative of the ATO by which personalised deduction forms will be provided first to PPS taxpayers who fail to correctly provide their tax file number and later to all other PPS payees. Originally, the prescribed payments system was introduced to overcome the potential for tax evasion and avoidance in industries where non-wage or cash payments are the usual method of payment. Under the PPS, payees are taxed at a rate of 15 per cent if their tax file number is shown on a completed deduction form, or a rate of 30 per cent where this information is not provided. If taxpayers can prove they have regularly met their taxation obligations, a variation of or exemption from the prescribed payments tax may be granted.

One would have expected therefore that as the PPS caused more and more taxpayers to meet their taxation obligations, an increasing number of exemptions would be granted to an increasing number of compliant taxpayers, with a consequential reduction in the revenue collected under the PPS scheme. However, this has not been the case. In fact, the receipts of the PPS have steadily increased since its inception. The Committee found that this is due to the changing role of the PPS. Originally introduced to catch non-compliant taxpayers, it is now being used by those who have good compliance records as a de facto, pay as you earn, PAYE, system, under which they can more conveniently meet their taxation obligation than by payment under the provisional tax system. The Committee suggests that this additional function has implications in relation to the current PPS withholding rates, and that it should be taken into account by the ATO when it is making improvements or changes to the system.

The efficiency audit into external sources of information examined the ATO's use of the information received from such sources. Although many organisations currently provide the ATO with information, the Committee received evidence that the format in which information is supplied is not standardised. Reservations were also expressed to the Committee about the use made by and the usefulness to the ATO of the information which is provided to it, and at the cost and time implications to organisations which supply it. The Committee has concluded that this situation is unsatisfactory. It has therefore recommended a review of the legislative basis for the exchange of information. In addition, the Committee has recommended to the ATO that it streamline its information requirements from reporting organisations.

The Committee is enthusiastic about the steps being taken towards electronic lodgment of taxation returns. The facility is still only at the pilot stage at this time. It is envisaged, however, that when the information technology strategy has been successfully implemented, the vast bulk of returns and communications with the ATO will be made electronically. The Committee considers that this facility will be beneficial for individual taxpayers as well as tax agents and it recommends that the costs of software packages should be met as far as possible by the Australian Taxation Office.

In 1986, I expressed very serious reservations about shortcomings in the administrative philosophies of the Tax Office. In the course of the review of the six efficiency audits, it became clear that substantial administrative improvements had been made by the Tax Office in both philosophy and practice. It appears that the Tax Office has turned the corner. The recommendations in this report, if adopted, will further assist that office in its efforts to increase the level of taxpayer cooperation and compliance. It is to be hoped that the Tax Office will continue to increase its efforts to assist taxpayers to discharge their obligations on a cooperative basis, not on a confrontationist basis. I put the view personally that one day the Tax Office may even be able to provide taxpayers with details of the information it has received from their employers, under the PPS scheme, and from financial institutions in respect of their wages and salaries for inclusion in their tax returns. The Tax Office should not wait for honest taxpayers inadvertently to wrong-foot themselves, but should assist them in the preparation of the information to be included in their tax returns.

In conclusion, I wish to express my thanks to the Chairman of the Committee, to my fellow members of the Subcommittee and to the Committee staff who helped in the preparation of this report. I commend the report to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the report of the Committee on the Efficiency and Effectiveness of Institutional Practices in the Higher Education Sector, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report which I have just tabled focuses on the capacity of higher education institutions to improve their performance in times of considerable economic and social change. New arrangements are proposed for allocating funds to institutions, for making the higher education structure more flexible and less regulated, and for greater institutional autonomy. Although higher education funding has increased in real terms since 1983, the funding per student has been declining for more than a decade. In this sense, higher education institutions have become more efficient. But they have not necessarily become more effective in terms of meeting community needs.

SPEECH.PARA: For the higher education sector to become more effective as well as more efficient, the Government must present a clear picture of what is to be achieved and then allow institutions to implement strategies to achieve it-without unnecessary intervention. Government agencies have been too closely monitoring and directly influencing the management and academic decisions of higher education institutions. This had led to excessive controls on budgetary allocations, repetitive demands for statistics, and sometimes conflicting legislative obligations, while the longer term goals of the sector remained undefined. The Committee therefore sees considerable merit in the proposal outlined in the Government's Green Paper on higher education to link funding decisions to educational profiles. In the Committee's view this practice would: encourage institutions to plan better; increase their awareness of community expectations and needs; allow the higher education sector to operate more cohesively; and give institutions wider flexibility in their operations.

A recurring feature of the debate about the Green Paper has been the Government's proposed minimum acceptable sizes for institutions. The Government has called for institutions to be a minimum size, based on equivalent full time student units, before they can receive funding as part of a new unified national system of higher education. The range of teaching and research activities funded would also depend largely on the institution's size.

On the basis of evidence received, the Committee cannot support the determination of an institution's activities by the size of its student load; nor should the size of the student load determine the amount of funds received. The primary determinants of the size and profile of institutions should be the educational requirements of the communities they serve.

The Committee does strongly endorse the need for growth in our higher education system, as identified in the Green Paper. Increased participation in higher education is crucial to the nation's ability to meet the challenges of economic, technological and social change. Moreover, growth is fundamental to increased access to higher education amongst Aborigines, people from financially disadvantaged backgrounds, and people from rural and isolated areas. More funds must be injected into the sector to create more places, replace obsolete equipment and upgrade capital facilities generally. It was the Committee's task, however, to identify scope for improving the way in which available resources are utilised. To improve the delivery of education the Committee recommends more comprehensive and coordinated access and equity programs; better links with the technical and further education sector; liberalised credit transfer arrangements between the higher education and TAFE sectors and between institutions; and greater availability of bridging courses.

To improve efficiency, the Committee supports measures to increase the range of financial and staffing resource management options. In particular, there should be more extensive interaction between the higher education sector, other areas of the public sector, and the private sector, in sharing and exchanging resources and services. The Committee recommends that institutions develop equipment management plans and seek assistance from other institutions, government agencies and the private sector in purchasing major equipment items and undertaking capital works. Better use of existing buildings through centralised timetabling, extended operating hours and energy conservation measures is also desirable. The Committee would also support the introduction of more contract appointment and consultancy opportunities for academic staff; better staff assessment and development procedures; flexible salary hierarchies; and the same basic salary scales for all academic staff in universities and colleges of advanced education, but with the capacity for management to pay overaward salaries in certain circumstances to attract staff in high demand areas.

Many of the practices recommended by the Committee are already being followed by institutions, but introducing new practices on a piecemeal or ad hoc basis will not lead to optimum efficiency and effectiveness. Practices employed in one institution will not necessarily work in another. Throughout the report the Committee emphasises the need to plan strategically at the institutional level as well as at the national level. Nonetheless, how successfully the recommended measures are implemented in any particular case ultimately depends upon the institution and the Government agreeing on what the institution should be aiming to achieve and the institution being allowed the means and the power to work to that end to meet those objectives.

The report is the first report of the Committee on Employment, Education and Training and is unanimously supported by its members. I would like to thank the other members of the Committee, and particularly the members of the higher education Subcommittee, the secretariat staff and our consultants for the time and effort they put into the inquiry. The report I have tabled today provides a coherent and efficient framework for a substantial, broadly based expansion of higher education. Growth in the level of higher education, which is proposed in the Government's Green Paper on higher education, can be achieved in three ways: by meeting existing demand for unmet places; by providing more opportunities for underrepresented groups; and by improving graduation rates. If higher education is to provide in an efficient way a fair chance for all, the base of its participation must be considerably widened.

The Committee, in its report, agrees that over the last decade the higher education system has become more accessible and more efficient, but there are certain groups in our community who are still grossly underrepresented in participation in higher education. These are primarily people from low income families and rural and remote areas. The Committee's recommendations relating to growth, to output-linked funding, to credit transfer, to closer links with TAFE, to the introduction of more bridging courses, to the establishment of equity goals and to educational profiles, I believe, will make a significant contribution to improving opportunities for traditionally underrepresented groups.

Our recommendations also should make a major impact on improving graduation rates and reducing unnecessary wastage in higher education. Graduation rates in our higher education system are lamentably low. I think the level of wastage is a national disgrace. Whilst it is true that there has been some improvement in graduation rates in higher education over the last decade or so, it is equally true that our present graduation rates of around 70 to 75 per cent are still not good enough. Much of the wastage which occurs is totally unnecessary and is due to the inflexible, overregulated and overprotected system.

The Committee's report develops a detailed strategy for reducing unnecessary wastage and improving graduate output. Key proposals which unquestionably will reduce wastage include, as I have said, more liberalised credit transfer, closer links with TAFE, the introduction of more bridging courses, output-related funding and more flexible staffing and timetabling arrangements. I think it is important to stress that introduction of the measures which the Committee has outlined will both improve graduation rates and maintain graduate quality. The Committee would not recommend, and has not recommended, any proposals which could lead to a fall in graduate quality.

In conclusion, I say again that this is a unanimous report. If implemented, I believe, it will lead to a more efficient, flexible system of higher education, which will be better able to respond to change. In addition, it will be a system which offers new opportunities to those people in our community who traditionally have been denied the opportunities which they deserve. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R. L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All members of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training Subcommittee on higher education, I am sure, agree that education is of paramount importance not only to the individual but to the country of Australia. I am sure that we share the view that this does not apply just to the subject in question, tertiary education; it applies also to primary and secondary education. Quite clearly, the future of Australia depends upon the quality of this tertiary education. I guess that that is tied up, in particular, with access for all those who are suitably qualified to receive a tertiary education.

SPEECH.PARA: I note in passing that the comparable figures for tertiary education achievement are that in the United States of America 23.5 per cent of those under 24 years of age go through a tertiary education program and only 11 per cent do so in Australia. That is an indictment of what has happened in the past. I believe that the recommendations of this Committee will help to improve that figure.

I strongly support the recommendations which are concerned not just with access but also with the quality of the education. Obviously, improving access without improving quality is of no value whatsoever. The access recommendations particularly are aimed at underprivileged groups, including Aboriginals and those in low income families, and also at mature age students, isolated students and women. I believe very strongly that the recommendations in the report which include bridging courses will improve not only the entry of these people but also the results once they are actually accepted into the various institutes. Bridging courses in particular seem to have a very large part to play and seem to have been underutilised in the past.

I was amazed at the rarity of the assessments of staff performances in most institutes. Only occasionally were staff assessed as to whether they were actually producing the goods, particularly in terms of their teaching responsibilities rather than their research responsibilities. I strongly believe, as we recommend in the report, that there are a number of situations where staff performance has to be assessed on a regular basis. I do not believe, as I think most members of the Committee do not believe, that this should be used as a punitive measure. It is not a method of sacking or disciplining people who are not up to scratch. Rather, it is a way of finding out where the deficiencies lie, improving those deficiencies, and making sure that the actual standard of teaching is improved. I might add in passing that we received several cases of evidence regarding the importance of student input into that assessment of staff performance. I strongly support that. At present it seems to me that a reassessment of staff performance only occurs when a promotion is in prospect, and that is often a fairly infrequent occurrence.

I would like to make a point about research. As honourable members probably know, the Green Paper indicates that research directions should be decided largely according to national priorities. I feel very strongly that research directions cannot be decided by some government bureaucracy looking at what is going to help the national good. I do not believe that that will ever work. It would probably do away with a large proportion of the arts oriented research which goes on at present, some of which may not seem to be directly productive in terms of our economy or our society. But pure research, which will not necessarily result in the production of, for example, a better oil rig drilling machine, has always been and, I hope, will always be a vital part of any healthy society. Surely curiosity about our world and searching after knowledge for its own sake is crucial not only to the future of Australia but to the whole world.

We did receive some evidence on the proposed graduate tax. Most of the evidence that we received in that regard was opposed to the concept. I believe that the proposed tax will counteract much that this Committee has tried to achieve with its report. In particular, I fear that it will deter entry especially for the underprivileged in our society. I believe that it will encourage graduates to go overseas and to seek other loopholes in the tax framework. I think it will discourage those who obtain tertiary education to improve themselves and to contribute to society both in terms of their contribution academically and in terms of creating other jobs. I fear that this discouragement will have a major impact upon the health of our economy and our society. I do not see how it can be of value to encourage people to get `hobby' degrees, which they will never use, but to discourage people from obtaining their education and using such an education to improve their standing in the work force and therefore indirectly improving the productivity and industry base of Australia. I also have difficulty in terms of why this tax is inequitably applied to tertiary education such as universities and colleges of advanced education but not to colleges of technical and further education (TAFE). I cannot see why it is appropriate to tax somebody with a tertiary degree from a university and who uses that education to get a higher income but not to tax, for example, plumbers who might do an apprenticeship course with TAFE, and similarly subsequently have a higher income.

As was also mentioned yesterday, I am concerned about one other aspect, in passing, which is the increase of the database which will undoubtedly be necessary to tax those graduates. We will have to make sure that there is a database in the Australian Taxation Office of graduates' past history as well as what they have done in the last taxable year. That gives rise to considerable concern for me. We have to remember that what we are talking about here is not just the doctors, the veterinarians and the dentists, who are very highly paid in our society, but also nurses and similar groups.

The Committee discussed educational profiles at some length. I support the concept of educational profiles so long as they are oriented towards the individual institution. These are a means of the institution deciding where it wants to go and the directions it wants to follow. Most of the institutions that we took evidence from did have an educational profile already, although it was sometimes called by a different name, such as a strategic plan, or whatever. I would have some reservations if that educational profile were used as a means of making funding decisions in secret. I have reservations about some suggestions in the Green Paper in that regard. Although I am happy to support the concept of educational profiles within institutions in terms of determining their directions, I have reservations about this being used by the bureaucracy of our Government at present.

I certainly support the encouragement which we have given to institutional autonomy, of getting away from central government bureaucratic regulation. I believe that this can only be healthy. In those institutions which have shown initiative in terms of developing various courses and in some cases developing overseas courses, it was quite clear that those courses were run in a very efficient and in some ways a financially as well as academically productive manner.

There was considerable evidence about inefficiencies in terms of overlapping between States. I strongly support the statements made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) in that regard. The recurrent complaint was that there was a requirement to provide statistics in two different forms-the same figures but different forms-to the States and the Commonwealth. Obviously there is no justification for this. If both the Commonwealth and the States need those statistics surely it would be simple enough to allow them to be prepared in a universal form. Restriction of mobility, in terms of staff as well as students, but in particular in terms of staff, by such things as superannuation schemes not being compatible among different institutes, was a major restriction on improving standards by recruiting staff from other areas.

We discussed and made recommendations about credit transfers, the importance of getting credit for courses completed at other institutes. We believe the emphasis should be changed. Whereas at present the emphasis is on the student to prove that he should get credit for a course which is done elsewhere, the emphasis should be changed so that the general rule would be that credit would be given unless good reasons to the contrary could be proven, and in cases of dispute that these be assessed by an independent body. I hope and believe that this will improve the mobility of students and therefore the standard of education. In conclusion, I would like to thank the Chairman of the Committee, the fellow members of the Committee and staff and consultants. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too welcome the tabling of this report entitled Setting the Course. In passing, I must commend the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training for its choice of an attractive title for a document which is both contemporary and relevant. Setting the Course is certainly more appealing than a title such as `Report of an Inquiry into the Efficiency and Effectiveness of Institutional Practices in the Higher Education Sector'. I am pleased that the Committee in this respect is continuing a practice which was begun I think by you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when you were Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Expenditure, in getting that Committee to choose arresting titles for its reports. Whether the use of an attractive title will boost sales I am not sure but since we are being broadcast this morning I would like to remind listeners that this report will be available soon in an Australian Government Publishing Service bookshop near them.

SPEECH.PARA: I should caution those people who might want to get hold of the report in the hope that it will deal with some of the aspects of the graduate tax discussed by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods). Despite what the honourable member for Lowe said in his contribution, those matters were not canvassed in this report. Central to the report, however, is its endorsement of the call for an expansion of the tertiary system, a call contained in the Government's Green Paper and which, I remind the House, aims for 125,000 graduates per year by the turn of the century. At current graduation rates this implies an expansion of the system of between 180,000 and 200,000 places by the year 2001.

The Chairman has noted that the Committee had some difficulties with the Green Paper notion of a minimum acceptable size for institutions-a size of 5,000 for those institutions with a broad teaching profile and some research and a minimum size of 8,000 for institutions with research across a significant portion of their profiles. The Committee found that some small institutions, nevertheless, were quite cost effective and, equally, some large institutions had a very large per student cost. The difficulty in this exercise is being able to be completely confident that one is comparing apples with apples. The Committee had some difficulty with the assumption of the Green Paper, based as it was on the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission efficiency and effectiveness review, of a minimum acceptable size. We felt that this tended to represent an idealised picture and therefore we had some difficulties with the minimum size as reflected in recommendations 12 and 13 of the report. The University of Adelaide most effectively and in very elegant language addressed this problem in its response to the Green Paper, when the university said:
It seems likely that an element of precision has been introduced to the Commonwealth's document-
that is, the Green Paper-
beyond that which the evidence can sustain.

The Committee quite correctly paid attention to graduation rates in Australia which are poor in comparison with some other countries. Currently, some 88,000 students graduate each year with a wastage rate of approximately 30 per cent. As I mentioned earlier, the target is some 125,000 by the year 2001. I make the point that that target could be achieved quite simply by raising graduation rates. In other words, the figure of 125,000 could be achieved without worrying about expansion of the system and without getting one extra student. I think that would be undesirable.

As the Chairman of the Committee pointed out in his remarks, some groups in our society are under-represented and they need to be given access to the system, which should be opened up. At the same time, care needs to be taken that, in improving graduation rates, standards are preserved. Nevertheless, higher education in Australia receives a highly selected intake at present. Approximately 20,000 to 30,000 people are qualified to enter the system but are unable to do so and must wait. Frankly, the system should be doing better given the quality of intake it receives. The Committee has made a number of important recommendations concerning support services for students: the provision of bridging courses, transfer arrangements, referred to in recommendations six, seven and eight, and staff quality, referred to in recommendations 25 to 28.

The Committee visited institutions and took evidence in four States. It considered matters ranging from patterns of organisation in different institutions to more mundane housekeeping concerns such as grounds, cleaning arrangements and the electricity bill. In the hearings I attended I observed that the newer institutions tended to be more innovative. I was impressed with the pattern of organisation at Griffith University in Queensland and I was also impressed with its grounds. Griffith University is located in grounds that are retained as natural Australian bushland. It is a very attractive setting which involves little maintenance, so it is a cost-effective site.

I mentioned that the Committee had concerns about housekeeping matters. It was particularly interested in energy conservation, and there are a number of recommendations concerning energy conservation. It was of interest to me to learn that quite a bit of money can be saved by institutions taking care to conserve energy. I quote from the report:

The University of New South Wales, for example, reported savings of $600,000 since 1986 by renegotiating its electricity tariffs and the University of Melbourne put at $1 million the actual cumulative savings against budget from 1978 to 1986 following the introduction of its `killerwatt' savings program.

The Committee found evidence of an interesting innovation, the results of which have been significant and sometimes surprising. I refer to the installation of computer controlled energy management systems to turn off lighting and air-conditioning in unoccupied areas when not needed. These systems respond to movement. I shall quote some of the evidence on that:

The problem is that, if the lecturer is not moving about much and the students are sitting still, the lights go off in the middle, and the attendant has told me that you can get into a panic situation then.

That confirms my recollections of some lectures I attended during my student days. The report also draws attention in recommendations 16 and 17 to the need for increased capital funding. However, at the same time, in recommendations 18 to 22 the Committee has called for a more efficient use of existing and future capital. The fact is that many Australian tertiary institutions are student-free zones for significant parts of the year. Therefore, the Committee has recommended more effective use of buildings by more efficient timetabling, the provision of summer courses and other measures.

Before closing, I also mention that although the Commonwealth Government provides the bulk of funding for the tertiary sector, those institutions located in the States are set up under State legislation. It is a matter of regret that the councils of those organisations are appointed by State governments and that the major funding level of government has no representation on the councils. I commend the report. I believe it is a significant contribution to the Green Paper-White Paper process. I support the Chairman's commendation of the efforts of the Committee staff during the conduct of the inquiry which, along with the presentation of this report, provides ample evidence of the wisdom of the Government's decision last year to establish a comprehensive system of standing committees in this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks made by previous speakers in relation to this report and I shall comment on a few matters of interest to me. I take up the point made by the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) about the absurd situation of the bulk of the money coming from the Commonwealth Government both for capital and recurrent funding of these institutions but the Commonwealth having little say because of the anachronistic situation of colleges of advanced education and universities being established under State legislation. The House should be concerned about the equity issues raised in the report and the real need, which was alluded to by the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Woods), to be able to fund the extra places required to ensure that all groups within the community and all regions within Australia have equal access to higher education and that it is not simply a matter of where one lives, how much money one's parents earn or what professions they belong to.

SPEECH.PARA: That is nowhere more important than in the western suburbs of Sydney and, in particular, the new institution being created in that area. I refer to the Chifley University College established in the electorate of the honourable member for Lindsay. One of the features of the western suburbs area of Sydney is that it has a strong technical and further education (TAFE) sector. For students attending TAFE colleges, the new arrangements of recognising or liberalising credit transfer between TAFE, universities and colleges of advanced education will, if the recommendations are adopted, make a significant difference to students in that area.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for statements on this report has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Brumby) proposed:
That the house take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 102b, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the decision by the ANZ Bank to introduce a fee for withdrawals from savings accounts, believing that-
(1) such a fee is unwarranted, unjust and unfair, particularly to pensioners, low income families and others who depend on savings accounts for the protection and management of their finances; and
(2) it is commercially immoral for a bank to charge a depositor for the right to withdraw his or her own money.

Honourable members will be aware that I gave notice of this motion on 15 September last year-eight months ago. The thrust of the motion at that time was to highlight the decision by the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (ANZ) to introduce a fee for withdrawal from savings accounts. I said then and I reiterate now that fees such as this are unwarranted, unjust and unfair, particularly to low income families, pensioners and others who depend on savings accounts for the protection and management of their finances. I believe it is commercially immoral for a bank to charge a depositor for the right to withdraw his or her money.

Australian banks hold billions of dollars in savings accounts. I noted a report that came out only a few days ago from the Australian Bankers Association which said that, as at 11 March, savings accounts across the nation amounted to $55.6 billion. Banks certainly take advantage of those deposits. Approximately 18 months ago I saw a report in the Courier-Mail that showed that the average interest paid on 15 per cent or 16 per cent of that money was only 3.75 per cent. So the banks certainly take advantage of it, and they are high profit earning deposits for the banks.

Regrettably, little can be done to stop banks introducing these charges, but it is time honourable members took a hard look at the banking operations in this country. I say that noting at the same time-and giving credit-that a number of banks are starting to operate what is called a disclosure policy, a policy whereby there is a clear outline of the terms of any loan. There is a setting down of the effective interest rate that people shall pay. People will be able to see what the individual fees are. The banks will even allow for a cooling off period for those who enter into loans. The ANZ Bank, fortunately, is part of this move that involves the other three major banks.

As I said, there is a time to look at the banking operations. There is a need to highlight the interest policies and lending practices of not only the banks but also the building societies. I have found out, as I have carried out inquiries in recent times, that many depositors are being duped into thinking that they are earning a lot more interest on their money than they actually are. This goes for not only banks but also building societies. Building societies and banks throughout this nation are guilty of misinformation and guilty of subtly misleading the community in their advertising as to the interest rates they are offering.

As I said, a survey was carried out in April. At that time, six banks and three building societies were considered and, in May, another bank was added. Therefore, seven banks and three building societies were considered. The survey covered the fees charged and the interest paid. There is a clear message here to every consumer across this nation that the time has come to shop around and to look before he buys when it comes to the services offered by the banks and the building societies.

I note that, although not all the banks are introducing this withdrawal charge, unfortunately, many have followed the approach of the ANZ Bank. They are hitting small accounts; they are hitting those small depositors. The Advance Bank, for instance, has an account keeping fee if one has less than $300 in the bank. It also charges a 25c withdrawal fee on accounts below $1,000. Admittedly, it gives people five free withdrawals, but that does not help very much. The Challenge Bank has a charge of $1 per month on balances under $200. It does not sound much, but it is wrong in principle. The National Mutual Royal Bank is charging 30c per withdrawal for each transaction in an account under $500. The Westpac Banking Corporation gives three free withdrawals and then charges 30c per item up to a balance of $500.

I received a letter the other day from the ANZ Bank in defending itself, because it knew the motion was coming forward, saying that many other banks are doing this. However, most of the other banks charge this withdrawal fee on those accounts up to about $500. Therefore, it does not catch a lot of people. However, what is wrong with the ANZ Bank is that it has a 25c withdrawal charge. It gives people 20 free withdrawals, but the bank's measure, its threshold, is $5,000. Every account under $5,000 faces a withdrawal fee of 25c per withdrawal once the person has used his 20 free ones.

Fortunately, some banks are not doing it. The Bank of Queensland is not doing it and the National Australia Bank is not doing it. They are not charging a withdrawal fee. Unfortunately, some building societies are. The Metropolitan Building Society in Queensland has a charge of $2.50 per quarter if a balance is less than $100. But there is a chance for competition here because Suncorp is not doing this, the Rock Building Society in Rockhampton is not, and other building societies are not. Therefore, the message is again to shop around, because there are differences in the charges that are being levied by the banks.

There are also differences not only in the withdrawal charges but as to how the interest rates are calculated. In the survey, I examined Westpac, which charges on a minimum monthly balance, and the ANZ and Advance banks are the same. However, a number of them are charging on daily balances: the National Mutual Royal Bank, the Metropolitan Building Society, Suncorp, the Bank of Queensland, and the Rock. Again, the message to consumers is to shop around.

It is also important not only to see what the interest rates are that they will pay to people for their deposits and whether there is a withdrawal fee, but also it is worth checking to see what their charges are. So often, they are hidden, and people do not know the actual interest they are paying on the money that they borrow; nor do they actually know what they are getting on these accounts.
