As I said before, people think they are getting 7 per cent or 8 per cent, but in actual fact, that is not true. Westpac, for instance, is paying only 3.75 per cent on its passbook accounts. This increases to 8 per cent if the account contains over $500. The Metropolitan Building Society advertises that it is giving people 9 per cent and 10 per cent; in actual fact, if a person has only $900 in that account, he gets 4 per cent. If he has $4,999 or less, he gets only 5 per cent. Other building societies are doing it too. The Rock Building Society in Queensland offers a top rate only if one has $25,000. If one has $999 or less in one's account, one gets a miserable 4 per cent. People do not know that, because the advertising talks about 10 per cent, 10.5 per cent and 11.5 per cent. If one has $4,999 or less in the Rock, one gets only 7 per cent.

Another building society, Suncorp, advertises 10 per cent, but one gets the 10 per cent only if one has $10,000 deposited. If one has less than $10,000-for example, $9,999 or less-one gets a miserable 5 per cent. The Bank of Queensland talks about a top rate of 8 per cent, but if one has $999 or less, one gets 3.75 per cent. The ANZ Bank is a beauty; it keeps talking about its 8.75 per cent rate, yet if one has less than $500 in the bank, one gets only 3.75 per cent.

I suggest that people do shop around, because there is at least one bank-and it is not my job to promote banks-that is, the National Australia Bank, which is paying top dollar. It is paying 7.5 per cent up to $999 and 7.75 per cent on $1,000 or more. People think they are getting 10 per cent on their money but in some cases they are getting 5 per cent, 4 per cent or even 3.75 per cent. The advertisements promote top interest rates, but rarely are the lower rates divulged. Honourable members need to have a close examination of this.

There is also a need to compare the charges that are being levied by the banks themselves, because there is a variety there. There are differences and contrasts. I have examined three banks in regard to overdrafts-the National Australia Bank, the ANZ Bank and Westpac. If one takes out an overdraft of $10,000, the base interest rate for the National Australia Bank is 14 per cent. If one borrows from the ANZ Bank, it is 16.75 per cent. If one borrows from Westpac, it is 14.5 per cent. There are variations, because it is not only the interest that one pays, but also the hidden fees. The National Australia Bank charges a flat application fee of 1 per cent. However, the ANZ Bank charges a different type of application fee that varies from $185 to $240 to set it up. It is charging people an extra 2.4 per cent on top of their 16.75 per cent and, as well as that, the ANZ Bank charges another $88 a year just to service the account. Therefore, if one starts to look into this, one notes that people are paying 16.75 per cent as their base interest rate; they are paying up to another 2.4 per cent as their application fee and 0.88 per cent as their service fee. It all adds up to a lot of money, which people do not know they are paying.

I refer now to Bankcard. How many people know that, if they use Bankcard for a cash transaction, they do not get free interest on that transaction? People are told that they get 25 interest-free days. In fact, the ANZ Bank keeps telling everybody that they get 25 to 55 interest-free days if they handle their accounts properly. However, the bank does not bother to tell them that interest is immediately charged on cash withdrawals. It does not bother to tell them that if they make a purchase and, as we know that when people go shopping, the shop asks whether they wish to charge up only that amount, which may be $89, and most people round it off to $100, the moment they do that, there is a cash withdrawal fee component and, at that moment, they start paying interest on the full amount.

There is a need also to have a look at the different interest rates being charged on Bankcard. For instance, the National Australia Bank charges 23 per cent. The Westpac Banking Corporation charges 22 per cent; and here is a mark in favour of the ANZ Bank, because it is charging only 21 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must have made a mistake.

—I do not think the bank made a mistake. The point is that people can shop around. There is a variation from 21 per cent to 23 per cent. The same is true for personal loans. If one takes out a personal loan of $10,000, the National Australia Bank is charging 17.5 per cent to 18 per cent, the ANZ Bank charges 17.28 per cent and Westpac charges 17 per cent to 19 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: There is good reason for people to take a hard look at what they are paying and what their banks are charging for the services that are rendered to them. As I said, I believe that the time has come to educate the community and for the banks to think through their responsibilities as well. There is a responsibility on the banks to follow through the disclosure policy which the ANZ Bank has told me about and which I know Westpac and the National Australia Bank are involved in and make sure people know what they are paying. It is totally wrong and commercially immoral for a bank to say that it will give people 10 per cent when, if they have less than $999 in the account, they get 4 per cent. The same is true for the building societies.

This motion may be eight months old but it is still applicable today. It is time the banks had a hard look at themselves and realised that they have a community and social responsibility to the Australians who bank with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in entering the debate on this motion and in totally rejecting it. Before I start, it is appropriate in terms of normal parliamentary procedures relating to members' interests to declare the fact that I used to be a director of a trading bank, the Macquarie Bank Ltd, in which I maintain some shares. However, I have no brief for the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, so I feel quite at home in going to its defence. This motion is an exaggeration. It is part of a continuing vendetta, almost, by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) against banks. It is cheap sensationalism. It goes for cheap headlines. It is devoid of any significant foundation in fact or logic. The extent to which the matter has been exaggerated in this House today is totally unjustified. Let me take the particular element of this motion, that is, the ANZ Bank's decision to charge for the use of its access accounts. I should put a number of points on the record in respect of the ANZ Bank.
—Who wrote your brief? Was it the ANZ?

—I have made a number of inquiries in this regard. The ANZ Bank's access account is one of those accounts that offer access through an automatic teller machine. Therefore, it is an expensive additional service for a savings institution to provide. It is the only ANZ savings bank deposit account which I believe is subject to fees. The fees apply only to withdrawals or transfers from a relatively small number of accounts. One has to hold less than $5,000 on an average daily balance over a quarter and one has to use the account more than 20 times in a month. I do not think it is an unreasonable proposition for the bank to put. It sent a letter to its customers in terms that the cost of providing this service is a considerable one and it is only fair that those who benefit most should actually pay.

SPEECH.PARA: The ANZ was not totally insensitive to the elements described in this motion. Apparently, there was concern in the bank that there may have been some disadvantage to particular groups-pensioners, low income earners and recipients of social security benefits. So the bank did a number of surveys to determine to its own satisfaction the likely impact of this charging procedure. One of the surveys done on pensioners by Reark Research Pty Ltd identified what it thought were older and lower income groups who used the access account. It had three criteria. About 18,000 people were identified as having an access account, being aged over 55 years and not working and having an individual joint pre-tax income per annum of about $22,000. The survey found that, of these people, the maximum proportion likely to visit their branch for any purpose more than 20 times per quarter was only 5.1 per cent.

The maximum proportion likely to use the automatic teller machine (ATM) more than 20 times per quarter was estimated to be as low as 1.3 per cent. Many customers of those branches hold traditional passbook accounts and their branch visits will not always have something to do with their access accounts. Consequently, on the basis of the survey, the bank estimated that only about 450 to 900 people would be affected. The figure equates to between 0.01 per cent and 0.03 per cent of approximately 350,000 people aged 55 years and over who currently bank with the ANZ.

I suggest to the House that it is not surprising that is the case because the use of that sort of account, plastic cards and automatic teller machines is not a natural feature yet of the group we identify as the `older age group'. They have little use for out-of-hours banking or for high frequency transactions. Much of what the honourable member for Capricornia said today on pensioners has been little more than a beat-up.

The bank also did a survey of social security recipients operating access accounts at 30 of its branches. It identified groups that received unemployment benefits and family allowances, veterans and pensioners. Interestingly, the relevant comparable percentages were for those who would be affected in each group: 12 per cent for unemployment benefit recipients, 6 per cent for recipients of family allowances, 8 per cent for veterans and about 9 per cent for pensioners. It is not surprising that the unemployed group, with a more significant younger element, would make greater use of plastic cards and ATMs. It was a massive exaggeration of the situation to have made some of the points the honourable member for Capricornia made today.

However, let us not just look at the surveys which were done in anticipation of usage. Let us look at the actual usage. In the December quarter of 1987 only 7 per cent, approximately, of ANZ access account customers made transactions in excess of the 20 free withdrawals threshold. In the March 1988 quarter the statistics were pretty much the same. However, this small percentage of customers accounted for more than 45 per cent of the total debit transactions to access accounts. So 7 per cent of the accounts are generating 45 per cent of the debit transactions. Clearly, that level of cross-subsidisation is both unfair and unreasonable.

To conclude, I suggest to the honourable member for Capricornia that he ought to take a hard look at some of his own advertising policies. It is a bit much for me to hear him lecture this House about truth in advertising when I have just been through an election campaign where truth was not really an element that en- tered into most of the Australian Labor Party advertising throughout most of that period. I also suggest to him that he take a basic course in the financial system and look at the benefits that are derivable from our deregulated financial system. People get higher effective interest rates out of our deregulated financial system. Of course they should shop around. An essential feature of a deregulated financial system is the possibility for greater choice. We now have a whole range of alternative savings facilities. Anybody who has an access account at the ANZ Bank, for example, has every choice to take out another account, a normal passbook savings account, on which there are no charges and on which they will not be subject to any of the charges claimed by the honourable member for Capricornia.

Most of what the honourable member said has been an exaggeration of the situation, not only in respect of the ANZ Bank but also, more broadly, in terms of the sorts of benefits that are available to individuals under our deregulated financial system. If the honourable member is concerned about helping pensioners and others I suggest that he do so through the Budget, not by trying to reregulate the financial system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Went- worth will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) deplores the delays in the processing of applications for immigration and change of status;
(2) criticises the uncertainty of business, independent and refugee immigration programs; and
(3) calls on the Government to upgrade and streamline the administration of immigration policy.

This is another motion that went on the Notice Paper quite some time ago. It is sheer coincidence that it has arisen in a week when the immigration debate has stirred some passions. Nevertheless, it is highly relevant to the subjects which are under debate at the moment. The motion refers to the inadequacies of the present administration of and the uncertainties surrounding the Government's immigration program. It should be possible for us to debate here and in the community Australia's immigration program in an objective and rational way. The events of the last few days have not encouraged that hope.

A few days ago the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) issued a totally unexceptional Press release in which he expressed, in particular, concern about the Government's actions in relation to the report of the FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies-not to be confused with the Queensland Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Conduct, which is looking at quite different subjects. I refer to the Stephen FitzGerald Committee to Advise on Australia's Immigration Policies. The inquiry was commissioned in the hope that we would have a report which would give us a framework for considering future immigration policy for this country. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) said here on Tuesday that it was public knowledge that the Government created the FitzGerald inquiry in order that Parliament could have before it an objective report based upon an examination of all the issues, and the canvassing of opinions from the widest possible spectrum of society. That report is highly relevant to the motion before us today because I have no doubt that the FitzGerald inquiry would have received a very large number of criticisms about and comments on the administration of the present immigration policy. It is natural that that would happen when one is considering what should happen in future with our immigration policy.

The Leader of the Opposition last weekend voiced his criticism, as he has in the past, of the fact that it is public knowledge that, when the inquiry's draft report went to the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) insisted that certain sections of it be rewritten because they were critical of certain aspects of present policy. The Prime Minister was not prepared to wear those criticisms publicly. The Leader of the Opposition made his criticisms of the Government in this regard and the most extraordinary debate followed. It seems that one cannot raise a criticism of immigration policies in this country without people screaming `racism' at one. I was one of many who had to depend on newspaper reports about the statement of the Leader of the Opposition for information on what he had said. I could not believe that the substance of what the Leader of the Opposition had said was as reported and as commented on very raucously by certain Government members. In fact, after I arrived in Canberra this week and had the opportunity to look at the statement, I found that the distortions of reporting of it, and the distortions intended to be created in the public mind about what the Leader of the Opposition had actually said, were so extreme as to be grotesque.

Today's debate is very relevant to this entire issue. The Opposition is criticising delays in processing of applications for immigration or change of status and the uncertainty of business, independent and refugee immigration programs and is calling on the Government to upgrade and streamline the administration and immigration policy. Every member of parliament who has an immigration constituency will be aware of very serious inconsistencies in the application of immigration rules in individual cases. I am not saying that that is so across the board; the great bulk of immigration applications that are made and approved we never know about because they are routine and they are dealt with routinely. Members of parliament tend to know about the ones which are a bit tricky-the ones that may be marginal or different in some way-and which do not fit neatly into the guidelines. It is the inconsistencies in those cases that concern me and many other members.

In some cases we see decisions that bear virtually no relationship to decisions that have been given in very similar cases. The actual direction and objectives therefore lack clarity. For example, it is very difficult to advise people on whether they should appeal against a decision, or whether they ought to be encouraged to apply to migrate, when one is faced all the time with these inconsistencies. We can only say to those people, `I know of cases like yours which have been approved. On the other hand, I know of cases like yours which have not been approved'. The Government must address this problem.

The delays are causing enormous problems and distress. The immigration program now is considerably lower than it was several years ago. But several years ago we did not get the complaints that now flow constantly about the length of time that it takes to approve applications. I have to say that in certain cases I think the delays are deliberate bloody-mindedness on the part of the Government. I am sure we are all aware of applications from people trying to immigrate from South Africa. Such people are being told that they can wait a minimum of 18 months, possibly up to 2 1/2 years. The Government has particular views on South Africa-most of which the Opposition agrees with in foreign policy terms. However, to apply, or to appear to apply, an extremely negative attitude to immigration to one group of people is quite unreasonable.

I would like to give an example of what can happen. A major hospital in my electorate, the Southport General Hospital, serves the entire Gold Coast, with a population of a quarter of a million. For a period that hospital found itself without any trained radiologists. It had advertised throughout Australia and had received no applications. It advertised throughout the world and the most suitable applicant was a doctor from South Africa. I might say that at that point the hospital had one radiologist. It decided to recommend the South African doctor under the employer nomination scheme, there being nobody in Australia able to take the position and nobody as well qualified anywhere in the world who had applied for this position.

The nomination went in and this man was prepared to leave as soon as he was able to sell his house and get flight booking to come here. Several months later the radiologist at the hospital also resigned and it was another 12 months before that hospital had any radiologist. It could have had one instantly. There was no doubt about this man's qualifications. There was no doubt about the bona fides of the hospital's attempts to employ an Australian radiologist. The application was clean in every respect. But the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs left that man waiting, not knowing whether he should put his house on the market, because he did not know when he would be able to move himself and his family. In that situation the population of the Gold Coast was left without an essential medical service because of a deliberate policy of going slow on applications from South Africa. The delays in certain areas are extreme and they are without any consideration for the needs of this country.

It has been said many times in debate on immigration here-it was said again this week-that there is only one proper basis for an immigration policy, and that is the interests of this country. In the instance I have given, the interests of a very large number of citizens of this country were at stake but other considerations intervened so that those citizens' interests were totally disregarded.

I also have to take issue with another statement which the Minister has made several times in the last few days. He has made it in media interviews; he made it in his speech in this House on Tuesday. It relates to attitudes towards skilled migrants. If what he has been saying is any indication of his mastery of his portfolio, it is no wonder that we have the problems referred to in the motion. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two tables relating to immigration. They were included in documents tabled by the Minister this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am entitled to speak for several minutes yet I know there are others who wish to speak in this debate so I shall refer briefly to only some of the statistics in the tables. However, the tables have been incorporated in my speech so everyone can see all of the figures, and they can see that I am not being selective in a way that is unfairly favourable to what I am saying, or unfair to the Government. The Minister has been saying that the number of skilled migrants has increased. In fact, on Tuesday he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the tables that I have made available to the Opposition indicate a general level of increase in the skills of people coming into Australia over the past four or five years. That is the reality.

This is the category I wish to refer to now. These tables show that in 1982-83-the last year of a Liberal-National program-the skilled category accounted for 34.17 per cent of the total immigration program. The tables show that that category now accounts for 18.47 per cent of the program. In 1984-85, the first full year of a Hawke government program, the figure decreased to 10.98 per cent. So if the Minister wants to talk about increases during this Government's time in office, that is fair enough, but he ought to admit that there was an enormous decline in that category after this Government took office.

The numbers in the total immigration program have also varied, and one of the tables I have incorporated gives the numbers. In 1982-83 the number of skilled people who came to this country under our immigration program was 31,831. In 1986-87 the number was 20,925-a fair decline. But the story is even worse than that, because in 1984-85, the first full year of operation of the Hawke Government's immigration policies, the number went down to 8,580. Again, if the Minister wants to talk about an increase from 8,580 to 20,925, he ought to say that he is comparing like with like-his own Government's policies over a period. Further, he should and admit that, the number of skilled people coming to this country and the proportion of our total immigration intake in this category have very dramatically declined since the time of the last Liberal-National Party government.

As I have said, I defer to the wish of some other people to speak in this debate, although under the Standing Orders I could speak for several minutes more. I conclude on this note: nobody wants a bipartisan debate on immigration more than I do, both here and in the community. I have certainly always been scrupulously careful about that. But bipartisanship does not mean that either the Opposition or any critic of some aspect of a government's immigration policy is gagged. When the Fraser Government was in power the then shadow Minister for immigration, Mr Mick Young, felt quite free to criticise certain aspects of the Fraser Government's immigration policy. The Fraser Government never indicated that he was doing something mischievous by criticising the policy. His criticisms were debated by the Government on their merit. Criticisms of policy should be debated on their merit. It is highly desirable that we have a bipartisan approach to immigration because it is one fundamental area to the welfare of this nation. However, we will not have a reasonable debate if, every time there is a criticism, people start to squawk like chooks about to get their heads cut off about matters that are irrelevant to the issues that have been raised. Unfortunately, that has been the case in the debate this week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) made a wide-ranging speech and referred to a number of matters that I feel obliged to reply to. She spoke at some length about the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his actions this week. She kept emphasising that there was an overreaction, that some people were accusing him of making racist comments, and so on. Neither the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Holding) nor I have accused the Leader of the Opposition of making racist comments.
—Oh yes-just hinted at.

—Just a moment. We said that his figures were wrong. Not only were they demonstrably proved wrong, but on Tuesday he showed that he did not even understand the nature of the immigration program. At one stage in the debate-this is recorded in Tuesday's Hansard-he said, `Brothers and sisters don't have to pass a test'. After he received some further information from the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) and other advisers he came back to the table and said, `What I really meant to say was yes, they do have to pass a test but it is a different test from the test they had to pass in 1981'. The fact is that he tried to compare the 1981 figures with the 1986 figures. In the 1981 figures he had not included brothers and sisters whilst in the 1986 figures he had. He then tried to say that we were comparing like with like. On the basis of that he drew some ridiculous conclusions about the family reunion program.

SPEECH.PARA: On Tuesday the honourable member for Mitchell and others, including the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), denied what the Leader of the Opposition had said. Now the honourable member for Moncrieff says, `Why has there been such an uproar?'. Why has there been such an uproar? In the original Press statement by the Leader of the Opposition he clearly stated:
. . . there is too high a proportion of migrants under the family reunion category and too small a proportion of those within the skilled and business migrant category.

He stated that the Opposition would change those proportions. Obviously, there is concern in the community as a result of that. It has nothing to do with any racist type comments. The racist type comments that the Minister referred to were in regard to comments made by other members of the Opposition.

I now address a couple of other matters raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff. She spoke in terms of facts and figures and tried again to support the unsupportable, namely, that the Leader of the Opposition got it wrong. He has not been able to reply to that point. In fact, the more personal explanations he made on Tuesday, the more foolish he looked. It is time that somebody in this House pointed out to him that when one makes a mistake one gets up and says honestly, `I made a mistake', and that is the end of the matter. If he wants to argue on the basis of some claim about increasing skills or reducing family reunions, let him do so, but not on the basis of fallacious facts.

Let me turn to the issue raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff in her motion, which, by the way, the Government rejects. We reject it because it is based on a totally unsympathetic approach to the problems we face as a government in relation to the immigration program. Why is that? I will tell honourable members why: it is because of the enormous success of this Government in achieving a 50 per cent increase in applications from people wanting to come to Australia. Nearly 1 1/2 million people applied last year to come to Australia. That is an amazing figure. Obviously, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has to deal with all those applications. It is a phenomenal job and the honourable member for Mitchell knows that. The Department has been stretched to try to come to grips with it in difficult times and in times of limited resources. That is the situation with which the Department has been faced because of 1 1/2 million applicants.

We have a problem because as the number of applicants increases, obviously, more and more people will pass the points system-a points system which the Leader of the Opposition did not even know existed for brothers and sisters, judging by his comments on Tuesday. If they do pass it, we still have a problem. Every year the Government has increased the immigration program. This year 132,000 migrants have been accepted and the Government is considering increasing the number next year. Notwithstanding that situation, approximately nine out of 10 applicants are rejected; only one in 10 can be accepted. In that situation one must sympathise with the situation faced by the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! You try to explain it away. You do not take any action.

—The honourable member for Mitchell interjects that the Government does not take any action. The Government has done many things trying to cope with what has become a massive problem as a result of its success-namely, that more and more people are trying to come to Australia. The alternative is to say that no-one will be processed. This issue must be dealt with humanely and sympathetically given the resources that one has. If the honourable member for Mitchell were in government, he would understand the massive problems with which the Department must deal. What evidence did the honourable member for Moncrieff offer to support her motion? Of the 1.5 million applications for migration to Australia, the honourable member referred to only one case in South Africa, a case obviously chosen by her to make her point. On the basis of that case the honourable member said that conclusions of the kind contained in her motion could be drawn, such as deploring delays, criticisms of the uncertainty, and so on. That is not good enough. Even if everything about the case is factually correct, we must ask what department that deals with 1.5 million people would not make some mistakes. Tell me that! No conclusions can be drawn from one particular case. The honourable member produced no statistics or facts to support the claims in her motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government admits that there is a difficulty because of the huge increase in the number of applications, but because of that one should not assume that somehow a crisis point has been reached at which there is no processing of applications or that there is total uncertainty.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine months for an interview in Lebanon.

—The Opposition talks about cutting government services; it talks about that all the time. The Department of Immigration has had to bear its brunt of cutbacks like all other departments. If the Opposition were in government and it had to face cutbacks, how would it deal with a big increase in immigration applications? Let us show some sensitivity to the matter instead of talking nonsense. Of course there will be delays. One cannot help delays when one is cutting resources. The Department is doing the best it can with its resources. If the Opposition has practical suggestions, the Government is prepared to listen to them. What are they? The honourable member for Moncrieff had none. As I said, she referred to only one case from which she drew general conclusions. Has the Opposition any practical suggestions for improving the current difficult situation?
—Change your policy on South African migrants. Easy!
—The honourable member for Mitchell wants the Government to change its policy on South African migrants. The Government does not have a policy on South African migrants that is different.
—You do-one of delay and frustration. You know that.
—What evidence does the honourable member have for that statement?
—The Minister's statement in the House.
—Order! I call the honourable member for Mitchell to order. The honourable member for Calwell will address his remarks through the Chair.

—The one case used by the honourable member for Moncrieff was supposed to prove that delays in South Africa were deliberate. What rubbish! Of course the Government is careful about what it does in regard to South Africa; it is careful about what it does with migrants from all over the world. But that is not to say that the Government has a deliberate or substantial policy to delay people in South Africa, or in any other place. There are problems everywhere in the world because of the matter that I mentioned earlier. With 1.5 million people applying for immigration, one cannot expect, when one made one's application only yesterday to be dealt with today. Too many people have been applying for migration to Australia because everyone thinks Australia is a great country. That is because the Labor Government has made it a great country in its past five years in government. The longer it is in government the more bloody applications it will get! I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker; I have been interrupted too much by the honourable member for Mitchell.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government totally rejects this empty motion. The Opposition should make some concrete suggestions about how the current situation can be improved, given the number of people applying for migration and the resources available to the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes left to me, I shall seriously address the fears that some people in the community have, as well as some of the misunderstandings. Without repeating some of the criticisms made by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) of the administration of the policy, I want to explain in essence what the principal difficulties are and are perceived to be.

SPEECH.PARA: The labour movement of Australia has a fear that immigration destroys jobs. It demonstrably does not. We are restructuring our economy, and a combination of sensible rates of change in various areas of policy-micro-economics, macro-economics and technological advances, immigration and education policies-can help us cope with the change. We harmonise the change. The Labor Government came into power beholden to a constituency that wanted less migration; but it was also beholden to a constituency that wanted family reunion migration-and properly so, because family reunion often means skilled people and often means reduced social security output, especially as the people with the greatest demands for family reunions are usually refugees whose immediate family has been exterminated in war or concentration camps. The comfort of having someone in the family enabled them to settle more easily in otherwise traumatic circumstances. The refugee program and the humanitarian programs were kept up-commendably and properly so-but by reducing skilled migration, independent migration and business migration, the Government distorted the composition.

The composition of our migration program ethnically varies according to world circumstances. When the Greek, Italian and Maltese migration began in Australia, many traditional Anglo-Celtic Australians did not like it. They said that they were not traditional sources. They had not read the nineteenth century of Australia-but never mind; they said that. But, of course, the term `traditional sources' now extends to the Mediterranean, and properly. Now even some people from the Mediterranean are saying that they want migrants only from traditional sources-that is, the whole of Europe; eastern, western and southern Europe. Their economic structures are similar to Australia's, their birthrates are similar to Australia's and their economies are better than Australia's, for the most part, and it is not very attractive to most of them to migrate to Australia, especially in large numbers, and certainly not those who are employed and those who are skilled. Australia wants people who are employed. We do not want the unemployed. The unemployed of Europe will be unemployed in Australia because of similar structural problems.

So, by their phobia about skilled, business and independent migration, they have produced a situation in which the principal intake has been from Asia. Having said that, I believe that all Australians should recognise that our principal intake for years to come is going to be from Asia anyway, especially if glasnost is successful. If glasnost is successful, we will not have people wanting to leave Germany and other countries, as they did when we were in power, because of fears of Soviet invasions of Poland and elsewhere. Once there is stability in Europe, politically as well as economically, the people who will want to come here, who will have the skills we need and who will be able to make the contribution we need are going to be people such as Indians from Fiji and Malaysia, Chinese from Malaysia and Hong Kong, and Anglo-Burmese and other minorities from Burma. Why? Because they have skills and high levels of education and they suffer prejudice and discrimination in their country of origin.

Australians are going to have to adjust to the fact that this is different from Britain or France settling some moral obligation of their former colonial years, where they took in anyone, regardless of education, skill or capacity to assimilate or integrate. So, we have a situation where the Opposition in government pursued, and the present Government says that it pursues, a highly selective immigration program based on what people can offer Australia but, of course, a non-discriminatory one in terms of country of origin, and that is the vital thing. It is wrong to say that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) or the shadow Minister has departed from that commitment. They have not done so, and that is the essence of the bipartisan commitment. We are not bound by every detail or by the handling or the sensitivity of what a government does or does not do. But the essence of the bipartisan policy which we formulated in government is still adhered to.

If we look at the foot of page 2 of the Press release of the Leader of the Opposition we see five principles. Those five principles were enshrined in the first major statement on immigration by the Fraser Government. They were repeated throughout the history of the Fraser Government and in opposition under the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). Those five principles always look at Australia's national interests. It does mean: what do the migrants contribute to Australia in terms of skill and in terms of cultural, economic and social contribution? We are concerned, then, about the capacity of the Australian society to accept and absorb change. That rests on, amongst other things, our capacity as leaders of this country on both sides of this House to educate the population to understand the reality of life.

Britain is an integral part of Europe. Supranational institutions, such as the European Parliament, hold the future for Britain. It is part of the North Atlantic community. Australia is an Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean nation, and as such our involvement inexorably, increasingly and properly, not just in trade but also in cultural and other matters, is going to be with various parts of Asia and Africa. The result of that is that, whether some people understand it or not or care for it or not, not only the flow of tourism as well as the flow of trade but also the flow of migrants will come from our part of the world, if only because of our involvement here and our future lying here as well as the declining birth rates in what are now deemed to be our traditional sources.

No-one should fear the way Richmond has settled, as we read in today's Age newspaper. If we really understand the settlement program in Australia, we will understand the enriching qualities that are coming to this country. The children of tomorrow are going to find a harmonious society because we relate to each other as people, not because of colour or background but because of the qualities which our migrants bring by a highly selective program which asks only: What is it that they can give to us; what is their level of education; what is the skill that they can offer? Of course, even when it comes to the special humanitarian programs and to the refugee intake, we apply selective criteria.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member for Goldstein will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) congratulates the Government on its commitment to a health insurance system based on the principles of fairness, simplicity and efficiency;
(2) calls upon the Government to maintain a universal system of health insurance funded by a fairly applied levy arrangement; and
(3) condemns attacks on the universal health insurance system.

Notice of this motion was given by me in September, following the election in the middle of last year when our opponents came forward with the unbelievable and incredible health policy with which we saw them enter that election campaign. One was to continue to pay the levy, and to pay the first $250 for services. There was much confusion in the community, and very rightly the electorate chose not to go down that path. Since then a number of amended health policies have been introduced, in November last year and March this year. On each occasion the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has found it necessary to shoot down the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who put forward those proposals which would have seen the abolition of Medicare. It seems that a year after that election last year the Opposition is still in a quandary as to which direction it should take.

I remember very well the vision and the will that this Government showed in 1983 in introducing its Medicare policy, and the very long nights that many of us spent in this place passing that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was worth it.

—As the honourable member has suggested, it was well worth it. On every occasion on which I have spoken about health policy since I have been in this place, I have made the point very clearly-and it remains true today-that unfortunately the direction of health policy in this country is much more towards treatment and delivery systems than, as it should be, towards prevention and promotion of good health. It is a great pity that the Opposition still does not realise that our health policy and the emphasis of the health debate should be going in that direction.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Centenary Conference earlier this week Senator Peter Baume-of course he is one of the more erudite and lucid Opposition spokesmen in the area of health policy-made the point very clearly that we need to remember that health care delivery has only a marginal effect on health outcomes, and indeed the inequalities that exist in our health care system are basically related to many social factors about which governments can do a great deal if they have the will. Poverty, diet, education opportunities, employment, child care, housing and welfare services are all very important determinants of the health of the population in general.

In the time that I have available to me today I hope to focus on the success that has been Medicare and to congratulate the Government on that and on its commitment to continuing that program, but also to sound a warning to many health providers who believe that a free market, entrepreneurial system will perhaps offer them better opportunities. The warning is one that has been sounded overseas, where similar health programs have been instituted and are failing, and it is a warning of which medical professionals in this country are aware.

Let us first talk about Medicare. The basic tenet of the Medicare structure is that of universal cover and payment for universal cover on the basis of a fair community rating principle. From each person the levy extracts an amount according to his means, and each person receives health care according to his needs. Indeed, it can be seen that before the introduction of our scheme in 1983, the cost of health care for low income earners was so prohibitive that large numbers of them were unable to take out private health insurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two million.

—Indeed, there were two million people in this country without health insurance. When we consider the economic development of Australia and our standard of living, that was a horrendous situation. The introduction of the Medicare scheme has turned that about.

SPEECH.PARA: As was mentioned by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) in this House yesterday, the Economic Planning Advisory Council said that the principal benefit of the introduction of Medicare was for wage earners and families, especially the less well off. The redistributive effect of Medicare and the social wage aspect of this program have been very important in government policy in a macro sense as well as in the delivery of health services. We now have a situation where all Australians are covered and they pay according to their means. I think that very few people on either side of the House could find fault with this system. I know that there are those who scream for a return to the previous system, but when we look at overseas evidence it is rather frightening to see what has happened in the United States where a free market philosophy is operating because in health there is not a perfect market at all.

There have been many criticisms. One of the things that the Opposition threw at us back in 1983 was that this would bring about an increase in over-servicing. Yet the average per capita increase in medical services over the last 12 years is 3.4 per cent. In the four years in which Medicare has been operating the average per capita increase in services has been 4 per cent, 4 per cent, 3.1 per cent and 2.9 per cent. So Medicare is not contributing to an increase in over-servicing. Whenever our opponents debate health in this House they blame Medicare for the increase in hospital queues that is occurring in some States, particularly in New South Wales. There have always been queues for elective surgery; indeed, to run an efficient hospital it is necessary to have such a system. In many cases this situation is brought about by State policy, but over the last few years, and particularly in New South Wales, it has been manipulated by provider interest groups. That manipulation has produced the problem. The Sydney Morning Herald earlier this week reported a statement from the new New South Wales Minister for Health. It stated:

The largest single cause of the waiting lists was the continued stalemate with orthopaedic and ophthalmic surgeons, Mr Collins said. They could cut the lists by a third when they returned to the State's public hospital.
We have the new New South Wales Liberal Minister for Health saying that the recalcitrant surgeons are the cause of one-third of the waiting list problem that exists in New South Wales at the moment.

The outstanding result of Medicare has been in a macro sense. We find that two million people have been able to receive health insurance cover with no additional cost in terms of the percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) spent on health care. The result has been very consistent for Australia over the last few years. We spend about 7.6 per cent of our gross domestic product on health. The United States, where 37 million people are not adequately covered by health insurance-an horrendous statistic-spends approximately 12 per cent of its gross domestic product on health care. It is a shameful result and one that frightens all who consider the prospect of the latest Tuckey health plan for Australia. In the United States for many people severe or chronic illness means not only dealing with the medical problem but also financial hardship and for many bankruptcy. Honourable members do not have to take my word for it. I would like to quote Professor Stuart Altman who is a federal health economist and an adviser to the Congress and to the Reagan Government. In a speech delivered in Australia just a few weeks ago he stated:

We as a country have been unwilling and unable politically to really make the kinds of choices that people say we have to make. I think that the United States is going to continue to see rapid increases (in health costs), at least through the end of the century and it could approach 15% of GNP.

You have to believe that at some point the payers are going to become so furious that they finally will muster the political will to do something about it, but quite frankly, I don't see it in the cards, regardless of who wins the next presidential election.
Professor Altman, I mention again, is an adviser in health care for the United States Congress. He finishes his quotation by saying:
So I leave you with the feeling that, if you want an exciting, well-functioning health care system-stay in Australia.
That is a glowing endorsement of our program in Australia and a condemnation of the free market policy being pursued in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe all this, do you?

—I believe Professor Altman who is a very distinguished health economist. Finally, I express a warning to members of the medical profession. Members of the medical profession are very fortunate to have their income underwritten by the Government. That has always been the case. It is not a perfect scheme, I am sure. There are criticisms that are fair, but I think that members of the medical profession should heed the experience overseas. This Government wants a good health care system and a healthy population. That makes economic, social and political sense. Doctors want fair remuneration and they want clinical freedom. That is where the irony lies for them. I would like to quote another prominent United States spokesman, Dr Mitchell Rabkin, the Professor of the Harvard Medical School. Recently in Australia he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The less tightly society controls the overall capacity of its health system and the economic freedom of providers to practice as they see fit, and to price their services as they see fit, then the more direct appears to be the private or public payers intrusion directly into the doctor/patient relationship and the less clinical freedom at the level of treatment will payers grant the providers. In fighting as tenaciously as they have for the principle of free enterprise in medicine, for example, American physicians seem unwittingly to have surrendered their clinical freedom, a freedom still enjoyed to a much greater degree by their colleagues abroad.
I will add to that a quotation from the Western Australian President of the Australian Medical Association, which is hardly a purveyor of socialist philosophy. Talking about the Tuckey plan he says:
. . . will we fare any better if the private health funds take over?

The answer could well be no. Take for example the American health care scene, where powerful health funds have reigned supreme, so that the medical profession has found itself squeezed and propelled into all sorts of fancy named cost cutting health care schemes.

I say to the profession that it is important that it understand the direction that the Opposition may take if its health policy ever-God forbid-gets under way. This Government has introduced a universal policy based on community rating. It has maintained a hospital system which admits a higher proportion of the population than the United States or Canada within the same percentage of gross domestic product. Increasingly other countries are looking to Australia for an example. I say to honourable members that for politically expedient reasons it is stupid to introduce an unfair, more costly system that endangers professional integrity. It would be sheer lunacy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.
—The honourable member for Canning will have the right to speak later in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) has been trying to support the success of the health system today. All I can say is that the only point I support is his view on the health prevention approach by the Better Health Commission of which he was a member. The rest of his arguments did not stand up. He was suggesting that the hospital queues were a fact of life before 1982. He conceded that the number of people in the hospital queue in New South Wales is now 40,000 and that the new Greiner Administration has now got to cope with this accumulating problem that has increased since 1982 under the Medicare arrangements. The proposition suggests that Medicare is fairer, simpler and more efficient. All the evidence suggests that that is completely incorrect. For instance, in Victoria there were 24,000 people on the waiting list at 30 March 1987. Victoria has had difficulty in working out the exact numbers and consequently it has changed the way in which it counts the numbers so that it can have a few less. That waiting list is growing every month and a great number of people, especially those who want to get into the public hospitals, are unable to get into a hospital of any kind.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem is identified by Dr Mark Ragg who wrote in the Weekend Australian in December last year that there is a very widespread belief amongst the medical profession that patients are actually dying in the queues because of inadequate hospital care caused by critical bed and nurse shortages. There are numerous examples to support that statement. I would like to quote Dr Peter Lawrence, Director of the Intensive Care Unit at Sydney's Concord Repatriation General Hospital. He stated:

We have to make choices-it is not hard to decide between a 70 year old heavy smoker with a bad chest and possibly only one or two more useful years to live and a 45 year-old with an acute problem who, if he survives, will live a long time. At times the choice is harder.

As I mentioned, the Victorian Government has made changes to its list classification and it is having difficulty making the hard decisions. The numbers on the waiting lists in South Australia are growing. Around Australia up to 100,000 people are on the Medicare lists, waiting for up to four years for elective surgery. The definition of `elective surgery' is that surgery which is not life threatening. To get into a hospital in Australia under the Medicare system, one must be facing death or have suffered a major motor accident or a traumatic problem such as that.

New Zealand and England are examples of countries which nationalised health systems. New Zealand is a close example of what happens under a nationalised health system. In the Gibb report, Dame Dorothy Fraser indicated the experience of that national health scheme, where 50,000 people are on the lists awaiting hospitalisation. Last year, the average waiting time for operations for hip replacements, kidney stones, cataracts, heart by-passes and osteoarthritis was at least two years. Almost as many people are waiting for outpatient appointments to determine whether they needed hospitalisation. That is the position in New Zealand, which has had a nationalised health scheme for many years.
Dame Dorothy Fraser went on to say-and I suggest this problem will happen in Australia:

The New Zealand public hospital system uses waiting lists to ration its services and encounters great difficulty in determining patients' priorities. It tends to respond to pressure from patients, family doctors, politicians or the media rather than develop criteria for priority. Uncomplaining, less articulate and poorer members of society tend to gravitate to the end of queues.

That situation is now rapidly developing in Australia as the queues grow longer and people are unable to get into hospitals. Medicare costs are horrific; its cost to the Australian taxpayer in 1982-83 was $3.4 billion, or 6.9 per cent of Federal Government outlays. In 1987-88 it was $8.2 billion, or 10.5 per cent of Federal outlays. Is such an escalation of the Government's contribution to medical health fair, simple and efficient?

In February 1984 the Government introduced a one per cent levy on taxable income. Despite the public cynicism that the levy would be increased to meet escalating health costs, the Government gave assurances in 1984, 1985 and again in 1986 that the Medicare levy would not be raised. As we all know, the Medicare levy was raised last year from one per cent to 1.25 per cent. So much for the integrity and the trust- worthiness of this Hawke Government. Of course, it is not beyond possibility that the levy will be raised again in the Treasurer's mini-budget to be presented next week.

The real cost of Medicare, to which the honourable member for Perth did not allude, is a 4.3 per cent levy on taxable income, if the true figures are taken into consideration. At 1.25 per cent, the Medicare levy raises $2 billion in round figures. Medical and hospital services expenditure in round figures is $5.2 billion and identified health grants to the States amount to $1.7 billion. That is a total of $6.9 billion, near enough to $7 billion, of Commonwealth Government expenditure, or a 4.3 per cent levy if it were to be raised in actual terms from individual taxpayers. That is the real cost of the so-called free Medicare system.

One of the other difficulties facing Medicare throughout Australia is that patients are impressed by science and new technology and are demanding ever increasing services using the new technology. With pressures from patients and financial incentives in the system to provide more and more services, it is not surprising that benefits paid for pathology rose by 8.1 per cent between 1984-85 and 1985-86 and by 11 per cent in the first six months of 1986-87. The increase in the use of CAT scanning services totalled 34 per cent.

I shall give an example of what happens to a patient complaining of a headache when he visits his doctor. The doctor could opt for a long consultation in which he looks for a history of migraine or any other problems. That could cost $30. Alternatively, under Medicare, the doctor could send the patient to have x-rays and blood tests. The patient might be a hypochondriac and fear tumours or a stroke. The cost of that service would be an additional $50. Another possibility is that the doctor could order a CAT scan to check for a tumour, which could run into hundreds of dollars. If the patient has been to his local entrepreneurial practice, under Medicare he will pay nothing because of bulk billing. Because of the perception that such a service is free, patients consider such treatment as their right.

I now turn to private hospitals. In the 1987 mini-Budget, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) reduced the rebate for medical treatment from 85 per cent to 75 per cent for private hospitals but maintained it as 85 per cent for public hospitals. That was supposed to force doctors into bulk billing and put pressure on the viability of private hospitals in an attempt to create savings for the so-called fair Medicare system.

The effect of the structure of Medicare has been to shift the general revenue demand from government to health funds. The Minister has, in effect, used the health funds as an extended arm of taxation. The Minister's restructuring of Medicare has seen operating costs in private hospitals in Victoria rise by 30 per cent. Hospitals are heavily labour intensive, with some 70 per cent of their costs taken up by labour and 30 per cent by incidentals. Labour costs demands and increases are expected to add another 10 per cent to operating costs during the next six months. So in less than 2 1/2 years operating costs in Victorian private hospitals will have increased by a massive 40 per cent.

Although health funds have been forced to increase their premiums, they have been unable to cover the incredible increases in private hospital charges. This means that the level of benefits is not enough to cover hospital charges and the out of pocket contributions of the patients are getting bigger and bigger. The Minister claims that he is not responsible for the lengthening hospital queues, yet it is quite clear that the Medicare system of which he is so proud is forcing more and more people into public hospitals because they cannot meet the enormous personal contributions that private hospitals are forced to charge. The Government is responsible for the demand for public hospital beds through the Minister's strategy on Medicare, through union pressure on wages, and through the centralised wage fixing system, which forces the costs to go up and up.

I now turn to the subject of doctors' salaries, about which the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear) has had quite a bit to say in this House. In my view, he has totally misrepresented the position. Doctors' salaries have been quoted in gross figures that take no account of the equipment used in the case of radiologists and pathologists and the skills that surgeons apply to their tasks. The overhead costs involved in the figures so glibly quoted by the honourable member for Canning are never taken into account. A rule of thumb is that, of the figures quoted, 50 per cent are generally taken up in overhead costs. The honourable member for Canning is keen to display publicly confidential information he has gained from Health Insurance Commission documented files, and that makes one wonder whether confidential information can be retained under this Government.

The salary arrangements for doctors take no account of the skills, responsibilities, life-saving decisions and the long years of training, as well as the short time doctors have at the peak of their profession. The coalition supports doctors in their professional position and totally rejects the attack of the honourable member for Canning on doctors' salaries and their position in the Australian medical community. From the point of view of the honourable member for Canning and the Minister for Community Services and Health, doctors' salaries are computer driven: the doctors' salaries should be set at whatever comes out of the computer. Through the Medicare system, the Government wants a salaried medical profession and it wants to remove the doctor-patient relationship. It does not want to provide incentive for doctors to improve their skills. The Minister and the honourable member for Canning want a nationalised system. They want an arbitrated arrangement to sort out what doctors' fees should be. They want to make doctors public servants.

Finally, Medicare is in chaos. Nationalised Medicare-type schemes worldwide have been a total failure. The poor are exposed in the queues. The doctors are unhappy. The costs are escalating through the roof. Fifty per cent of the population are paying twice, as they pay their levy and private insurance; and, of course, 50 per cent of the population are taking out private cover to make sure they get the doctor of their choice and the hospital of their choice and, in the final analysis, in the hope that they will get some treatment under Medicare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Liberal Party of Australia supports the doctors, the Australian Labor Party will always support the patients, because that is what the whole focus of medical insurance is for-to support the patients. In this debate today, honourable members should consider what Medicare does not do. What Medicare does not do or what it has not meant is the loss of professional autonomy to the doctors. Of all the decisions that are made on medical grounds in Australia, they are still made by doctors, not by politicians. If one goes to the doctor, he makes the decisions, just as he always has. Therefore, there has not been a loss of autonomy with the introduction of Medicare.
—As in the United States.

—Yes, like in the United States. Medicare has not meant that there has been a drop in medical standards. Nobody in this country would suggest that since 1984 medical standards have dropped, for the very good reason that it is not true. Another thing that Medicare has not done is to lengthen the hospital queues. The accusations fly that that is the case, but I refer to a Press release put out after a meeting of all health Ministers-that is, State and Federal, Liberal Party, National Party and Labor Party health Ministers-in Fremantle last year. The Press release said this:

SPEECH.PARA: At their annual meeting held in Fremantle, the Ministers pointed to the following factors affecting waiting times:
nurse shortages resulting in bed closures;
supply of some specialist medical services, such as orthopaedic surgeons-
as referred to by the honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth)-
advances in technology allowing a greater variety of procedures, such as coronary bypass surgery, lens implant for eyes, or hip and other joint replacements, to be more readily performed-
therefore, it is a change in technology-
greater public awareness of new improved technology leading to greater demand.

Therefore, when one considers the hospital queues, those are the reasons for them, not Medicare. One could also add to that the fact that Medicare, as has been pointed out, insured over two million people who did not have access to medical insurance before. Those people are now going to hospitals to have operations. We also picked up 300,000 repatriation patients under Medicare who were not there before. Workers compensation and motor car accident insurance, and a lot of those types of claims that never went to the general hospital or were not admitted under the general hospital procedure before are being included under Medicare. Therefore, it is a spurious argument to say that hospital queues are the result of Medicare. All the evidence suggests otherwise.

Let us consider the alternatives that will be put up by the Opposition. Of course, one has only to refer to the spokesman who disgraced himself in this House yesterday and was thrown out. In a speech to the surgeons, he said:
The first thing I want to walk away from is community rating, where everyone in the community is charged the same premium. I believe it's destroying the system, because it's a major distortion-
listen to this-
of normal business practice.

Therefore, what the health spokesman for the Opposition is saying is that health insurance is a normal business practice. The fact is that it is not. What the Government is doing is insuring people's lives. One cannot compare people's lives with motor car insurance, because they are not the same. It has been recognised, as was pointed out by the honourable member for Perth, by Senator Peter Baume in his speech in Sydney the day before yesterday. He was quite right: medical insurance is different from other business practices, but not according to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The policy that he flew up the flagpole in Townsville got shot full of holes by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard).

I refer now to a Press report headed `Howard ticks off Tuckey for health policy comments'. The Leader of the Opposition is no mug when it comes to public perception about health policy. He could see where it was going. Given his normal rein, the Opposition spokesman on health would have a so-called free-enterprise system of health insurance in Australia, but the Leader of the Opposition knows that is political suicide. He knows that out in the community people do not cop that one, and that the community rating principle is accepted out in the wider community; so he had to tick off the spokesman on health. That is the Opposition's alternative.

Just to reinforce that, after the Opposition got thrashed at the last election, as it should have been, a review was put under way by the Opposition to find out what went wrong. I should like to quote from it. It states:
Our promise to tear up Medicare disturbed the most dangerous of all political sleeping dogs. No subject is more important and we promised to alter it yet again.
A significant number of people still care about social values as well as balance sheets.

That is what the Opposition's review said about its performance in the last election, but it has not learnt the lesson because the Opposition's health spokesman got up in Townsville in front of all those surgeons and, with the big hairy chest, he said, `I will give you what you want'. Free enterprise in medicine never works. As the honourable member for Perth pointed out, in America, there are 37 million people with no health insurance at all. The Opposition talks about waiting lists and all the inadequacies. I point out there is a better health insurance system in this country than one will ever get under anything the Opposition has ever proposed.

The Opposition has run the whole gamut. It had five proposals in seven years when it was in government, and it has made three or four proposals since. There have not been many that the Opposition has not had a stab at. It has had a go at all of them, and it is still back to square one. It still has the hairy-chested one up in Townsville saying, `We will have free enterprise back into it'. The Opposition cannot have it; it just does not work. People will not cop it. Opposition members can talk about whether Medicare is accepted out in the community. I shall quote from the latest survey done to ascertain whether people support Medicare. I can tell the House it is up by 3 per cent, to 64 per cent. That is the approval rating of Medicare. Only 15 per cent say it should be abolished.

Therefore, if the Opposition wants to go into the next election with a silly tax policy as well as a silly health policy, the Labor Party will take it on, because the Labor Party will give it a thrashing once again. The Opposition will not learn; it had a review that told it what was wrong-but, no, Opposition members are not even like the primates, because even the primates know that if one does something once and it hurts, one does not do it again. The Opposition has not learnt. Its members bob up and suggest free enterprise medicine again. I despair at the Opposition; it is so talentless that it cannot even recognise--

TALK.START.PARA: —Thick.
—The honourable member for Corio says it is thick.
—As a brick.

—I would not have said `thick as a brick', but others have said it. I return to the survey. When one fronts up for one's Medicare claims, the approval rating there is 94 per cent. There is a 64 per cent approval for Medicare and it is increasing all the time, and 94 per cent approve of the system itself when it comes to people getting their cheques. I am quite happy to defend that. It is being accepted out in the community. It is a rational policy that has stood the test of time and it is getting better, despite the fact that there are some surgeons-the old doctor-dollar relationship-who want to go back to that private health insurance because they know that under any private health insurance that doctor-dollar relationship will improve to their advantage. The fact is that Medicare is a patient-based system, not a doctor-based system. If the Opposition wants to go out supporting doctors, good luck to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to conclude by quoting once again the quote that was used by the honourable member for Perth-that from Professor Altman. I remind the House that he was and still is the Federal Health Economic Adviser to Congress in the United States of America. He has had a look at the sort of system that the Opposition wants to bring in. He lives under such a system. He came to Australia to examine its health insurance system. I remind the House of his final words:
So I leave you with the feeling that, if you want an exciting, well-functioning healthcare system-stay in Australia.
All I can say to that is, `Amen!'.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 50 seconds that are left for me to say something here, I am amazed that the Government brings in this ridiculous motion. Prior to 1972 when Gough Whitlam came to power in this country, Australia had the best health system in the world. For the sake of 6 per cent or 8 per cent of the people who were not insured, that Government smashed the system and gave Australians this socialised medicine, which has been tried all around the world and failed. Government members wallowed in an orgy of ideology to socialise medicine, which has done absolutely nothing for anyone, yet they have the hide to tell us it is free. It was costing $786m when the Government came to power and today it costs $8,132m-and Australians are paying for that. They could be paying 10 per cent or 15 per cent less tax if this system had not been brought in. The honourable member for Perth (Dr Charlesworth) is attempting to interject in a ridiculous manner. He says in his motion that he wants to fund this system by a levy. We would have to increase the levy from 1.25 per cent to 4.25 per cent. That is what he wants to do.
