DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force Board of Inquiry-Parliamentary Process-Soviet Union: Fishing Rights-Third World Debt-Road Funding-Northern Territory Government-Petrol Prices

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just after noon on Friday, 2 May 1986, a Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Mirage jet, A3-40, piloted by Pilot Officer Craig Douglas Mackelmann, crashed into the sea off Williamtown, New South Wales. Subsequent to that unfortunate fatal accident, the Royal Australian Air Force conducted a board of inquiry called by Air Vice-Marshal Radford, Operational Command. Whilst the result of that inquiry was an open finding, the board leaned heavily on evidence provided by the Air Force's own doctor, the then Squadron Leader Dr Jeffrey John Pinkstone, that Pilot Officer Craig Mackelmann was still under the influence of liquor as a result of an official and compulsory dining-in night at the RAAF base, Williamtown, held on the night prior to the accident. The board of inquiry recorded breaches of Air Force regulations against the late Pilot Officer Mackelmann.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, you may recall the publicity given to this case in January 1987, and subsequent to that. It made great copy. People everywhere, in and out of uniform, from the highest to the lowest, then accepted that my former constituent, though a proficient and efficient RAAF pilot, had brought his death upon himself. I speak with considerable feeling on this issue because, in a period of less than 15 months, three young men who had chosen the Air Force as their career and who called my Moreton electorate home, went to their deaths as a result of RAAF crashes. I am not casting aspersions on the findings of the other two incidents, involving Flight Lieutenant Stephen Erskine and Flight Lieutenant Mark Fallon, but I am expressing grave concerns as to the atmospherics, the innuendo and the misinformation associated with the RAAF Mackelmann board of inquiry.

Captain Graham Mackelmann, Craig's father, came to me in early October 1986, after being frustrated by the Air Force in his bid to obtain a copy of the report of the board of inquiry. It was only after my intervention and approach to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) that the board of inquiry document was eventually made available to him. Though the document, comprising hundreds of pages, was handed over about a fortnight prior to the commencement of the New South Wales Government-run coronial inquest, the Minister's direction to release remains appreciated. The late Craig Mackelmann's entire immediate family has an aviation background, and his father is a senior captain with Australian Airlines. His father was alarmed by the Air Force doctor's evidence. He was deeply concerned that the marker over his son's ocean grave carried the word `alcohol'.

When the coroner's inquest commenced late in December 1986, headlines such as `Coroner concerned at alcohol intake by RAAF pilots' began to appear. The headline `Boozy night before fatal flight' reinforced to the world the impression that Craig was not in control of his aircraft. With the RAAF board of inquiry having placed such emphasis on the effects of alcohol and the dining-in night, Craig Mackelmann's father sought outside expert advice. That expert opinion, using the same witness statements, established that, while Craig had consumed liquor at the dining-in night, Craig would have had no alcohol in his system after 4 a.m. the next morning-a period in excess of eight hours prior to the fatal flight.

Can honourable members imagine how any father would have reacted with that knowledge? He had an obligation to his deceased son to appear before the coronial inquest and fight to clear his besmirched name. That he did. Captain Mackelmann subsequently sought legal aid to present the evidence he had gathered as a result of his own efforts. Correspondence passed between myself and the Defence Minister in a bid to obtain legal aid. The Defence Minister advised that he was not in a position to assist with legal aid. I then commenced representations to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). Attached to his reply to me was a copy of a letter written to Captain Mackelmann by the Office of Legal Aid Administration. That letter says, in part, `The Attorney-General has indicated that assistance may be authorised', if a person acting on behalf of the Government in the exercise of duty gives incorrect advice which causes the claimant to take a course which is to his financial detriment. Further, the letter mentions `special circumstances which lead to' conclusions of moral obligations on the Commonwealth's part as representing legal aid criteria.

If there were ever a case of incorrect advice and moral obligation it is this case. Had the then Squadron Leader Dr Pinkstone been more careful and competent in terms of the evidence he gave to the RAAF board of inquiry, this matter would never have reached the point it has today. Not only has Craig's family lived in a state of agony since 2 May 1986, but also they have had to dig deep into their pockets to ensure the emergence of the truth about Craig's state of sobriety. It has cost them thousands of dollars to prove their son had not a skerrick of alcohol in his veins when his Mirage crashed into the sea the following afternoon.

The New South Wales coronial inquiry was a lengthy affair requiring far more time than the Air Force would have anticipated or, for that matter, hoped for. The attitude of the New South Wales police-their being aware of the RAAF board of inquiry-was to save the Mackelmann family from embarrassment, and to make the New South Wales coronial inquiry as quick and as short as possible. No doubt, with good intentions, they offered to conduct the case as a `hand up', which means that a document stating that the late Pilot Officer Craig Mackelmann had been indiscreet would be handed to the coroner. It would then be signed and, in all probability, it would pass unnoticed by the media. Craig's father well understood that to go down the long road would mean discomfort. However, for the sake of clearing his son's name, particularly in the eyes of Craig's colleagues, Captain Mackelmann felt duty bound to reject the easy option.

During cross-examination at the coronial inquest, the now Dr Pinkstone admitted that his evidence to the RAAF inquiry about the blood alcohol level of Pilot Officer Craig Mackelmann at the time of the accident was wrong. Three other doctors gave evidence to this inquest that Craig's blood alcohol level would have been zero. Unfortunately, the time available to me today prevents my going into detail about other factors surrounding this extraordinary case. However, cutting a long story short, there was also expert evidence introduced to prove that there were many severe engineering defects present in A3-40 when it took off on the fatal flight. Justifiably, the coronial inquiry found on 3 February 1988 that, for hours prior to take-off, Craig Mackelmann's blood was free of alcohol. Had Craig's father not had Air Force experience himself, had he not had the determination to fight for the truth, had he not had access to the money to fight the case, the memory of Pilot Officer Craig Mackelmann would have been one of a pilot who had been killed because of the liquor he consumed at a dining-in night. The findings were an about turn by the New South Wales coroner whose public comment, at the very beginning of the inquest he conducted, had obviously been heavily influenced by the preceding RAAF board of inquiry. Such was the impact of the RAAF board of inquiry. One is left to wonder how many findings of other inquiries into accidental deaths inaccurately reflect the true situation. Without the tenacity and perseverance of Captain Mackelmann, this case would have definitely fallen into that category.

Following the findings of the New South Wales coronial inquest, which I have said served to clear Craig's name, Captain Mackelmann made a request of the Air Force. He asked that it reconvene its board of inquiry and take into consideration the expert evidence given to and accepted by the coronial inquiry and reconsider the evidence given to its board of inquiry by the now Dr Pinkstone, whose evidence to that inquiry had been shredded of credibility at the New South Wales coronial inquest. On 19 April 1988 Air Vice-Marshal Radford replied to Captain Mackelmann's reopening request to the effect that `no further investigation is justified'.

I have already expressed appreciation of the actions of the Defence Minister in making the RAAF report available to Captain Mackelmann in December 1986. The following is not so pleasant. To the Defence Minister I now say: you have a responsibility to your late loyal servant to ensure that justice is done and that your Department reconvenes its board of inquiry. For too long Captain Mackelmann has been subjected to rolls of shameful red tape, untruths and obstructions. The Mackelmann family has suffered long enough already and I believe that regardless of the problems for the Air Force justice and decency demand that the Air Force at least add an additional chapter to its report.

The second matter raised by Captain Mackelmann since the clearance of his son was a request for the reimbursement of the costs he incurred in searching for the truth before the coroner. Honourable members will recall my making mention earlier of part of the criteria to be applied if reimbursement of his costs were to be considered. The Attorney-General's Department is now indulging in classical bureaucratic red tape that does it no credit. Out of compassion and a sense of justice for the case, Captain Mackelmann's legal fees were drastically reduced by his firm of solicitors. The cost still amounted to several thousand dollars, sufficient to drive the average citizen from the pursuit of truth. Yet Attorneys-General talk about `the relatively small cost to you of legal representation'. How out of touch they are. It has been proven beyond doubt that Dr Pinkstone gave incorrect advice to the RAAF inquiry and, also beyond doubt, there is a moral obligation on the Commonwealth to reimburse. (Extension of time granted) It would not matter whether Captain Mackelmann was an Airbus captain or a bus driver: in this instance income levels count for nought; it is the principle involved. As far as I can see, the entire nation owes a debt of gratitude to Craig's father for being prepared to fight to the very end to ensure that the Australian bureaucracy, in and out of uniform, had before it another example to show that cover-ups, deliberate or accidental, are simply not acceptable.

There is also a second debt. Craig by his death and his father by his expertise and perseverance have caused most serious questions to be raised regarding the engineering integrity of the Mirage airframe. It could well be that this matter explains the reluctance of the Air Force to reconvene its board of inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second last week in which the House of Representatives will meet in this chamber. Whilst I do not want to indulge in valedictories, I think it is an appropriate time for the House to examine whether the developed processes of this House are adequate to the 1980s and beyond and whether the manner in which we conduct our business is the most appropriate one in which to perform our duties; that is, to represent the people of Australia in the House of Representatives and to make the decisions which must be made on their behalf in the Commonwealth Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The manner in which the business of this House has been conducted has to some degree been tailored by the physical limitations which exist within this building and also by the growing needs of governments to deal with legislation almost to the exclusion of all other matters. There was a time, and I do not reminisce, when in most sessions of the Parliament one could expect that there would be a major economic debate, a major defence debate, a major debate on foreign affairs and other substantive debates on issues of the day. That no longer occurs and has not occurred for at least 15 years. Time is no longer available for the Parliament to debate matters of substance, as opposed to the legislative requirements of the Government. We have degenerated to the stage where a matter of public importance debate gives 50 minutes to the Opposition to raise a matter. There was a time when debates on matters of public importance came on in this chamber very rarely and they were, in fact, on matters of public importance. They now represent the only non-committed debating time available on most sitting days.

It is my belief that we cannot, within our present procedures, conduct the business of this House in a way which reflects our responsibilities and reflects well on the chamber itself. I make not a new suggestion, because I have made it for at least the last 15 years, that this chamber should adopt processes whereby we can conduct our business in plenary and committee sessions. We conduct our business where the major debates which face the nation today and the actual passage of legislation, not necessarily the debating of legislation, take place in the House as a body, but we could utilise the powers that we have to delegate the responsibility to examine the many hundreds of Bills that go through this Parliament which have little more interest to the members of this Parliament and the public than normal machinery regulatory matters, rather than significant policy.

It would be possible, for instance, within the framework of sittings that we have now to conduct both in the chamber and in committees, debates on second readings, Bills, papers and other matters which the House itself determines are of lesser significance than those requiring the whole House; in committees of, say, 30 or 40 members reflecting the membership of the House. Using the three-day sitting pattern, if Wednesdays after Question Time were devoted exclusively to dealing with business in smaller committees, no-one would be able to say that they were not on the air and they were disadvantaged.

If a committee of 30 were used to deal with the Bills on the Notice Paper today, other than those that were of such significance that they justified the full House, there would be no fewer people in the chamber if the quorum was 10. But we could do three times as much business and therefore clear the decks for other days of sitting and clear the decks of most of the time-consuming debate that takes place in this chamber and does not altogether do the House of Representatives any good out in the community.

By moving to that type of system and adopting a process that the committees' reports to the House would be passed without debate unless a resolution to refer them to a committee of the whole for further consideration or some such resolution were passed, we would also be able to list the majority of divisions in this House to take place at a predetermined time because it would be possible, under those circumstances, to list the reports of committees on Bills, one after the other, for vote only in this House. It would free up the chamber then to debate in depth those matters which are of concern in our community, those matters which because of time we rarely debate in this place. When was the last time we had a major debate on a significant issue that went past four or five speakers?

A practice has been adopted for nearly 20 years now in this Parliament when a no-confidence motion is moved, and by that I mean a genuine no confidence motion in the Government-not one that is a debating device which most of them now are, but a genuine no-confidence motion in the Government, such as we saw against Gorton on a rather traumatic Friday back in about 1970. Every member of this chamber should have the opportunity if necessary to participate in such a debate; but certainly the opportunity should exist for a significant number of members of this chamber to participate. But the pressure of business requires that after the third speaker on each side, or the second speaker, the gag will be applied-it is done by agreement in advance-and it may well be that some member on the back bench of either side has a significant point he would like to add to that debate, but the Leader, Deputy Leader and two other front bench spokesmen speak and the day is over.

We do not, as a House of Representatives, provide ourselves with the time and the opportunities. Additional sitting times will not provide those opportunities; only changed practices will. I am suggesting that we are now about to move to a new Parliament House which is built to take us forward into the twenty-first century. The practices which we currently use are no longer capable of coping with the business this House of Representatives has to deal with. It certainly does not reflect the needs of a chamber of 148 members. If we adopt a procedure whereby the major debates take place in the full House and those others matters, which must be dealt with by the Parliament because of the legal requirements for law making, are dealt with in subsidiary committees which report back and are passed ultimately, or rejected by the Parliament, then we give the Parliament an opportunity to perform the functions which are its responsibility and, at the same time, to deal with its legislative and other responsibilities.

I raise this now; I have raised it on many occasions, not always in this chamber. But we are extremely loath, as a group of persons on both sides of the chamber, to attempt any form of change which moves us away from the traditions that lie in the system from which we evolved. All modern parliaments re-examine regularly the way in which they carry out their business, as do other institutions which survive. The opportunity exists because the facilities are built into the new Parliament House for the type of system I advocate. If we continue to do our business with four of us sitting here listening to recurrent debates on second readings of Bills, those facilities may as well be let out for public housing or something else for all the use they are going to be to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will recall that, on 17 March last in the grievance debate, I raised the matter of the relocation of the Soviet Union's Canberra Embassy to a site behind the British, New Zealand and Canadian high commissions. It appears that since I raised this issue the National Capital Development Commission (NCDC) has remained steadfastly committed to ensuring that the Soviets acquire this prime intelligence gathering site. However, of some comfort is the fact that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has now involved itself more seriously in the site selection process. Let us all hope that in the face of such idiocy from the NCDC the Prime Minister's Department is able to introduce some basic commonsense into the resisting process. However, as long as the NCDC maintains its irresponsible position on this matter and until a firm decision is reached, this issue will remain one of very great concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to another issue involving the Soviet Union and Australian national security. I speak of the proposal from the Soviet Union requesting fishing rights, port services and access for Aeroflot charter flights for crew changes. Yesterday, in answer to a question, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to the fact that the Soviet fishing vessels have port access in the United States and Canada. He indicated that these countries had the resources to contain any threat and indicated that Australia, too, had the resources to do so. This is an absolute nonsense. The concerted campaign by Labor to weaken our security and intelligence services has been such a resounding success that we do not have the resources to properly monitor the established Soviet presence already in Australia.

Each of the Soviet naval fleets maintains an intelligence directorate known as an RU. These are responsible for coordinating collection operations by, among other things, fishing vessels. The most innocuous Soviet trawlers are the Okean class, officially designated by the Soviets as survey ships, such as could be used in the proposed surveys off Western Australia and Heard and McDonald Islands, but their true role is intelligence gathering. Other trawlers that perform intelligence tasks are the Mayak class, the Mirnyy class and the new Al'Pinist class.

In all these trawlers the former fish hold has been converted to take electronics and the fact that these vessels are converted trawlers means that at first glance, especially when working in conjunction with a fleet of true Soviet trawlers, they seem to be legitimate fishing vessels. However, intelligence gathering is not just the domain of the specially converted trawlers. Even Soviet trawlers engaged in actual fishing work have an electronics fit that is far beyond their requirements, thus enabling them to play an intelligence role as and when required.

For this reason it is impossible to establish a ratio or percentage of Soviet trawlers which are engaged in intelligence operations at any one time. Furthermore, the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) to my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) on 10 May last concerning Soviet trawlers was either ill-informed or designed intentionally to cloud the issue. He would obviously be aware or at least, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would hope he is aware, of how the Soviets employ their trawlers.

On a regular basis a significant amount of logistic support required by the Soviet Navy in peacetime, especially in distant areas, is provided by merchantmen. This flexibility allows Soviet merchant ships to obtain supplies for naval use in ports where warship visits might be denied. In other words, Soviet warships operating in our region could be resupplied by Soviet trawlers and other Soviet ships which have access to Australian ports, thus increasing the endurance and on-station times for the Soviet Navy. It must be remembered in this context that Soviet trawlers are much larger than most trawlers we see, their smallest measuring 90 metres in length, compared with Australia's largest at 56 metres.

Soviet merchant vessels have often been reported doing very strange things; supposed non-military fishing vessels have been logged sending messages in highly complex codes, far more complex than warranted by a report on fish tonnage caught. In fact, Soviet merchant vessels have been suspected of and even observed transferring espionage agents, military equipment and strategic technology items.

It is important to note that in their proposals the Soviets also requested port access and it is interesting to hear that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), being from the Socialist Left, probably agrees with the Soviet proposal. I do not think most Australians do. If this is approved, it presents a far bigger problem than just allowing the entry of trawlers into Australian waters. Port access means Soviet personnel on the ground in Australia.

In the Age of 30 April this year the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) is reported as denying that a fishing deal would enable Soviet spies to enter Australia. He said, `It is a fairly inefficient way of putting spies into operation'. Clearly the Minister's grasp of Soviet intelligence operations and trade craft is extremely poor. Not only would the Soviets use port access to insert and extract agents; they would use their access for other tasks just as important, tasks such as the servicing of agents already operating in Australia by communicating with them through, for instance, dead letter boxes.

Port access would provide an ideal opportunity for passing on equipment and to facilitate most importantly the onward passage of computer tapes on which the trawlers would have stored signals intelligence and electronic intelligence. These tapes could easily be handed over to Soviet diplomatic and consular staff for immediate return to Moscow through the diplomatic bag or, alternatively, a crew member could carry them out on one of the Aeroflot flights.

If port access also involved the Soviets obtaining a building for offices, et cetera, this would offer the opportunity to instal heavy communications and intelligence gathering equipment that is not able to be used on the trawlers; this is particularly applicable to microwave intercept equipment.

Of all the Soviet proposals the one of the deepest concern has to be the one regarding landing rights for Aeroflot. The Soviets have, and will continue to utilise, the Aeroflot assets for the following direct military and non-military associated purposes: troop lift adjunct to the Soviet air transport command, the VTA; intelligence gathering; communications monitoring; aerial surveying and route development activities useful for future military operations; and finally, transporting clandestine agents for surreptitious operations.

Let there be no doubt, Aeroflot is an adjunct of the Soviet Air Force, and since the 1950s it has been headed by the Soviet Air Force Marshal of Aviation reporting directly to the Soviet leadership. A report I have been apprised of by a Western intelligence service showed that a huge percentage of Aeroflot officials stationed abroad were clearly identifiable as spies, particularly from the GRU, Soviet Military Intelligence. Officials of the United States Defense Department are in no doubt that the Soviet Government uses the assets and designated routes of Aeroflot for general information and specific intelligence gathering.

Periodically, members of Aeroflot foreign ticket agencies and maintenance staff have been arrested for illegal activities, including espionage and attempts to gain access to security information through the use of local nationals. It is not unusual for Aeroflot aircraft to veer `accidentally' off their prescribed flight path to overfly troop movements, naval exercises and other events of interest. Such an accident was reported in the Washington Post of 1 December 1980.

United States officials are adamant that Aeroflot routinely engages in sigint activities at certain locales along their flight paths and in 1977 an Aeroflot flight over the United States was actually observed to have signal intelligence intercept equipment on the aircraft. Western intelligence agencies believe that as well as sigint operations, the use of legitimate Aeroflot operations for the insertion of undercover agents and clandestine forces into the designated target is a tactic repeatedly employed by the Soviets. If Aeroflot is given landing rights in Australia the Soviets will be presented with a golden opportunity to service established agents and to insert new agents brought in with the relief trawler crews.

Yesterday, in answer to a question from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Prime Minister sought to allay the security fears posed by the Soviet proposals by equating our ability to deal with them with that of the United States. He indicated that our ability to deal with the problem was much better than the South Pacific nations who recently flirted with the Soviets over the same sort of deal and were castigated by the Hawke Government for so doing. Surely the fact that the Prime Minister felt it necessary to reassure the Parliament indicates that there is a problem. It is a problem we are better off without. Our region has already been substantially destabilised by a growing Soviet and Libyan presence, with Libyan activity significantly behind the most recent unrest in Vanuatu. The Hawke Government will at least, for once, have truly served the national interest if it says, no, no, no to Soviet fishing rights, port access and to Aeroflot.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to the referendums.

—That is right. Mr Deputy Speaker, in conclusion I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard three diagrams from defence publications, illustrating what I have said about the structure of Soviet intelligence as it relates the use of their trawlers and Aeroflot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Third World debt is a major factor depressing global economic growth. At present developing countries have to pay an average of 25 per cent of their earnings from exports of goods and services in interest payments. This undermines their capacity to import, severely retarding both international trade and, of course, their development. It means that there is a massive leakage of funds from developing debtor countries to the industrialised world and in the last three or four years there has been a net flow of finance from developing countries to the industrialised countries totalling about $30 billion dollars a year, exactly the reverse of what one would want because we ought to be looking for ways of increasing financial resources flowing towards developing countries so that they can invest and grow.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) warned in the December 1987 Economic Outlook that the root problems of Third World debt have become less tractable since 1982. That comment is from a very cautious organisation. In mid-January the World Bank's annual report on Third World debt concluded that, after five years of largely fruitless attempts to defuse the crises, the problem has grown acute and urgent solutions are needed to prevent a breakdown of industrialised developing country relations. At the end of last year the Third World owed $US1,190 billion to external creditors, an increase of over 6 per cent on a year earlier. Such figures are unimaginable, but one way of thinking of it is that it is about four times the total annual national income of Australia. The strain of servicing that debt will increase in 1988, particularly if the slow-down in industrialised countries' economic growth occurs as is predicted. The World Bank report states:
Future progress requires a franker recognition by leaders in the industrialised world of the likely conditions under which solutions will now have to be pursued.
The World Bank goes on to ask rhetorically:

If sound growth cannot resume in the debtor countries while the industrialised countries themselves are growing, what will be the chances for a solution during a recession, particularly one that comes on top of years of weak growth, stubborn unemployment and persistent budget deficits?

The most recent figures that came out of the OECD this week suggested some slight strengthening in the estimated growth rate for the rest of this year. But there is still great uncertainty about what will happen to industrialised countries' growth in 1989 if the incoming United States President seriously addresses the twin problems of the high budget deficit and the high current account deficit. If creditors do not cooperate in reducing debts this year, more debtors will be forced to suspend interest and capital repayments. Henry Kissinger, who is certainly a moderate in these things, said at the meeting of Nobel Laureates in Paris in January that, if the Latin American debt burden is not relieved `within one year, several democracies will be in insoluble difficulties'.

The problem is not confined to Latin America and Africa, which to some people seem remote from Australia. The Philippines and Indonesia are amongst the large debtors. Nor is the confining and destabilising impact limited to debtor and creditor countries. Australia is both directly and indirectly affected, too. Australian banks have relatively small holdings of developing country debt. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd has most because it acquired $1.7 billion of Third World debt when it purchased the British bank, Grindlays. Westpac has $730m of developing country loans, subject to rescheduling; the National Australia Bank, $270m; and the Commonwealth Bank, $30m.

This has required the ANZ and Westpac to increase dramatically their provision for doubtful debts. There was negligible growth in Westpac's profit in 1986-87, for example, after an abnormal transfer of $75m to provision for doubtful debts to help cover the bank's exposure to countries rescheduling their external debt. The indirect consequences are more serious. The prices Australia receives for commodity exports depend in part on the volume of output in other exporting countries. The current low world prices for many commodities are further caused by expanded output by developing debtor countries such as Brazil and Argentina, which are attempting to increase foreign exchange earnings to service their foreign debts.

Australia also shares with the rest of the world both the risk of financial crisis caused by widespread default and the consequences of slower growth of world trade caused by reduced imports of debtor countries. So we have a close interest in reforms to cope with Third World debt and its causes, yet the problem has had very little attention in Australia.

I would like to outline some of the proposals that are around for reform, because they are important to us, as for most of the rest of the world. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid has recently published a book on Australia and the global debt crisis, entitled Life After Debt, of which I was one of the authors. The bank discusses both Third World and Australian debt and the policies Australia might advocate to resolve the crisis. The hesitant efforts at reform since the crisis began in 1982 have not even stopped further deterioration. Policies so far have concentrated on, first, new lending, of which there has been very little; secondly, rescheduling debt servicing by delaying repayments or lowering interest payments-and that is important, but it is simply a coping mechanism and does not really resolve the crisis; and, thirdly, debt conversion, involving exchanging foreign debt for domestic assets such as equities, securities or even conservation measures. That approach does have something to offer and could be more usefully and extensively used.

The Baker plan announced by the United States Secretary of the Treasury in September 1985 was hailed at that time as the most significant initiative since the crisis began. It involved US$30 billion of new commercial bank lending and US$3 billion of multilateral bank lending and the possibility of additional United States funding for the World Bank. So far, only Mexico has benefited from this plan, and then only after heavy pressure from the then head of the United States Federal Reserve Board, Mr Volker, and Mr Baker on the United States commercial banks.

Mexico is always a special case for the United States because the poor can walk across the border. New loans, rescheduling and debt conversion have not solved the crisis. Some debtors have coped by declaring unilateral moratoria on debt service payments, but this will become more general unless new ways are found of reducing the debt burden and reversing the decline in global economic growth. The most promising proposal is for the establishment of an international debt management authority. Senator Sarbanes, Chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, has proposed such an authority and the idea was approved by the House Banking Committee and has been included in the omnibus Trade Bill. The principle behind the debt management authority is to use the financial markets.

At present, Third World debt can be purchased at a discount on its nominal value. Discounts vary, depending on the economic position of each country; some discounts involve selling debt at about 50 to 70 per cent of face value, and that covers countries like Argentina and Brazil. Others sell at up to 90 per cent discounts, for example, Bolivia. The multilateral debt management authority could borrow funds from surplus countries to buy debt at a discount. Already billions of dollars of Third World debt are being traded in Wall Street at a discount on its nominal value. Such a debt management authority could be established under the International Monetary Fund. Substantial funding would be required. A paid-in capital subscription of, say, $US3 billion, plus guarantees totalling $US27 billion, could provide total capital of $30 billion. With a gearing ration of 10 : 1 this would allow the authority to raise $US300 billion from the international financial markets, plus selling bonds, mainly no doubt to current account surplus countries.

If debts were purchased at an average discount on their nominal value of 30 per cent, then $400 billion or $500 billion of Third World debt could be restructured over a number of years. Australia could have an important role in resolving the debt crisis. We have the financial expertise and representatives at the international banks. Our leadership of the Cairns Group shows the role that we can take, yet so far we have not played a significant part.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, yesterday morning I picked up the Sydney Morning Herald and saw a heading `Roads Funding Slashed by 10 per cent'. When I saw that I thought that there must be something wrong, that cannot possibly be right, someone has made a mistake. On reading further publications I have found that the Cabinet Expenditure Review Committee of the present Government has decided that it is going to cut another $50m or 10 per cent off road funding. It is hardly believable. Could honourable members believe that?

SPEECH.PARA: Over the last four years this Government has cut somewhere between 30 and 40 per cent off road expenditure. When I saw the first article I was dumbfounded, I thought it could not be right, but when I saw the other articles my disbelief turned to anger, and my anger since has turned to dismay because now I am convinced that that is what the Government is about, to cut another $50m off road funding. Everyone in this House surely knows the importance of infrastructure in this nation. I, because I am the member for Riverina-Darling, will talk mainly about my electorate, but I can imagine what my city cousins will be thinking because they have similar problems.

We know what the last New South Wales Labor Government did when it cut the expenditure on expressways and freeways, what turmoil it caused in Sydney, what it did to the Department of Main Roads (DMR), that great organisation that had such a high morale because it was doing something for the State. The last New South Wales Labor Government, of course, decimated that great organisation. But I am going to concern myself mainly with what is happening in my electorate. We all know, of course, that the rural and mining sectors produce at least 60 per cent of Australia's overseas earnings. In the last few months, with the increased price of wool, that has gone up to nearly 80 per cent and here we have a government that is cutting expenditure on roads. I still cannot believe it.

We have to get wool to the markets and we know that the price of wool today has really saved this nation. Once again we are riding on the sheep's back. I have seen wool bales scattered across the road because the trucks cannot get around the curves due to the gravel, the dust or the mud. The price of beef, of course, is very important and it is rising. It has had some ups and downs.

Recently south of Ivanhoe on the Ivanhoe road a road train was bogged along with a tourist bus. They could not go anywhere because of a few points of rain and this of course is all adding to the cost of getting our exports to the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't use their cars because of the state of the roads.

—That is right. The whole thing seems to me to be a nonsense. We have got cotton in the Hillston area. We are trying to develop a cotton industry there. The road from Hillston to Cobar which the harvesters would have to use in order to harvest that cotton is an absolute disgrace, and then to get the cotton back to the cotton gin there are those added costs.

SPEECH.PARA: As to wheat, the New South Wales Government is closing down some of the railway spur lines. If the Commonwealth Government continues to cut this expenditure on roads, there is no way those lines can be closed because the roads are going to become even worse than they are today. So our markets are affected by the cut of expenditure on roads. But what about the safety aspect? People in Australia worry about their loved ones and their close ones and their friends when they go out onto the Australian road system. Certainly we must say that the road system, despite cutbacks by the Government, has improved slightly over the years because of works. I am talking about New South Wales works by the DMR.

I know about it from personal experience; my son has to travel 55 kilometres every day between Griffith and Leeton on a road whose edges are broken down; it is bumpy and it has potholes. It is not the fault of the councils concerned, but the fault of the governments who will not realise the importance of roads. My wife yesterday was driving from Canberra to Broken Hill. I was concerned about her because it was raining. She was travelling on a bitumen road but I know that the Kelly Creek bridge, just a few kilometres south of Broken Hill, when the rain comes can be washed away. Anyone who gets into that creek is going to find himself in great difficulty. The same thing happens right throughout Australia. Travelling on the Mossgiel Road, for example, it takes only a few points of rain and one is bogged. As to the Rankin Springs to Lake Cargellico road, even the ambulance has to take a different route because it cannot get down that road. For school buses in the summer the dust is a tremendous hazard.

So we need expenditure on roads, not only because of our markets, but also because of the safety aspect and because of the communication needs of our people in outback areas. Okay, so the Government says that we have to cut back on expenditure. Where is all this money going? I know the Government has problems because it will not take the hard decisions in economics, but what about the money it is expending? Let us have a look at our Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) who recently came back from the African continent. What has he done? He promised $6m to the Marxist Government of Mozambique on top of the amount already promised which is $9.5m and then $100m over three years to the front line states of Africa. I do not think these Marxist states have a reputation for saving lives. If this money were expended on road systems in Australia it would certainly save many lives and of course would help our economy.

I do not mind if the Foreign Minister sends off a donation to these groups in Africa. Like most socialist governments, of course, it is good at spending other people's money, but the money would be better spent here in Australia, if not on the road system. I saw earlier the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) sitting at the table. He and the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) are very concerned about the Aboriginal population. I would rather see that money spent here, provided it was administered properly and spent in the correct manner. But we are talking about road systems now.

Why should we be expending money in those parts of the world on Marxist regimes for who-knows-what purpose when that money could be better spent here? I am not one who is against overseas aid for developing countries, particularly in our own region, in the Pacific region. I think it is money well spent, but I do draw the line at expenditure that Minister Hayden promoted instead of spending it here in our own nation.

Over recent months, I should imagine most members of this House would have had their local councils call them in to speak to them about the cutbacks in road expenditure and they are very concerned about them. About two weeks ago I was called by the Leeton Shire Council to be told how it was finding it extremely difficult. There was no way, it believed, that it could carry on the present works unless the Federal Government did something about road expenditure. Then along come the referendum proposals and we are told that this Government is concerned for local government. One of the questions is: `Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government?'. Proposed section 119a in the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill states:

Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State and empowered to administer, and to make by-laws for, their respective areas in accordance with the laws of the State.

Now, what is new about that? It is a farce that it takes $6m to put that into a referendum and another $30m for the referendum. The road between Ivanhoe and Hay, with the expenditure first promised, would have taken 30 years to seal. With this going on, with expenditure on things like this and the money the Government is talking about cutting back, it will take 60 years. There is no-one in this House of parliament who will see that road sealed, and I would say there is no-one in Ivanhoe who will see it sealed either.

So this referendum nonsense, which promises nothing to local government, is a farce and we can see now what this Government really thinks of local government. The way it is treating local government and the people of Australia is absolutely disgraceful-particularly outback Australia. I know that this Government does have problems. There are areas that it finds a bit difficult to touch. It believes that rather than taking the hard options it will take the soft options. Once again it will get stuck into the people in the bush and no doubt, of course, some people in the major areas will be affected.

I am saying to the Federal Government today that we are going to have major problems in the future, particularly as our oil supplies run out. The taxation that is coming from there will not be available, and also the Government will have to find the money to get this oil from other sources unless it does something and takes some hard decisions now in promoting the search for oil. Unless we get our infrastructure into place now, the way that we should get it, instead of spending this money on ideological mysteries overseas, we are in for real trouble. I say to the Government: for heaven's sake, think about our own economy but, most importantly, please think about the safety of our loved ones as they take to the roads which are fast falling apart and becoming a real disgrace to this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, in the weeks leading up to the Premiers Conference I, along with my Senate colleague Bob Collins, made representations to the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about funding for the Northern Territory. We did that in conjunction with the Northern Territory Government, a conservative government, and the Northern Territory Labor Opposition. We did that because we believed that the arguments put up by the Northern Territory Government about recommendations made by the Grants Commission were appropriate and, indeed, correct.

SPEECH.PARA: I am happy to say that the Treasurer was able to accept the arguments that were put forward and they demonstrated a concern on my behalf-and that of my Senate colleague Senator Collins-to adopt a bipartisan approach to the question of funding for the Northern Territory Government. However, I am somewhat concerned at the way in which the Northern Territory Government administers its internal affairs and the way in which it administers the public purse which is so graciously given to it by the Federal Government and made available to it by courtesy of the Commonwealth taxpayers.

I refer to some decisions made in the education area by the Northern Territory Government in which it has essentially diverted money from the public purse, and consequently undermined public sector education, and delivered that money into the hands of private enterprise. That is not new. These sorts of decisions are not new to the Northern Territory Government. It has had a history of making those sorts of decisions since self-government in 1978, and it wonders why the Northern Territory population-the Northern Territory electorate-is becoming increasingly disenchanted with it and the way in which it administers the Territory's affairs.

Last year, as an example, the Northern Territory Government chose to spend $6.5m on the Northern Territory University College, money which was needlessly spent because the Commonwealth had suggested to the Northern Territory Government that, should it accept a proposal that the Commonwealth was prepared to discuss with it, that money would not need to be spent by the Northern Territory Government; that it would be able to get a tertiary institution established on the campus of the Darwin Institute of Technology.

However, the Northern Territory Government, in its own wisdom, decided to go the other way, and as a result spent $6.5m of taxpayers' money, given to the Northern Territory by the Commonwealth in its general revenue grants. It spent that money on this university.

At the same time, it slashed expenditure on general education by $6.5m. So the balance it achieved was to prop up an idiot idea at the expense of the public sector education. Let me just give a few examples of what those cuts in public sector education meant: firstly, the community education centres program was shelved, at a saving of some $800,000. This community centres education program is very important because it is designed-and it is a very well thought-out program, I believe-to provide post-primary education to Aboriginal students in Aboriginal communities.

We ought to understand that in a lot of areas in the Northern Territory, in remote communities, there are no secondary education provisions. In fact, in the area of Urapunga, to the north-east of Alice Springs, there are some 900 people who live in a widely dispersed area, none of whom has access to post-primary education facilities in the region. That is not the only area where the Government has cut funds; not only has it not expended money on the provision of post-primary facilities in remote communities, but it has undermined the existing infrastructure of the education system. For example, it refused to provide housing for local recruits.

Aboriginal teachers are not provided with housing in their own communities; some live in car bodies and some in humpies. There are teachers who successfully complete courses offered by the very well-credentialled Batchelor College and who return to their home communities to find that there is no provision for housing for them. There has been a failure to expand the bilingual education program. Cuts last year were made to equipment and to the provision of literacy supervisors and their positions. In one community I visited with a bilingual program, with a very committed school and a very committed teacher in charge of that program, there was not even a photocopier to reproduce the bilingual education material that is so essential for the delivery of that program.

The numbers of school counsellors were cut in high schools. The Northern Territory Government introduced new staffing level formulas which incorporated librarians and counsellors into the staffing ratio and which has meant, consequently, fewer teachers in the school rooms. Curriculum services to schools were reduced. All this was done so that the Northern Territory Government could go ahead with its highfalutin scheme for the provision of a university college which, incidentally, will almost inevitably be amalgamated with the Darwin Institute of Technology, to which I referred previously.

This coming year we have something even more horrendous. The Northern Territory Government has, in its wisdom, decided to provide $8.7m over six years for funds for a Darwin international grammar school. It has been set up by a private business consortium, including overseas business interests, under the company name of Education Holdings. Local students will pay fees believed to be in the range of $5,000 to $6,000 with overseas students, mainly from South East Asia, to pay more. The school will offer the international baccalaureate diploma which, it is claimed, will give successful graduates entrance to more than 200 universities around the world. That is all very well and good, but why should the taxpayers of the Northern Territory have their money used to subsidise this operation when the Northern Territory Government has failed to live up to its obligations in the provision of public sector education elsewhere in the Territory, and particularly to those people living in remote communities?

I might say that, true to form, the Northern Territory Government, whenever critics raise their heads and have the temerity to object to the way in which it administers its affairs and spends the public purse, makes puerile, senseless and baseless attacks on the integrity of those people. It uses the forum of the Legislative Assembly in the Northern Territory, inevitably during Question Time, to attack those people. In particular, it has made these attacks on teachers and principally the executive members of the Northern Territory Teachers Federation.

Far be it for me to waste my time and to waste the time of the House to state things honourable members must inevitably already know; that is that the Northern Territory Government lacks a sense of responsibility, is not prepared to accept open criticism or creative suggestions about the way in which it might administer the social justice programs which it has a responsibility for administering, including education. It would rather spend its money supporting these programs which, incidentally, will cost $8.7m, or $1.5m per year from next year onwards for six years.

It has been estimated by the shadow Minister for Education in the Northern Territory, Brian Ede, that the Government will pay the international grammar school $22,000 for each Territory student it enrols in the first year. Mr Ede says that the payment is over and above the standard subsidy of $1,100 and whatever fees the school charges. I want to make it very clear that I have no objection to these private schools, provided they meet the criteria for funding by government but we have here a situation where these people have been given an extraordinary impetus, extraordinary support by the Northern Territory Government on the false assumption that it is saving the Northern Territory taxpayers' money and increasing the standard of educational services delivered in the Northern Territory. As I have said, that is simply not the case. What it has set about doing is undermining the Northern Territory public sector education system. It has attacked those teachers who have had the temerity to object to the way in which it is administered. It has attacked the parents who have dared, in the past, to criticise the Northern Territory Government and inevitably it goes to its friends in the private sector for support.

As I have said, Mr Deputy Speaker, since 1978 when the Northern Territory Government achieved self-government, its administration has been typified by these rortish attempts at diverting money from the public purse to the private sector. It is well known in the forums of this Government. The previous member for the Northern Territory was a past master at it in his position of Chief Minister. The present Chief Minister does not seem to have changed his cloak. Unfortunately, Mr Deputy Speaker, while my colleague Senator Collins and I are more than happy to represent the appropriate interest of the Northern Territory Government when it comes to making representations to Canberra, it makes it incredibly difficult to substantiate those requests when we see the scandalous ways in which the Northern Territory Treasury is administered and the way in which it undermines the social services it ought to be providing to the whole of the Northern Territory community and not just propping up its friends in private enterprise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is good to see in the House my two colleagues from Tasmania, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) and the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr), and it will be of no surprise to them that I grieve again today on petrol prices in Australia. I will go back in history a bit. In my second speech in this House, the one after my maiden speech, in 1976 I spoke on the petroleum industry and the Royal Commission on Petroleum by Mr Justice Collins. Some of its recommendations were never brought into being. It said that the industry cried out for reform; that it was an industry that was prostituted; that there were unfair practices; that the people who worked in the industry, specifically the dealers, were sometimes treated unfairly; that we should look for alternatives; and that we should look more at converting to liquefied petroleum gas.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an industry that is ever changing, so of course some of those points in 1976 are not relevant today. But if one hops into a motor car in Canberra and drives down to Melbourne, when one gets to the border at Albury-Wodonga one will find invariably that the price of petrol will increase by 10c per litre. I can understand the motorists of Australia looking at the price of petrol and wondering why. I have been critical of the Prices Surveillance Authority, because I thought that it was not able to fix a maximum wholesale price that was justified in the true sense of the word, making it fair for all Australians.

I will keep my remarks brief to give the next honourable member a go. I know that he is keen to get on his feet; he is smiling now, of course. The previous Government, the Fraser Government, went to import parity pricing and the price of petrol increased quite dramatically in Australia. That caused great pressure on people who use petrol for their mode of business. It increased transportation costs and the consumers of Australia had to bear that penalty, the reason being that there were world shortages and if we did not have petroleum we had to depend on other countries for our petrol.

In the long term, that was a sensible move even though people like me rejected it at the time because I thought it was too severe, all of a sudden to go from a cheap price to a very high price. But we saw that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when he was in Opposition, continually said that it was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump, that the people of Australia were in virtual fact being conned as a result. He said that they were paying the penalty for government decisions and that it was taxation by stealth at the petrol pump. We heard it consistently during those election campaigns. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with his now famous remark, said that if he were elected he would reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre. And of course the consumers of Australia thought, `Well, great, it is going to be cheaper, it is going to be better for us and we will take it'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it happen?

—No, it did not, and when the Labor Government came to power, like many other governments, it found that it is a very good way to get revenue. It is a very simple way, it is a very painless process in getting money from the pockets of the consumers of Australia in a very simple way; once the hue and cry die down it is forgotten. The Prices Surveillance Authority stated in its annual report for 1986-87, `With the exception of petroleum products, which reflect particularly complex pricing arrangements, price increases were not generally sought by declared persons more than three times in the year'.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say that for petroleum products the Authority received 218 notices of proposed price changes, so in fact I agree that it is a very complex industry. But if the Prices Surveillance Authority-and this is what the consumers of Australia keep looking at-fixes a maximum wholesale price in every capital city, it does not vary very much. Then all of a sudden, with the whim and fancy of what the oil companies want to do, we find that petrol in some particular parts of Australia-mainly in the heavy volume areas-is sold below that wholesale price. So the consumer starts saying, `What gives? We are paying taxes to have an authority to fix a maximum wholesale price, then all of a sudden we see it being sold at a far cheaper price'. I can understand their concern and I can understand that they would feel that governments have failed as a result of it, not being able to contain this complex industry, not being able to harness it for the best interests of all Australians.

All right, I have talked about it ad infinitum. The trouble is that the more we talk about a subject, the more helpless we are to change an industry, because we all know that the power is given only to a very few who can really make those changes.

I would like to make a few suggestions, in my last speech, most probably, in this House. My first one was on the petroleum industry. It cried out for reform then, it needed changes to it; governments have failed to change it, to make it more equitable for all the people involved in the industry, the consumers and everybody else involved. But we find we are no better off, that we go from State to State. It varies from State to State, for reasons. It could be argued that my own State has the highest price for petrol in Australia. It could be argued that Mr Robin Gray, the Premier, said that he had to impose an additional 3.7c to offset a shortage of funds by this Federal Government. Frankly, the consumers of Australia are sick of these arguments and one can ask the question: How long is that 3.7c going to stay-ad infinitum?

We heard somebody talking about the roads of Australia. We have the 2c a litre levy that is supposed to have been directed to the roads. We have the royal automobile clubs of Australia saying, `Look, not enough money is being spent on the roads and the motorists are being ripped off'. The whole thing needs a good clean up. The Prices Surveillance Authority cannot do it; royal commissions cannot do it. This is one recommendation that I would like to make. A lot of us come up here with all the best intentions in the world to try to reform, to try to do the best we can for the consumers. We will differ, but surely to God we can harness a few from this Parliament to go out and do a good inquiry into this industry, if we are serious, and come back with decent respectable recommendations, to make this a better industry, not only for the people who work in it, but also for the consumers of Australia, and make it fairer and more equitable.

Surely we could do that. Surely we could start talking about alternatives. We could start saying that we should be using more liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in this country, not exporting it to Japan so that they can do their cooking with it. We could use it in Australia. We could start talking about the manufacture of motor cars, with not just a single system of petrol but also the dual system of LPG. We could also start saying that if a person wanted to convert to LPG he could get a tax reduction. We could start talking about these sorts of things and, hopefully, we could make it a better industry for everybody. We could get away from the ludicrous situation that in Melbourne up to yesterday there had been seven increases. We can also get away from the ludicrous situation that in Sydney the price went down to 43c a litre but overnight went back to 59c a litre. We could stop those sorts of things, make it fairer for the people in the country and the people who live in Hobart, Sydney, Melbourne or wherever, and also the people who work within the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find that I am in agreement with the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) when he expresses his concern about the price of fuel. But I would also remind the honourable member that when the Fraser Government came into power the wholesale price of fuel was 13c or thereabouts; when the Fraser Government left government it was 38c wholesale, and now we see an increase of about 12c. Twice the increase took place under the Fraser Government. But he is right in his concern and my areas have the same gripe.

SPEECH.PARA: In the four minutes that I have left, I should like to raise a matter that relates to road funding. I join with other colleagues who have spoken in this House in recent times because I express grave concern at any reduction that might take place in the Commonwealth funding for roads across this nation. It needs to be pointed out that a reduction of just $1m in road expenditure can lead to a loss of 55 jobs. That is 23 in the construction industry, nine in the supply industry, and 23 as a result of consumer spending; that is the multiplier effect. There is not a great saving for Government to cut down on that $1m, because the actual Budget saving is only about $380,000, when you take into consideration the income tax forgone and the additional unemployment benefits the Government will have to pay.

There is a need for government to maintain its responsibility and commitment to road funding right across this nation. I talk about local government, State government and Federal government because too often we have the States blaming the Commonwealth when there is a cutback. They say, `We cannot give you the money because the Commonwealth did not give it to us'. That has happened in Labor as well as non-Labor States. Seventy-five per cent of Federal road funding is spent in rural Australia, and I represent a provincial and rural electorate.

This money provides a significant economic boost to local, residential and regional economies. I talk about the local aspect here. A cut of $100m will mean a loss of some 2,400 road jobs in the rural sector. You can add to that 1,725 likely to be eliminated in the longer term as the decrease in consumption spending works its way through the local economy.

We are talking about economics. I am concerned about a report that I am told has been put out by the Department of Finance which recommends a major cut in road funding. I can understand people saying that the national highways are almost completed; we do not need the capital up-front outlays. But that is not an excuse to cut back on local and arterial roads. There is a real argument for maintaining funding to local authorities and the States in real terms. There is a real argument for increasing that percentage of the excise on fuel-about 21c per litre-from the 5.4 or 6c per litre to at least 7c. Every 1c per litre means an extra $200m that can be spent on roads. It means jobs, an injection of funds into local economies.

There is a need to understand also that road fatalities are costing this nation $3 billion a year. If the rumour is correct that we are going to have a major cutback, not only the major metropolitan areas will suffer, but also provincial cities, local towns right across the nation. I see this as an apolitical issue, one that is non-factional. It cuts across all parties because it is an Australian issue. I believe we have a responsibility to ensure that road funding increases and not just as it did last year at $1,245m, but increases in real terms so that we can get on with our upgrading works.

We have provided millions and millions of dollars for road construction work over many years. The Hawke Labor Government can be commended for the massive injection of funds that it put into road funding during the 1983-84 period. Regrettably, there is a decline since that time. It is an issue that crosses all the factional areas. It is an issue that crosses all the party areas. I would urge that in this May statement full consideration is given to the needs for roads across this nation-for local roads, for arterial roads, for those in the metropolitan areas. If we do not do this, there will be economic consequences, social consequences and, I would suggest, political consequences.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Prices-Dried Fruits Industry-Herbert Electorate-Proposed Canberra Casino-Vietnamese Women's Association of Queensland-Chile-Bicentennial Medallions-Dr Germeet Anand-Farm Workers-Tasmania-Christian Gathering

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some 12 months ago I helped form the southern prices action group which has been working most effectively in seeking to curtail rising supermarket prices. The success of our group is due to the commitment and dedication of a small band of volunteer shoppers who once a month conduct a regular prices survey. Supermarkets in our area are becoming more competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall price of a standard basket of groceries remained stable during the months of February and March and the April results indicate an actual price drop. What is also happening is that more and more people are phoning our office with consumer complaints. For example, a woman recently phoned to tell us that for some time now she had been buying a particular brand of oat bran from the local health food store. A 500-gram packet used to cost her 89c. Then a couple of weeks ago the price jumped from 89c to $3.12.

The irate customer phoned the supplier, Selective Foods Pty Ltd of Waterloo, Sydney, who informed her that this was in fact the new price. The customer says that the brand she buys is being publicised by a visiting American as part of a low cholesterol diet and that this is the reason the stores and suppliers are cashing in.
