TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, I call questions without notice.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that the Government is putting forward the first referendum proposal on the basis that it will have no impact on the term of office of the current Government? If so, is it not a fact that under the existing Constitution the last practical date on which the next half-Senate and the current House of Representatives elections can be held is 2 June 1990? Is it not also a fact that if the first referendum is carried the last practicable date for the next Senate and House of Representatives elections will be extended to 17 November 1990? Does the Prime Minister therefore deny that a practical consequence of this would be to enable his Government to stay in office almost six months longer than is now provided for under current constitutional arrangements?

—I point out to the honourable gentleman that the legislation involves an extension of the term of the Senate so that if the people-as I hope and expect they will-vote to extend parliamentary terms to four years we would avoid the necessity of a half-Senate election and we would subsequently get contemporaneity of elections for the two Houses. The dates the honourable gentleman mentioned are accurate. To the extent that the issue has any significance, I assume it will be taken into account by the electorate when it has to make its decision. I am confident that the decision as to which party it wants to govern it will be, on the fourth occasion since 5 March 1983, the same as it has been on the last three occasions.

—Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware of an editorial in the Melbourne Herald which claimed that child-care was one of the neglected issues of Australian politics in the 1980s? Can the Minister inform the House of the Government's record on child-care?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of what is a sadly ill informed and incorrect editorial in yesterday's Herald which was headlined `Toying with child-care'. One can only believe that the writer of the editorial had been a Rip van Winkle since 1983. There is one small glimmer of accuracy in this otherwise quite ignorant article. It does state:

ANSWER.PARA: It was buried as a policy priority under the weight of economic crisis and ideological opposition during the Fraser years.
That is a pretty accurate statement. This single glimmer of accuracy is immediately snuffed out by the editorial's next statement:
The issue has continued to languish since then, a low priority in a time of . . . uncertainty.

I want to look at the facts which sustain an argument that under this Government child-care has languished. Let us look at each of the facts in turn. Firstly, since 1973-74 about $1 billion has been spent in this country on child-care and 85 per cent of that-$853m-has been spent by the Hawke Labor Government. So in the last 15 years, $1 billion has been spent on child-care, 85 per cent of it by this Government. Is that any evidence of languishing? Since 1983 we have increased spending on child-care from $62m a year to $222m this year. That increase in five years, again, provides no evidence that child-care has languished. The number of child-care places was 46,000 when we came to power. By the end of this year the number will be close to 110,000. Indeed, more has been done for child-care by this Government than by all of the other governments in Australia put together.

The editorial goes on to claim that the Government has shown a lack of understanding of families where both parents have to work to survive. That claim that we lack understanding is absolute nonsense. In July 1984 we introduced the fee relief subsidy to ensure that services were affordable to low and middle income families. Extra deductions were provided under that subsidy for people with more than one child in care. We are very well aware-contrary to what is said in the Herald editorial-of the economics of child-care. Some 80 per cent of sole parents working or seeking work in this country have their children in government funded child-care centres. The preliminary results of a study by the Centre for Economic Policy Research at the Australian National University shows that the fiscal benefits from the provision of work-related child-care are significant.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not like this, of course. As that survey points out, the expenditure saved could outdo the cost of child-care-that is, the economic advantages deriving may offset all that we spend on child-care.

ANSWER.PARA: There are two equally significant benefits for the labour market: the participation of women in the labour force has increased from 45 per cent in 1983 to 50 per cent in 1988; and over 478,000 new jobs were filled by women and girls between April 1983 and August 1987-nearly 58 per cent of all the new jobs created to this point. Again, child-care has gone a long way to make that expansion possible. The editorial in the Herald did get a few points right. It pointed out that it is cheaper for the community to subsidies comprehensive child-care than to bear the cost of welfare payments to families on single incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat the point for the benefit of honourable members opposite: it is cheaper for the community to subsidise comprehensive child-care than to bear the cost of welfare payments to families on single incomes. It is also economically unsound to tie talented women to the home due to a lack of child-care. The editorial also recognises that child-care is more than a welfare issue.
—These people have no notion that child-care is more than a welfare issue.
—Order! The Minister should draw his answer to a close.

—I am drawing my answer to a conclusion. It is obvious that the Opposition does not understand the point that child-care is more than just a welfare issue. It is a matter of equity and social justice and has made this Government the child-care government in Australian history.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Now that the Prime Minister has confirmed that one consequence of the carriage of the first referendum proposal would be potentially to prolong the life of the Hawke Government by almost six months, I ask: Was this an unintended consequence? Why has the referendum proposal been presented on the basis that it would be politically neutral in its impact? How does the Minister justify not disclosing to the Australian public the potential conferment of a clear political advantage, and why has he not come clean about a conspiracy to keep the Government in office for another six months?

—The question from the Leader of the Opposition is extraordinary because he would have at least studied the matter. The only issue that really related to the fact was that the half-Senate term may expire before the House of Representatives.
—Another six months.

—Will the Leader of the Opposition listen to the answer? The Bill the House is now talking about is to extend the term of the Senate until the expiry of the House of Representatives; it is very simple. The House of Representatives is limited by the Constitution in its power to continue its term, which is three years after the date of the first sitting. The Government is not extending it.
—You are extending it for another six months.
—Why does the Leader of the Opposition not understand the law? It is an incredible situation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the distinguished and effervescent Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business: What is the significance of work carried out by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the University of Adelaide to reduce the severity of disease and accident trauma for patients? What community benefit will arise from the research and what are its commercial prospects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie for his question.
—What about a short answer?

—As it happens, the answer is very important. A team led by Dr John Ballard of the Division of Human Nutrition of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, in collaboration with the University of Adelaide, has discovered a high potency muscle growth protein with great potential in the treatment of burns, cancer and trauma victims and diseases involving muscle wasting such as acquired immune deficiency syndrome-AIDS. These illnesses currently cost some $2 billion in health care in Australia and 50 times that amount worldwide. Loss of muscle is a major contributing factor towards death and incapacitation, and it involves cancer and physical trauma particularly with road accident victims. Muscle loss also plays a central part in the long term wasting of certain inherited diseases, including muscular dystrophy and cystic fibrosis.

ANSWER.PARA: Escalating health costs are a serious problem for the community. Finding hospital beds for patients undergoing courses of treatment and subsequent recovery periods is placing enormous pressure on our already overworked hospital system. The researchers have isolated the growth protein from cows' colostrum-a fluid that is produced at the beginning of lactation. It has an identical component in humans. The insulin-like growth factors also play a significant role in animal production, increasing growth rates and probably the efficiency at which food is converted to meat. Growth proteins, produced by a range of cells, act on other cell types to stimulate their growth. The research team has discovered a growth protein that is super potent, being active at one tenth of the level required for other growth proteins.

This protein, known as `insulin-like growth factor one', would not be a cure for illnesses, but it has potential to prevent muscle loss and wastage, thereby making the body stronger. The patient would then be better able to withstand infection. Recovery following curative treatment programs, or accidents, especially of elderly people, might also be speeded up. The research team has taken out the first international patent in this important developing area and presently are negotiating for its commercialisation internationally and I hope to be in a position to announce something further shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training been drawn to an article on the front page of this afternoon's Melbourne Herald newspaper entitled `Politics Decides Where Cuts Hit'? Is the Minister aware that the article refers to internal working papers obtained from his Department that show officers of his Department have assessed the political allegiance of electorates as a major factor in deciding the future funding in Victoria of community youth support schemes (CYSS)? Is the Minister further aware that the article states that, of the 17 CYSS projects to be eliminated, 12 are in rural Liberal and National Party seats and that schemes in mainly urban marginal Labor electorates are largely exempt from the cuts? Is this newspaper report correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a fascinating question, coming from the Party that tried to abolish this scheme a few years ago. It is especially intriguing bearing in mind that, when the Australian Labor Party came to office under the distinguished ministry of my colleague the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Government expanded the community youth support scheme by approximately 50 per cent because it recognised the important role that the scheme plays in providing support for young unemployed people. Therefore, the Government continues its commitment to the scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of making some inquiries after this article appeared, I understand that the paper referred to is a handwritten set of notes and that it has no official status, makes no recommendations and has not been submitted for consideration by departmental management let alone the Minister for Employment and Education Services. The Department is not under any direction to consider political issues in relation to these matters. No decisions on budgetary matters have been made about the continuation or otherwise of projects under the new program.

Last September the Government decided that the community youth support scheme, the community training program and the community volunteer program should be integrated into a single program under new guidelines. The existing three programs will continue until the end of December, and the new program will commence on 1 January 1989. Without prejudice, all existing project sponsors, as well as others, will be invited to submit applications for funding under the program's new guidelines.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question I direct to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel concerns the commercialisation of the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO). The Minister has said that she wants every reasonable opportunity taken to translate the research of the Organisation into marketable products for Australian industry. What programs has the Minister implemented to achieve her goal of commercialising DSTO products and what success are her programs having?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Port Adelaide for his question. It is probably the first question that has ever been directed on the Defence Science and Technology Organisation in this Parliament. That says a great deal about the history of the organisation, which has done an enormous amount of good for the Defence Force of this country but has made very little contribution to Australian industry; it is time that that changed.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the first things I have done is to change the charter of the DSTO so that it can now work with any sector of Australian industry where that is in the broader national interest. As part of this interface, we need to ensure that industry is aware of commercially promising DSTO research at a very early stage. I have had to throw open the doors of the organisation. Recently I issued a corporate statement, which I forwarded to the Opposition spokesman, and the Government is also releasing specific booklets that explain what the organisation does. I bet if honourable members in this place were now asked what role the organisation had actually played, very few would have any idea of what it does, nor of its cost, which is approximately $170m a year.

The DSTO is a world leader in many technologies but unfortunately it has done very little to take up that opportunity and to commercialise it. Currently the organisation is working on a number of projects, in which my colleague the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business would be interested, and in future I may adopt his practice of bringing in here with me things to demonstrate to the Parliament. But I will not do that today.

Suffice it to say that at the moment it is developing an energy efficient laser which could be used in hospitals, an anti-corrosion process-that could do very well in this House-and a diamond hard coating for use in optical devices. Also I am organising in Melbourne next month an industry seminar which I hope will inform industry further about the role the DSTO is taking.

Already there are signs that commercialisation is working. An agreement has been signed to allow the company, Australian Commercial Research and Development, to fund selected research projects with commercial potential within DSTO. Further agreements have also been signed, or are being negotiated, with State innovation centres and Sirotech Pty Ltd. In addition, I recently announced that the DSTO will participate with industry in a joint venture company, and that company is being established to commercialise the infra-red detector technology developed at DSTO, Salisbury. This venture will allow us to tap into the billion dollar international infra-red detector market.

I summarise by saying to the House that the commercialisation of the DSTO is under way. We still have a long way to go, but I think we can look forward to much greater cooperation between the Defence Science and Technology Organisation and industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The Minister will be aware that a senior Japanese Government member of parliament and former Defence Minister, Mr Kato, has publicly admitted in the United States of America that his Government does discriminate against Australian beef in favour of United States beef, that `administrative guidance is given to treat United States beef imports favourably', that the Japanese Government body, the LIPC, pockets $400m to $500m a year from levies on imported beef, and that Japan and the United States are moving towards a bilateral deal to increase United States beef imports. In the light of this revelation, does the Minister agree that he and other Ministers have been duped by the Japanese and United States governments into believing that there is no discrimination against Australia at the moment; nor will there be any? What action will he now take to ensure, even at this late stage, that Australian beef producers and exporters receive a fair deal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, we have not been duped. If the honourable gentleman had been in contact with the industry he would have realised that, at every step in the current negotiations, in the intervening period and the last time quotas were established, we have been pointing out exactly what has now been confessed by Japan, and that is that the arrangements that have been in place for some time discriminate against Australia vis-a-vis the United States. A study by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics in great detail last year-I hope that the honourable gentleman has read it-set out very clearly where the discrimination was, how much the LIPC was creaming off from the trade, which was billions and billions of yen, and just exactly where the problems lay. It gave an effective rate of tariff against Australia considerably higher than that pertaining to the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: There is not much sense in going into detail; but, when beef that is diaphragm beef and is said by the Japanese not to be beef somehow gets sold as beef, that has always been pretty open to anyone who really wants to use his or her eyes. There is a system called single buyer to seller, which is somewhat self-explanatory. That system has an inbuilt incentive for people to buy higher valued grades of meat. The whole administration by the LIPC of the present quota arrangements discriminates against Australia in terms of tonnages. In other words, the quotas are not truly global; there is administrative guidance.

We welcome this statement by Mr Koichi Kato, because it simply confirms what we have been saying for a very long time. The assurances that the Prime Minister, the Minister for Trade Negotiations and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and I have gained in recent times are prospective. We believe that the people with whom we are dealing in both the United States and Japan are people of honour and that prospectively we will not be discriminated against, and this confession helps us immensely.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of statements by representatives of the National Farmers Federation that they have been trying to create an industrial dispute on the waterfront, but have been unable to do so? Can the Minister advise the House why the National Farmers Federation is having this problem, and what action the Government is taking to improve industrial relations and productivity on the waterfront?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--

—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order relates to the second part of the question asked by the honourable member for Hunter, which related to the conduct, alleged or otherwise, of the National Farmers Federation and as such is outside the jurisdiction of the portfolio of the Minister. Therefore, that second part of the question should be ruled out of order.
—I accept the point of order raised by the honourable member for Farrer. The Minister will answer the other parts of the question.
—The first part of the question asked whether I was aware of reports that the National Farmers Federation had been trying to establish an industrial dispute on the waterfront.
—You were just ruled out of order on that.
—I am listening.
—I am aware of such reports. Those reports have been in the newspapers in recent days and also a few months ago. The West Australian in early March contained a report saying:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Farmers Federation is gearing up for a full-scale fight on the Australian waterfront.
Retiring NFF president Ian McLachlan said yesterday that the federation would go out looking for trouble.
Apparently he has been looking for trouble for the last two months but cannot find it. He was quoted in the Australian today as saying yesterday:
We've been trying to get a decent barney going but we can't.
Perhaps if we go to the wharves we might have a different result.
Today in the Sydney Morning Herald the Industrial Director of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Paul Houlihan, is quoted as saying that:
. . . the farmer lobby was trying to provoke disputes on the waterfront so that it could use its multi-million `fighting fund' to take court action against unions.

What we see here is that the National Farmers Federation quite clearly, through its own spokesmen, has been trying in the last few months to promote industrial disputation in this country. That is an extraordinary situation. We have a leading industrial employer organisation in this country trying to provoke industrial disputation rather than prevent it-a role reversal for an employer organisation in this country and quite extraordinary behaviour. The National Farmers Federation President, a well known member of the Liberal Party of Australia, is perhaps indicating to us the kinds of views which are advised to the Opposition. That perhaps helps to explain the kinds of policies which come from it.

The reason the Federation is having so much trouble in developing that industrial dispute is that there has been a dramatic improvement in industrial disputation on the waterfront. In the last five years, since the Government has been in office, there has been a 70 per cent reduction in the level of time lost in industrial disputes in the stevedoring industry, compared with the previous five years under the Fraser Government-a 70 per cent reduction, a massive reduction in in the level of industrial disputation in this area. That alone indicates an improvement in efficiency on the waterfront and indicates why, with much improved industrial relations on the waterfront, it is difficult for outside bodies, such as the National Farmers Federation, to provoke the parties into industrial disputation, despite the fact that it has a multi-million dollar fund and is just itching to spend it on some such disputation.

This kind of statement and the intention on the part of the National Farmers Federation are made even more irresponsible by the fact that there has been on the part of this Government a very determined attempt to improve productivity and efficiency on the waterfront. A number of steps have been taken, and I will briefly mention them. We have established the Stevedoring Industry Review Committee, which is headed by Sir John Moore, the previous President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. That body, which comprises union and employer representatives, has gone around all of the Australian ports and has looked at ways to improve efficiency in every port in Australia. Those efficiency improvements have been implemented and there are ongoing efforts to obtain further efficiency improvements through the operations of that Committee.

We have also asked the Inter-State Commission to establish a review of the shore-based shipping industry in this country, to establish a long term integrated structure for an efficient industry in this area. The first report from that body should be available to us in a month or two. Alongside that, there have been initiatives such as the move to productivity based container operations in Melbourne and Sydney. The Waterside Workers Federation of Australia has itself gone into business in joint ventures with employers in small ports in Queensland, Victoria and Tasmania, and these operations have been cutting stevedoring costs in half.

So we can see that a variety of steps has been taken by the industry and the Government to try to improve productivity and efficiency. In the midst of all of this rises this Rambo-like figure with his multimillion dollar fund saying, `We want to create a big industrial dispute to try to improve things on the waterfront'. What an absurd situation. It is a ridiculous situation for a supposedly responsible organisation in this country. I can only say that I hope that the new President of the National Farmers Federation, who takes office today, I understand, has a different attitude from that of his predecessor. I understand that he said today that he would be looking to adopt a less confrontationist approach. I hope that that is the case and that we see an end to this kind of stupidity from the National Farmers Federation. I hope that we see from it the kind of action that we greatly desire; that is, I hope we see it get into the mainstream of industrial relations in this country, abandon the confrontationist approach which has been so disastrous under the previous governments, and adopt a much more conformist industrial relations system, producing vastly better results in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications to information contained in a paper prepared for the Minister by Mr Roger Smith, the First Assistant Secretary of the broadcasting policy division of the Department of Transport and Communications. Is it a fact that the paper reveals that the News Ltd corporation's interests in the Channel 10 television network amounted to 17.16 per cent at the end of last year? Is it a fact that the prescribed interest limit for newspaper proprietors having television interests is 5 per cent? Does such a holding breach the cross-media and foreign ownership laws of Australia? Why has the Government not taken action to enforce the law when it has known of this apparent breach for over six months.
—I note the honourable member's interest in the issue he has raised. I will make inquires and provide him with an answer at the first opportunity.
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Commonwealth now transferring surplus defence land at Point Nepean to the Victorian Government for a national park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Dunkley for his question. He has long exhibited a very close interest in this very important area. I can answer that, yes, the plans to transfer the area to the Victorian Government are well advanced. This matter has been the subject of negotiations between the Prime Minister and the Premier of Victoria, Mr Cain. I also pay tribute to the effort put into these negotiations by my predecessor, the former Minister for Administrative Services, the honourable member for Reid.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a very important and historic area. It is on the eastern headland of Port Phillip Bay, Victoria. It includes a number of very important natural, historical and heritage features. For instance, it contains Cheviot Beach which, of course, has some tragic connotations for this country. It also includes a number of Aboriginal sites, famous shipwreck sites, and nineteenth century fortifications. The Victorian Government has long been interested in the area, and we propose to transfer some 215 hectares for a national park. We will retain in the ownership of the Commonwealth some 110 hectares, which is the current site for the Army school of health.

The finances involve a price of $5m for the Victorian Government to meet; and in return we will pay it $4m for an area of land that this Government is interested in at Fishermans Bend. So the Victorian Government will owe the Government $1m, which we hope to pick up within the next 12 months. I have signed the disposal order and I have signed the acquisition order. Much of the area, of course, will be open to public access, and I expect that we will sign the contracts of sale in the near future.

I think our actions in these areas illustrate two things: firstly, the commitment of the Hawke Labor Government to protecting the finances of the Commonwealth and, secondly, our abiding interest in the protection of significant areas of this country for national parks in the interests of the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Why has the Government allowed a 40 per cent duty to be applied to imported high quality lightweight woollen fabrics made from Australian wool, even though Australia's manufacturing industry does not have the capacity to produce this fabric in any quantity? Why was wool the only lightweight fabric excluded from by-law entry, its duty thus being increased from 2 per cent to 40 per cent under the guise of harmonisation? What is the sense of the wool industry developing new products like these and spending millions of dollars of woolgrower and government money on promoting them when the Australian Government prices them beyond the reach of the consumer?
—This is really a question for my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and it is a matter that I have brought to his attention.

—I ask a question of the Minister for the Arts and Territories. Now that the new Parliament House is completed, what action has been taken to proceed with the development of the National Museum of Australia?

—I thank the honourable member for Robertson for his question. The National Museum of Australia is one of the subjects of the museums review that the Government has been undertaking. It is a matter that will go before the Cabinet, I hope reasonably soon-in fact, shortly-and we will have a result on the matter then.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I refer to recent media reports to the effect that the World Jewish Congress has provided to the Australian Government evidence relating to the deaths of two Australian servicemen during World War II. I also refer him to legislation which he introduced, and which is currently still before the Parliament, to prosecute World War II war criminals in Australia. I remind the Attorney-General that much of the evidence on which the Government made its decision to introduce the war crimes legislation originated from the international Jewish community. I ask the Attorney-General: What action is the Government taking to investigate thoroughly the allegations relating to the deaths of the two Australian servicemen? I also ask: Does the Government plan any action to bring to justice the person or persons responsible for their deaths?

—I am aware of the reports to which the honourable gentleman referred. I think the allegations related to a well known person now occupying a position in Europe being perhaps directly or indirectly responsible. Of course, the honourable gentleman will recognise that the war crimes legislation that we now have before the Senate relates to war criminals in Australia. So there is a big difference between this situation and the matter the honourable gentleman asked about. If there is some validity in the allegations, it would appear from the reports that the person or persons who may be responsible for the wartime atrocity that resulted in the deaths of Australians are overseas. The only evidence we would need then, of course, would be to establish whether we should seek extradition. We have never sought extradition to this country for a war criminal trial. The matter is interesting. It in no way affects our legislation which deals with war criminals in Australia. I do not know whether the honourable gentleman is suggesting that some unknown person in Australia was guilty of those atrocities.
—They are war crimes against Australians.

—They are war crimes against Australians overseas and the question arises as to who committed the war crimes. I am posing the question that the law now before the Parliament deals with war criminals in Australia, not war criminals outside Australia. If one were to talk about trying to deal with war criminals outside Australia, one would be dealing with the question of extradition, which is a slightly different procedure. That is the point that the honourable member and I do not know at this stage. I welcome any advice the honourable member wants to give me as to where he thinks we may be able to pursue further inquiries to identify the unknown people who may be guilty of these alleged crimes.

—I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy: Can the Minister inform the House what is the role of the Government's rural counselling program and how does it differ from other counselling services available in rural areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rural counselling program was announced in the Government's economic rural policy statement of April 1986 and came into operation later that year. The Government introduced it because there was clearly a gap in the provision of confidential advice to farm families experiencing financial and, consequently, family and personal pressures. It is important for honourable members to note that it is not a centralised or bureaucratic service. The Federal Government puts up one half of the total costs of operating the scheme and the other half must be found, in cash or in kind, by a local group.

ANSWER.PARA: The local action group in receipt of the grant must be broadly representative of relevant local interests. These would normally include farmers' organisations, church and welfare groups, local councils, State government organisations and local businesses. It is this group that runs the program, selects and employs the counsellor, and determines the area of operation. This ensures that the service can be targeted to those in greatest need and that the confidential advice provided takes account of local characteristics.

Counsellors working within the program provide free advice and help to farm families to assist them to identify their financial and adjustment options and refer them to agencies that can provide other assistance. Recently in Canberra I met with counsellors from the program, and it has been a great success. We have probably got more information out of this program than from any other for the small amount of money that has been committed to it. It is very much a quiet achiever. Currently, 17 counsellors are working throughout Australia and more than 1,500 families have already received financial, personal and management advice from the rural counsellors. That compares with about 400 farmers assisted by the debt mediator program.

I would like to acknowledge the work of the rural counsellors, whose skills, devotion, long hours and frequent long journeys are the basis of this successful service. The rural counselling program has the verbal support of the National Farmers Federation and the new President, Mr John Allwright, has indicated that he is very concerned about downstream effects of farm income problems, such as the human and community problems to which I have referred. I would like to commend the service to rural organisations and businesses in the hope that they will be able to provide cash or in kind support in the future for this most useful activity. I particularly thank the honourable member for Calare for his interest in this program in his capacity as a member of the Prime Minister's task force.
