DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON THE USE AND EFFECTS OF CHEMICAL AGENTS ON AUSTRALIAN PERSONNEL IN VIETNAM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 22 August 1985, my predecessor tabled the nine-volume report of the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam, conducted by Mr Justice Phillip Evatt, DSC-the Evatt Royal Commission. At that time, Senator Gietzelt announced that, on the basis of the scientific, medical, statistical, and other evidence relied upon by the Commission, the Government accepted that the case for a link between agent orange and health problems among Vietnam veterans had not been established. The Government announced its intention to give further close consideration to other specific findings and recommendations of the Commission. In that, it has been ably assisted by a report from Mr R. D. Hogg. The document tabled in November 1987 by Senator McLean and purporting to be the report of Mr Hogg was not the full report. I therefore table Mr Hogg's report as submitted to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I now wish to announce the result of the Government's consideration of these reports. In doing so, I table a schedule outlining the Government's response to each recommendation of the Evatt Royal Commission presented in volume 8 of the Commission's final report. Perhaps the most controversial aspect of the Evatt report was the statement `Agent Orange Not Guilty', with which the Royal Commission headed the chapter on conclusions in its final report. Wide publicity was given to Mr Hogg's dissatisfaction with that statement. In support of his view, Mr Hogg pointed out that it was too early yet to speak with such absolute certainty. He went on to say however that, leaving aside that heading, there was no convincing argument, no new material presented by the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia (VVAA) or others, to change the underlying conclusions and comments of the Commission. This, and Mr Hogg's judgment that the Commission's conclusions were, in the main, sustainable, did not receive wide publicity.

Much of the media and parliamentary attention given to the Evatt Royal Commission and its conclusions has centred on the criticisms made by and through the VVAA. In particular, the VVAA criticised what it saw as bias and plagiarism on the part of the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Evatt. The Government has considered these allegations. The Government's view is that no impropriety arises simply by reason of the fact that the Royal Commissioner adopted, by acknowledged quotation or otherwise, parts of submissions made to him. Further, the Government considers that other general allegations could not be sustained on the material provided by the VVAA. The Government confirms that it does not doubt Mr Justice Evatt's integrity, and notes that his integrity was not questioned by any party at the time of his selection as Royal Commissioner.

In addition to its own allegations, the VVAA submitted criticisms by some scientists dissatisfied with the Royal Commissioner's findings or with his treatment of them as witnesses. The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) examined the VVAA's submissions and made detailed comments on them, including comments on the complaints by Swedish scientists, Drs Hardell and Axelson. In commending the thoroughness and objectivity of the Department's analyses, Mr Hogg expressed the view that the analyses should conclude the Government's responses to matters relating to the conduct of the Evatt inquiry and should be made available to the VVAA. The Government endorses this view, and that material will now be made available. It also endorses the view that the Government should not proceed with any further inquiry into the Evatt Royal Commission's work, as-in Mr Hogg's words-no benefit would accrue to the health of Vietnam veterans from such an inquiry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, the Government has no option but to endorse the Commission's conclusions on chemicals and health as consistent with the evidence put before the Royal Commissioner. In short, the Commissioner concluded that the exposure of Australian service personnel in Vietnam to chemical agents did not produce dosage levels which would be likely to cause any long term health effects. He also concluded that exposure of fathers to chemicals in Vietnam had not caused, and would not cause, birth defects. As a general statement, veterans and their families can be reassured by the Commissioner's report and his conclusions.

The evidence provided by the weight of scientific research and by the available data on cancer incidence among Australian veterans gives a solid basis for the Commission's summary conclusions on cancer. Nevertheless, reservations have been expressed about the Commission's final statement that `service in Vietnam has not and will not cause cancer amongst veterans'. The Government does not intend to leave this potential source of concern unexamined, as I shall explain in more detail when discussing Mr Hogg's recommendations.

As to the Commission's recommendations, they are a mixed bag. Some ask the Government to do what it is already doing. Some raise what are, at most, very minor matters. Other recommendations nevertheless propose significant changes in the repatriation system. The Government's response to the Commissioner's recommendations, including those which fall within the portfolio of the Minister for Defence, is contained in the material I have tabled. I propose to speak only to those recommendations which cover matters of some substance.

The Commissioner recommended: `that as a matter of policy claims by Vietnam veterans, their widows or dependants based on diseases of the circulatory systems be allowed'. In the same terms he recommended that claims based on alcohol-induced diseases or alcoholism itself be allowed. In volume 5 of his report, though not in his summary of recommendations, he recommended that any mental health disorder should also be accepted as a matter of policy.

The basis for these recommendations apparently was that Vietnam service involved stress. Further, alcohol and cigarettes were available in Vietnam and an increase in smoking and drinking could be connected with Vietnam service. These are observations which may be correct. There is, however, a very considerable jump in translating these observations into a recommendation for automatic acceptance of particular conditions for repatriation benefits. To take an extreme example, in relation to circulatory diseases, a veteran who never smoked and never drank but who spent one day in Vietnam could develop a heart condition 50 years after that day in Vietnam. If accepted, the Commissioner's proposal would mean that any claim for the heart condition would be automatically allowed under the repatriation system.

Australia's repatriation system is already among the most generous in the world, and the Government is unable to agree to the proposed automatic acceptance of pension claims for the stated health conditions. Under the Veterans' Entitlements Act, the Repatriation Commission is required to determine that an incapacity or death-claimed as related to the veteran's operational service-is war-caused unless the Commission is satisfied beyond reasonable doubt that there is no sufficient ground for making that determination. The Act provides that the Commission shall be so satisfied if it is of the opinion that the material before it does not raise a reasonable hypothesis connecting the incapacity or death with the veteran's operational service. Cases are considered on their merits, taking account of known medical and other evidence. This approach will continue to be adopted.

The Commissioner sought an expanded role for the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS). The VVCS, he recommended, should become a short term statutory authority, function as a mediator between veterans and government agencies, provide an advisory service on repatriation entitlements, issue travel warrants to veterans, and educate the community regarding the Commissioner's findings on agent orange.

The National Advisory Committee on the VVCS has pointed out that development of the service would be delayed if a separate organisation with its own administrative structure had to be established, that the VVCS should not attempt to provide services and information to veterans which could be provided better by other organisations or by officers of the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and that it was inappropriate for senior counsellors to perform the administrative function of issuing travel warrants. The Government shares these views. As to an educative role for the VVCS outside its own services and clients, the Government considers that a general community educational role could be counterproductive to good relations between the VVCS and its clients. The role of the VVCS is to provide counselling for Vietnam veterans in need. The additional roles which the Commissioner seeks would inhibit the ability of the VVCS to carry out its primary task.

In responding to the Commission's concern about veterans in remote areas, however, the Government has decided to increase VVCS funding to ensure a better service for country veterans and their families. This decision is consistent with the Government's concern that people living in country areas have an equitable access to government services. The VVCS will be able to begin recruitment action designed to add six full time positions to its staff. The aim will be for the extra staff to organise networks in country areas, employing local personnel on a part time basis and providing up to 1,000 hours of fee-for-service counselling. To ensure that these additional resources are employed to the best advantage of veterans and their families, and to provide a basis for government decisions on the level of assistance in future years, the use made of VVCS services will be closely monitored. I should make it clear that this announcement does not pre-empt the work presently being carried out by the House Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The Committee will be reporting on matters of detail which will assist in determining the future scope and extent of work by the counselling service. I expect to be considering the Committee's report later this year.

In the body of his report the Commissioner referred to the provision of half-way homes or hostels for veterans. The Government has already provided support to assist in setting up an emergency accommodation centre for veterans in Queensland. Where the need for short term emergency accommodation is demonstrated and the Government is satisfied that an applicant group has the necessary management expertise and community support, the Government is prepared to contribute, in the form of a seeding grant, towards establishing further community-based facilities. It is proposed to earmark up to $400,000 for this purpose over the next two years. Submissions developed by the ex-service community will be considered on their merits.

The Commission recommended that the Government erect a Vietnam veterans monument. The Australian War Memorial has been established as the national monument to the veterans of all the wars in which Australia has been engaged. An important aspect of this monument is the commemoration of veterans fallen in all wars, including the Vietnam conflict, by inscription of their names on the cloistral walls of the memorial.

Some veterans associations have seen fit to erect their own monuments in the national capital. A committee representing a broad spectrum of Vietnam ex-service groups has sought approval to erect a memorial in Canberra. In processing the application, the Canberra National Memorials Committee will consider the range of sites which might be suitable. The next step would then be for the ex-service committee to make a detailed submission, including design and costing, for a specific form of memorial. Subject to the result of the National Memorials Committee's examination of any such proposal, the Government would be prepared to offer some financial assistance to the ex-service committee.

Mr Hogg made a number of recommendations in his report. Some of these, including matters already alluded to in the Evatt recommendations, are covered elsewhere in this statement or in the schedule to it. The most significant Hogg report recommendations I have not so far referred to are a series of proposals for further scientific studies. I do not propose to comment on two of Mr Hogg's proposals-for studies of agricultural workers and of women exposed to phenoxy herbicides-because of their lack of relevance to the specific issue of veterans' exposure to chemicals in Vietnam. Other studies he suggested were a regular update of the earlier Australian mortality study, reactivation of the morbidity study referred to in the Evatt Royal Commission and investigation of possible health effects arising from the use of dapsone.

It should be noted that Mr Hogg himself said, `. . . it is conclusive that there is no marked difference in the level and nature of illnesses between Vietnam veterans and Army personnel who did not serve'. As to mortality, the additional number of deaths available for analysis since the previous study would probably be too few at present to confirm or refute the findings of that study. As to morbidity, the Government had concluded earlier that such a study could not answer questions as to chemical causation, a conclusion which the United States Government also appears to have reached after expenditure of many millions of dollars. The Australian pilot study had given cause for concern about the likelihood of reaching the necessary high contact and response rates and had indicated that, with veterans more motivated to participate than non-veterans, the difference in response rates could be marked and introduce distortions to a study.

Clearly, in addition to overall mortality, Mr Hogg saw the incidence of cancer as a continuing issue of concern. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has already established a Vietnam veterans data base which contains, inter alia, details of causes of deaths. The Government is of the view that a more cost-effective approach to monitoring mortality or cancer incidence is to use the DVA's records, supplemented by information from State death and cancer registries. The Department will use its own staff to maintain, update and improve the date base and extract material for analysis as required. The Department will also continue to monitor relevant overseas research.

Mr Hogg's final research proposal was that the Government immediately establish an epidemiological study into the possible health effects of the anti-malarial drug dapsone. The Government agrees with Mr Hogg-and with Mr Justice Evatt-that research into the cancer-causing potential of dapsone is desirable. It does not, however, support a wider investigation into all possible effects of the drug, given that dapsone's use for various medical purposes has resulted in an extensive knowledge of reactions it can cause. The National Health and Medical Research Council will be asked to advise on the feasibility of a study into whether dapsone is carcinogenic in man.

We have come a long way since fears about agent orange first emerged among Australian veterans. Milestones along that road in Australia have included the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment in 1982, the Government sponsored birth defects and mortality studies, and in America the Ranch Hand and Centres for Disease Control studies. Soon after this Government came into office, it set up a wide-ranging royal commission which brought many leading international scientists here and visited others overseas in its search for the facts. Since becoming Minister I have ensured that the Royal Commission report, subsequent VVAA submissions and the Hogg report received thorough examination before Cabinet considered the whole issue. The Government believes that too many Vietnam veterans' lives have been disrupted by fears about agent orange and other chemicals. In endorsing the view that any exposure of Australians to chemical agents in Vietnam would be unlikely to cause long term adverse health effects, the Government in no way steps aside from its commitment to help veterans. Its latest decisions reinforce the measures in place to provide continuing assistance to veterans and their families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-At the outset I would like to thank the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) for the courtesies he has extended with regard to this very important ministerial statement on agent orange. I acknowledge the presence in the gallery of the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia (VVAA), Mr Tim McCombe, and the role played by his association in particular, along with many other veterans organisations, including the Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) in respect of Vietnam veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now 2 years and 9 months since the Royal Commission on the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam report, the agent orange report, was tabled in Parliament. Furthermore, it is now six months since the Hogg report, less one page, on that Royal Commission was tabled in the Senate. It has now been retabled today. It has to be said that the ministerial statement made today is long overdue. Indeed, for too many it is too little too late. The delays have exacerbated the concerns of many Vietnam veterans. As the Minister said in his statement, for too long there has been concern over agent orange and its impact on the health of veterans and generally. The delays have contributed to problems associated with the collective image of Vietnam veterans.

In many ways this whole area was addressed in a very proper way with the very successful National Welcome Home Parade held in Sydney last October. It made an outstanding contribution to helping many Vietnam veterans individually and contributed in giving a positive boost to the overall image of Vietnam veterans in the community at large. It is time this nation and this Parliament fully recognised the highly disciplined and entirely professional contribution made by Australian soldiers in Vietnam, often in the most difficult conditions and circumstances. I was pleased to support a resolution that was adopted by this House and the Senate last year with regard to the contribution made by Australian soldiers in Vietnam.

The service given by Vietnam veterans was of the same high standard as established by the Australian Anzacs and as maintained in other theatres of war in which Australian soldiers participated. For the record, I should point out to the House that 49,211 Australians served in Vietnam in the period 1962 to 1973. The total battle deaths were 427. The total non-battle deaths were 74, giving an overall total of 501. The total number of casualties, injuries and illnesses was 3,131.

In the month of May 1988 it is particularly relevant that we are considering this statement because it commemorates the twentieth anniversary of Fire Support Base Coral in which many of us were involved. Mr Lex McAulay has written a book on Fire Support Base Coral. He is well qualified to do so because he is a rare Australian, having served no fewer than three times in Vietnam. In launching that book in Canberra last Monday night Mr McAulay said that he had at no stage witnessed any specific war crimes or any war criminal activity being committed by Australian soldiers in Vietnam. It is relevant to highlight that because we often see today, especially coming out of Hollywood, a series of films which would give one a false picture of the activity in Vietnam. It is important that we place on the record of the House a true and balanced picture with regard to service in Vietnam.

It must also be said that the alienation of many Vietnam veterans was not unique to this particular group of returned soldiers: World War II veterans in many cases felt alienated from the previous generation of World War I veterans. For a period there were difficulties in veterans organisations. When World War II veterans returned they were told by World War I veterans that they had not fought in a real war. Although this experience was probably very limited, it nevertheless did exist-in the same way that Vietnam veterans in some but not all RSL clubs and other veterans organisations felt intense alienation. On the plus side, I should say that there were RSL clubs such as the Granville RSL club which went out of their way in the opposite direction to extend a welcome to Vietnam veterans. I was there along with the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) last Friday as members of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs and, once again, we were assisted by the facilities provided by that club.

There was another group which had a legitimate reason to feel alienation. I refer to the prisoners of war who came back from World War II. The honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) and I had the privilege of visiting part of the Burma death railway some two years ago and then of meeting with a number of the prisoners of war from it. Undeniably, they must have felt absolute anxiety as they came alongside the wharves in Australia. Having come back as prisoners of war, quite often they received a very indifferent reception from the people at the wharves and from the system in place at the time. These things are overcome only after a long period of healing and, to some extent, that is happening. It is tremendous that it is happening: full credit to those involved who helped bring about real progress in this regard, especially with the National Welcome Home Parade.

I turn to the statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In complaining that it is long overdue I must be fair and point out that the Minister has occupied this job for less than a year, since the last election. So the delays relate as much to the Government as they do to the Minister. Let me tell the House of the chronological record. August 1980 saw comparative studies of pesticides used in Vietnam and in Australian agriculture. On 19 January 1982 the then coalition Government opened the first Vietnam veterans counselling service in Adelaide. The Federal Labor Government, on 13 May 1983, shortly after it gained office, in accordance with its election promise, established the agent orange Royal Commission under Commissioner Evatt. In July 1985 that Royal Commission reported to the Government and the report was tabled on 22 August 1985. That was a very moving day. It was particularly moving to see the late Phil Thompson conduct a Press conference in the Senate committee room under King's Hall. He was suffering very real hardship and personal health problems at the time. Nevertheless, he carried the battle forward for the Vietnam Veterans Association on an extremely difficult day for him with what is now deemed a flawed report. In passing, once again I pay tribute to the work and role of Mr Phil Thompson with regard to the welfare of Vietnam veterans. In November 1985 we saw a comprehensive critique issued by the Vietnam Veterans Association. Eventually, that led to the decision in March 1987 to appoint Mr Bob Hogg to report on the Royal Commission's report on agent orange. But what happened during the period of his activity in reporting on the Royal Commission report? Mr Hogg was given leave-to do what? He was given leave to act as an Australian Labor Party campaign worker in the Federal election of July 1987. A further delay ensued but I do not want to dwell on that aspect; I will pursue it on a more appropriate occasion.

In October 1987 the Hogg report on the Royal Commission report was issued and a further six months delay occurred before, finally, today the Minister for Veterans' Affairs brought down his ministerial statement. Those delays, which have been far too long, have added to the problem. I sheet home the blame for those delays to this Government, as it has been in office for the entire time since the report of the agent orange royal commission was handed down. I believe that the Government has directly added to the problem. Hopefully, there will be no further delays in implementing those recommendations that have been adopted.

The Minister's response in many ways is a limited response because some of the recommendations of the Evatt Royal Commission report have been rejected. I commend to honourable members the schedule-I am not sure whether the Minister has tabled it yet; presumably he will table it shortly-because the ministerial statement should be read in conjunction with the schedule table, which gives the exact response to each of the recommendations of the report of the agent orange royal commission.

Clearly, the major thrust of that report was the controversial finding regarding agent orange. I note the careful wording chosen by the Minister with regard to that part of the report. I acknowledge what the Government has determined with regard to the causal linkage which may exist between chemicals and the level of dosage which was encountered by Australian soldiers serving in Vietnam. I accept that there is a need to circulate information with regard to that key finding of both the Royal Commission and Mr Hogg that there is no direct linkage which might impact on the long term health of Vietnam veterans. I accept that we must encourage Vietnam veterans to receive that information, act on it and get on with their lives. Equally, I am sure that the Minister would agree that, given the nature of medical science today and given the nature of the developments which occur, which were not previously anticipated, in regard to chemical development and diseases related to chemicals, it would be unwise completely to close the door to look at what might come up in light of additional scientific work in the future. Certainly, for my part, I will continue to monitor that additional scientific work to see whether further light may be thrown on the application and impact of agent orange and its usage in Vietnam and elsewhere.

In his statement the Minister also proposed an increase of six staff in the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS). That is also welcome. It is a step in the right direction. It is a limited step. There are 3,500 staff under the Minister, excluding repatriation and general hospitals and other institutions. I was pleased to highlight that fact in recent committee proceedings. I am delighted, if not as a consequence of that particular effort then as a consequence of all the representations that have been made by many bodies, that at last the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service is to receive the increase in staff of six which was recommended some time ago. That will help the VVCS. I do not know what else will be left for the standing committee to do with regard to its report, but there are other important aspects relating to the Service which no doubt that committee will report on in the not too distant future. Hopefully, that too, will be acted on quickly by the Minister and the Government.

We welcome the fact that other recommendations were picked up in the Minister's statement. We believe that they will be acted on quickly. Equally, there are other recommendations which have already been adopted and are part of normal practice. I acknowledge that; it is as it should be. On the fundamental question of an epidemiological study, the Minister has failed to persuade Cabinet-if he set out to do so; I am not sure of that, and he might like to tell the House of that on another occasion-regarding that important overall study. It has been rejected by the Government even though it was recommended by both the Evatt Royal Commission and the Hogg report. As the National President of the VVAA has said in his media release, it is an area of disappointment for Vietnam veterans.

As we look to the future with regard to the Vietnam chapter, we should put in context not only the highly disciplined and capable service given by Vietnam veterans but also, equally, the fact that the majority of them have had the good luck to be able to return to this country, to take up citizenship, to fulfil that citizenship in a meaningful way to get on with their lives as hard workers contributing to the community. Unfortunately other Vietnam veterans have been bedevilled by a massive degree of sickness since returning from Vietnam, including massive psychological disorders and the like. They must be helped. It is a continuing obligation on the part of this Parliament and this Government to see that they are helped. We must focus more attention on the condition of post-traumatic stress disorder to learn more about those problems and the way we can help those Vietnam veterans overcome their problems and resume as normal lives as possible. We cannot take away from them the fact that they have legitimate hardships and legitimate conditions. They have recognised conditions, particularly in regard to post-traumatic stress disorder. It is a continuing obligation on this Parliament and this Government to those who serve their country in time of war to look after those Vietnam veterans in a meaningful way.

The Opposition is delighted that finally the Government has produced a ministerial statement detailing its response to the agent orange royal commission report which was tabled 2 years and 9 months ago. It serves notice that it will continue to monitor closely the Government's implementation of the comments and contents of the ministerial statement in the interests of Vietnam veterans, who have a right to be very proud of the service that they gave for their country in a very difficult conflict.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The increasing inappropriateness of Labor's `three mine policy' on uranium mining and export.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday's balance of payments figure brought home, if nothing else, the significance of the elements that add to our export returns and those that prejudice them. Perhaps the most significant aspect of yesterday's figures was the content on the improvement in exports. Without spending a great deal of time talking about this, I make the point that everybody looking at the analysis would have been impressed by the fact that the rise recorded in all commodity groups was a significant element that added to the dimension of what appeared to be a far better than expected result for the month, which was certainly in marked contrast to that of the month before.

SPEECH.PARA: The important aspect of those commodity price rises is that, as the Australian Bureau of Statistics commented on yesterday's figures, not only were rises recorded in all commodity groups, but the main increases were in metal ores and minerals, with about two-thirds of the increase due to uranium. Uranium exports in this month's figures contributed an additional $78m to the export earnings of this country. I think it is particularly appropriate, at a time when within the Australian Labor Party there seem to be a few elements still violently opposed to the commonsense approach about uranium exports, that we in this House look at the consequences for Australia. That is not what the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) and others of his ilk seem to be looking at when they pursue a narrow, self-centred, ideologically prejudiced cause. I have little doubt that at the forthcoming biennial conference of the Labor Party, the left wing will ensure that all the shackles are placed on the few in the Labor Party who are prepared to consider uranium exports rationally and the left wing will extract its pound of flesh.

For Australia it is not only the monetary return that is of concern. Commonsense should prevail in the Labor Party Caucus, which should consider the traditional landowners in the areas of significant uranium deposits, proper and environmentally sympathetic development of those regions, the contribution they will make to both population growth and the development of urban communities and provision of employment in those regions, and ensuring that extraordinarily tight uranium safeguards are imposed. There is not too much commonsense in the Labor Caucus. One of the most disappointing features is that a few of the lesser known and not particularly significant members of the back bench of the Labor Party have been left with the job of reasonably advocating the cause. I am disappointed that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who should be at the forefront of trying to change the minds and views of Labor Caucus, has not taken a more notable stance in trying to move away from the three-mine policy. That is what the uranium issue is all about.

All honourable members know Nabarlek is progressively running down and shortly we will have only two mines. Honourable members should bear in mind the first statistics-that $78m of the improved balance of payments returns yesterday were directly attributed to uranium receipts-and that it would be absolute stupidity for the Labor Party not to accept that the three-mine policy has to go and that the three-mine policy, which is about to be the two-mine policy, should be expanded into a rational assessment of exports or uranium subject to safeguards. Exports should be allowed.

The real problem in the Labor Party is that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is not prepared to stand up for what he believes is right. Honourable members have seen that on successive occasions. The consequence of that will be that, instead of a rational debate proceeding, the Prime Minister will try to duck and weave on the two issues of the most importance to the Australian community: firstly, to adopt a reasonable policy for uranium; and, secondly, to do something reasonable about privatisation. Neither issue will be allowed to surface because the Labor Party is no longer in control of what it believes should be right for Australia because its policies will be entirely directed and manipulated by the left wing.

I wish the few members like the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon), the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) well in their cause, because there is a rational basis on which uranium exports should be permitted and uranium mines should be opened and extended, subject not only to our uranium safeguards but also to appropriate environmental safeguards in this country. Both conditions are practical. On that basis the coalition would move in permitting uranium exports. It is important to understand that not only does an immediate opportunity exist but also that by post-1992 world demands for uranium for the generation of nuclear power will increase and the prospects are bright for many contracts being made available in the various countries around the world that permit nuclear power generation. Beyond that, the prospects for quantity and price returns are also good.

Many honourable members would know that currently world uranium prices-certainly those that affect Australia's exports-are determined largely by the Canadians. With the announcement on 3 March last that the two state owned agencies in Canada-Eldorado Nuclear and Saskatchewan Mining and Development Corporation-are to be merged to create the world's largest integrated uranium company, the competition among those two giant companies will no longer exist and uranium prices will probably be increased. With the prospect of their privatisation by 1995, in the mid period when the next term contracts will be available, Australia will have the opportunity not only of selling uranium but also of negotiating a far better price. Even in Energy 2000, the national energy policy paper, an assessment was made that if exports were permitted, Australia has a reasonable basis on which it might obtain one-third of totally uncommitted Western world demand for uranium for the generation of nuclear energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least.

—At least. I was about to say that to my mind, those figures underestimate the situation significantly. Australia has a real and probable opportunity of filling that gap and, unless it starts selling uranium now and negotiating now, the Canadians in particular will take advantage of Australia. Anyone who has any doubts, like the honourable member for La Trobe, should read the national energy policy paper. The paper is not anywhere near as generous in its assessment of the prospects of uranium exports but little doubt exists, considering Australia's prospects for a market share, Australia will not be selling uranium if its ban remains but countries like South Africa will, and then the fears the honourable member pretends to have will be realised. The world will not have uranium sourced in countries that impose safeguards like those we impose on our uranium; it will be sourced in other countries such as some in South America and South Africa, where probably far less of a safeguard will be applied to that uranium in the future climate of nuclear power generation.

SPEECH.PARA: In a few minutes, my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) will deal in more detail with the contract gap. I want to consider the circumstances of who will benefit if a development of more than three mines is allowed and the opportunities in Australia. All honourable members would remember that, when the Labor Party took office, nine or 10 mines had reached the point of having identified the uranium resource and were in a position, had they been allowed to export uranium, to bring significant benefits to the Aborigines who lived in the areas and to foster Australia's exports. For example, we have Jabiluka and Koongarra in the Northern Territory; in Western Australia, Yeelirrie, Kintyre and Ben Lomond; in South Australia, we have Beverley and Honeymoon. At present all those mining prospects are virtually shut down and are not able to proceed in a rational, orderly way simply because the Labor Party is not permitting them to do so, despite the fact that Nabarlek is not being permitted to export uranium.

One of the interesting aspects of the community debate is that a number of Labor members have been prepared openly and honestly to lay down their views on the situation. I pay credit to the honourable member for Northern Territory. If only he were able to persuade a few of his colleagues to support the views that are included in the paper that he produced on uranium mining. These views have been necessary because of the blatant prejudice demonstrated by the honourable member for La Trobe in his assessment of the consequences of uranium exports on Australia.

Members on the Opposition side of the House are not trying to intervene in the interfaction fights in the Labor Party-we know they happen all the time. But we are concerned that the product of the prejudiced approach to uranium exports in the so-called Milton paper is such that people will not be able to understand that, if development and expansion from the three-mine policy is not allowed, the Aborigines will suffer. One only has to consider the enormous returns. On earlier occasions I have read out correspondence from various representatives of the Aboriginal people who believe strongly that the mines in the north could have brought them significant rewards.

At Koongarra at the moment there is a window. The Denison operators not only have said that they are prepared to provide fair returns to the Aboriginal people but also have identified a very real equity for those Aboriginal landholders. They have given them something like a 25 per cent share in the project and have told them that, if this Government is not prepared to change its three-mine policy, instead of very considerable economic benefits being brought to the people of Koongarra, that contract will go to Canada. With the prospect of its big State-owned mines being amalgamated and then privatised, there is little doubt that Canada will be able to provide those contracts without any difficulty at all.

Let me give honourable members some idea of the prospects. The Koongarra mine in the Northern Territory could go into production immediately. It has something like 32 million pounds of yellowcake, and that has already been sold at prices in excess of the Australian floor price. This represents a potential export revenue to Australia of $2 billion from 1991 to 2001, at 1984 prices. The real point about this is that now is the time to permit these mines to start negotiating their contracts, because Koongarra has that contract at the point where there is a window in the availability of opportunities to sell uranium for energy generation around the world. From 1992 onwards there will be a particularly significant shortage of uranium in the United States of America, but there are shortages in other countries too.

Now is the golden opportunity for the Australian Labor Party to throw aside the prejudices of its Left and to say that the three-mine policy is not the way to go and that there is no basis on which one can say that there is good uranium and bad uranium. The Labor Party has to forgo its political prejudices and accept that, subject to proper uranium safeguards and subject to the proper interests of the indigenous land-holders and the environmental concerns being protected, uranium should be allowed to be exported from mines around Australia. Indeed, we know that the Gagadju people, who own the land at Koongarra, have signed an agreement with Denison. As I mentioned, it gives them a 25 per cent equity in the mine as joint venturers. It will bring them a return of more than a quarter of a billion dollars over 10 years. Yet it is the prejudices of the left wing of the Labor Party, which pretends to be interested in Aborigines, which are going to stop them taking advantage of that opportunity.

There are very real reasons for Australia's sake, on an economic basis and on the basis of a concern for the people of the region and a concern for Aborigines, why the present three-mine policy of the Labor Party has to be scrapped. It should never have been introduced in the first place. It is there only on the basis of a compromise among Labor's factions. Australia's need for export returns has never been greater. As I remarked, this month the balance of payments figures show $78m from uranium. The opportunities are there economically. For goodness sake, members of the Australian Labor Party must get their heads out of the sand and put Australia's interests first. It is too late in the day for them to continue to live in yesteryear. We have to get that three-mine policy lifted. It is up to the members of the right wing of the Labor Party to put those left wing members where they jolly well should be-out of the Parliament altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Here again we have an example of the tired, lazy old Opposition jumping on any band wagon. On this issue it really did not have a policy when it was in government, and we do not know what its policy is now. As a matter of fact, it had a two-mine policy, and that was the result of very extensive inquiries and the problems that it faced in government with this industry. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) started off his address here today by talking about the balance of payments effect. Of course, he exhibits here the danger of grasping one month's figures. Because uranium goes out in large shipments, of course it will be recorded in the figures for any one particular month. More importantly, what I think he should have been pointing to is that the level of exports of uranium from this country are increasing and the value is going up. But this Government does have a policy about the mineral.

SPEECH.PARA: All this bleating about Aboriginal rights must be a new twist. For the National Party of Australia to be supporting Aborigines in the mining industry, I would suggest, is a very new twist indeed. To be bleating about this and also to be talking about the environment, with the history that the National Party has on those sorts of issues, associated with the mining industry, is massive hypocrisy. The Leader of the National Party also says-and this is an example of his logic-that two Canadian companies are going to get together and prices will increase. Let us look at that logic. If that logic is accepted, prices will fall when new Australian companies are introduced into the mining scene here. That is rather a nonsense argument. He says that Koongarra can open immediately; later on he says that it cannot open until 1991, and 1991 is probably the date if the go-ahead were given now.

But this is the Opposition just jumping onto any old band wagon. A few months ago the Opposition was prompted by the Esso Australia Ltd advertising campaign on petroleum and when it jumped onto that band wagon it again exhibited the fact that it did not really understand the far more sensible taxation and exploration policies that we have put in place, compared with those when it was in government. Today it is uranium, mainly of course because of the coming Australian Labor Party biennial conference. There is going to be a very healthy debate in the Australian Labor Party on this issue and, of course, would-be miners of uranium are being assiduous in their lobbying. Yesterday a paper was released by CRA Ltd, using an Orani model. I simply point out that, although a case is made there, I think Orani has very little applicability and we should not take its end point estimates as having any significance in fact.

I have three mining industries that are tinged with controversy and emotion. If I may indulge myself, they are gold, coal and uranium. We are told that the gold industry can survive only if it is not taxed, and the multinational companies that take half of the profits of the industry threaten to bring down any government that touches the taxation regime or the lack of it. Australia is the world's largest exporter of coal, yet sellers cannot get a high enough price to stop mines shutting down. The workers want a bureaucracy to plan the industry's development and set prices. The coal industry and its structure, of course, are of some significance to the uranium industry, because we have oversupply. Then there is uranium. Some in the community want to shut the industry down. The Senate bears testimony to this. Others, mainly the Opposition, want open slather, regardless of any notion of an industry policy and mainly for ideological reasons. The Opposition's case today was all on the basis that uranium is not different from any other mineral.

My view is that for existing mines we do have to exercise judgment as to what are the interests of the country, the industry and its well-being. I also believe that uranium cannot be simply regarded as the same as any other mineral. The discussion and debate in Australia and worldwide for a long period confirms this statement. Uranium is dangerous to mine in some circumstances. Uranium's derivative, plutonium, is used to make atomic weapons. I suggest that peace is the world's biggest issue. Nuclear proliferation has to be prevented, so we have in place a comprehensive system of elaborate safeguards. Uranium waste and nuclear by-products are extremely dangerous to handle and extremely dangerous to life. The human health risks from any nuclear accident are large, and we have only to take into account the Chernobyl accident.

It is for some of these reasons, as well as political opportunism and a denigration of science, that uranium is of such concern in the political process and the politics of this country and other countries. Opponents of uranium and anything associated with it misrepresent facts, truth and logic. Other use facts, truth and logic to fortify their arguments. It is really a question of value judgments, and the fact that value judgments are exercised again indicates the nature of this debate.

I recently had a discussion with Senator Sanders. While sitting in his office in Australia, he can tell me what happens in France because it is in his book. When I ask for the source of what is in his book, he tells me that it is in his book. So perhaps someone should write two books. The European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom), I am told, is the Euratom Safeguards Directorate because the word `Euratom' appears in the name of both organisations. I think that is a rather peculiar connection to make.

People do not accept the theory of equivalence in the safeguards regime. Flag swaps, which can also be described as safeguards obligations, are misrepresented and are often represented as international flag swaps, which are something entirely different. I made a statement that we cannot track every atom of Australian uranium through the process of converting uranium into fuel rods, and that was misrepresented to say that ipso facto Australian uranium goes into French atomic bombs. It is just a nonsense statement to make. We have in place a comprehensive system of safeguards. I think anyone would admit that uranium is a different mineral on the basis of that fact alone. Of course, members of the Opposition when in government treated this mineral very differently-in keeping with their perceptions of the different nature of it. Of course, in those days the then Leader of the National Party was one of the high regulators of mineral exports.

So I am saying that uranium cannot be viewed solely in terms of gross revenue to be gained. There are costs and benefits to be taken into account when looking at the industry in purely industry terms. Looking at the industry in economic terms-accepting what I have said about the very different nature of the mineral-I am also saying that at this time there is no overwhelming economic imperative for expansion of the industry. We are talking about estimates of world supply and demand. Of course, members of the Opposition here today are the same people who talked up the so-called resources boom. It is hypocrisy for the coalition to talk about the inappropriateness of Government policy when it has never had a policy itself. There is not much sense in its attacking us for having a three named mines policy when it had a two mines policy and when it had set a minimum price. To some extent we are carrying on exactly what honourable members opposite did. So I do not know why the heck they are attacking us because we have one more mine than they did.

What has really happened is that the coalition has simply taken ad hoc decisions in response to whatever figures happen to be floating around at the time, and it has left the uranium companies, quite naturally, in a state of confusion. When the party of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was in power it did not move to open up the uranium industry. That Government ineffectively fiddled around the edges. The then Government, in its response to the report of the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry, said that it would consider proposals for other projects once environmental and Aboriginal welfare criteria had been met. But, to use the then Prime Minister's words-honourable members will all remember Mr Fraser-that consideration would be `without commitment to order or timing of development'. That was that Government's policy-without commitment to order or timing of development. There was, to quote one commentator: `a widely held view outside Canberra, that Liberal meddling and lack of nerve had damaged Australian uranium'. That is how inappropriate that Government's approach was. It was Doug Anthony who introduced quite sharp export controls on price back in the late 1970s. The Government got into export controls trying to hold prices for existing mines. At the same time Mr Anthony was citing the economic benefits of a uranium enrichment plant. The Government was reported to be having so much difficulty in selling its share of Ranger uranium that the Ranger holding was disposed of late that year.

This Government and this Party have a clearly stated policy on the mines which are to be allowed to mine and export uranium. It is determined by the Party's conference; it is publicly available; and those with uranium interests should be more than aware of what it says. No amount of steamroller tactics on the part of the Opposition will force the Government to adopt the conservatives' make it up on the run approach-or open slather for ideological reasons. Party policy will be determined at the Party's National Conference, with due regard to various points of view, and then, as always, it will be clearly set out for all who are interested. As I said earlier, we will have a very healthy debate.

Let us look at uranium supply and demand, which is the basis of what I am saying about this industry in purely economic terms. Estimates from international agencies of demand for uranium in non-communist countries in 1990 vary from 44,500 tonnes to 49,000 tonnes. Similarly, demand for 1995 is variously estimated at 50,000 to 52,000 tonnes. Data on demand and supply for centrally planned economies is relatively difficult to obtain. But the Nuclear Energy Agency estimates production from existing and committed production centres at around 48,000 tonnes of uranium in 1990 and 47,500 tonnes in 1995.

Given that current non-communist uranium stockpiles are reliably estimated at around 145,000 tonnes-or three to four years forward reactor requirements, when the normal level would be two to 2 1/2 years requirement-non-communist production capacity, combined with inventory drawdown, could be seen to be meeting requirements until 1995. The reason why prices are hard to hold at present is that this inventory is holding down prices-there is a stock overhang. Perhaps the best guide to the actual demand for Australian uranium in the 1990s can be seen in relation to anticipated uncommitted uranium demand; that is, demand not already under contract. Estimates suggest that in the early 1990s uncommitted demand will be around 15,000 tonnes per year. Realistically, I believe that Australia could not expect to gain more than one-third of this quantity-and that is around 5,000 tonnes of uranium, which is about equivalent to 6,000 tonnes of U308. Given that the Ranger mine has the capacity to expand production to around 6,000 tonnes per annum, and that the Olympic Dam has an anticipated total capacity of around 4,000 tonnes, existing operations could be expected to be able to meet uranium demand well into the early 1990s.

I will be very honest. Admittedly this assessment is something of a simplification of the world market. Various companies have claimed that, through special relationships with uranium buyers, they have access to market windows not available to existing Australian suppliers. The argument from each individual company is that it could gain substantial sales without displacing the market share of existing mines. But this, of course, would get us into the whole regime of what is a special contract and what would be the sequence. The simple fact is that all the would-be miners would say that they have contracts. If we had open slather and all these would-be miners' would-be contracts were exercised, enormous pressures would be placed on the economic well-being of the existing mines. I believe that what I have said is an accurate description of the uranium industry in Australia, taking into account what I have said about the mineral being not just like any other mineral and taking into account the industry that we have. At this time there is no overwhelming economic reason why we should change the policy which we have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), in his speech just a moment ago, made this observation: `Here we go, the Opposition just wants to make political capital out of this particular issue'. Far from it. This is the second matter of public importance on this subject we have had this year. We had the first in February and we want to keep raising this issue until the Government comes to its senses and takes policy directions which will be to the benefit of the majority of Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we are having a matter of public importance debate today is the inappropriateness of this Government's particular policies; but more particularly it is that we have this amazing situation. One of the honourable members who caused this situation is sitting in this House, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney). I mention also Senator Collins, the Australian Labor Party senator for the Northern Territory. These people have issued papers which indicate quite clearly that the Government is floundering and they are getting no leadership from the Cabinet as to the direction in which they ought to be going. It is all right for the Minister to dive down that burrow and say that the Party will talk about the matter in Hobart. The rest of Australia wants to know what is going to happen now. The Minister said that in February. While we are rubbing our hands and watching the Canadians take all the benefits of the international uranium markets, Australia is missing out. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) detailed the extent of that loss. Indeed, the trade figures that came out yesterday showed that a figure in the vicinity of $75m from uranium sales meant the difference between a good balance of trade figure and a bad balance of trade figure. It is interesting to look at what the Minister said on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in February of this year. He said:

It was made very clear at the time of the Treasurer's Budget statement and those of the then Minister (Mr Dawkins) that we had decided that the party's policy, given the trade situation at the time, was a hollow gesture and that all we were doing was hurting our own country.

The Minister admitted it then, in February; yet he will not do anything about it now. The Minister says that we have to wait until the factions have sorted themselves out. It is simply not good enough. What did the Australian Financial Review say in its editorial as long ago as January? It said:

. . . the Labor Party, elected to govern Australia for the benefit of the people as a whole, still allows itself to be intimidated by this pathetic rump of Neanderthal pretenders to a power base that no longer exists.
Just a moment ago the Minister, bless him, adopted the arguments of Mr Milton. What happened last night on The World Tonight? Mr Milton put those very economic arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the honourable member for Bass to refer to the honourable member for La Trobe by his electorate.
—The honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) said that he was concerned that the economic arguments did not demand that Australia export its uranium.
—Using the same words as the Minister.
—Exactly, that is my point. All of a sudden the Left is joining with the Minister. I do not know whether the Minister feels comfortable about that. Let me refer to what Mr Bilney said in his paper.
—Order! Again I ask the honourable member for Bass to refer to honourable members by their electorates.

—He calls it the Bilney report; why does he not call it the Kingston report? The honourable member for Kingston commissioned a study by the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research. He touted it as the first time that a study of that sort had been done to gauge the damage that would be done to Australia and is being done unless we get rid of the three-mine policy. The report shows that in 1992 an extra 240,000 jobs and an extra $5 billion would be the benefit to Australia if it proceeded. Why did the Minister not refer to that report? Why were those figures ignored?

SPEECH.PARA: I now refer to yesterday's Australian. In an interesting report, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that Dr Reynolds, a visiting American, should not be listened to. Dr Reynolds's advice to Australia and his observations about Australia can be encapsulated in what he said: `It looks like it's a big country that thinks small'. The editorial in the Australian states:
Dr Reynolds brings the freshness of an outsider to the analysis of problems with which we are too depressingly familiar. It remains fundamentally a question of will, the will to change.
That is what the debate is about-whether the Labor Party has the will to change and take a policy direction that will be to the benefit of this country with regard to the three-mine uranium policy.

The paper of the honourable member for Kingston, which is referred to as the Bilney report, says that Australia should be proceeding down that path. Senator Collins from the Northern Territory also issued a report in which he said that we ought to be proceeding. Those two reports answer the fundamental questions the Minister raised about whether there is demand. I want to put to bed the myth that the demand is not there. Just a moment ago when talking about this issue-it took him about 10 minutes to get to the nub of the problem-the Minister said that the estimates of the world uranium demand were perhaps being simplified by himself and it was difficult to ascertain some exactitude about them. There are figures, of course, and the Minister quoted some. I have some figures and Senator Collins's paper also refers to figures. Senator Collins said at the beginning of his paper with regard to supply:
Initial projections for uranium demand were over-optimistic. To portray current demand as a dramatic downturn, however-
as Milton does-
is to obscure both the extent and the vital importance of the steadily growing use and acceptance of nuclear generation around the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy-eight and a half per cent over optimistic.
—The honourable member for La Trobe can have his opportunity to dispute that. I have not heard from him yet.
—I have not had the chance.
—I am not surprised that they will not let the honourable member speak. Senator Collins concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the existing policy places an artificial constraint on the industry which, while allowing Australia to remain a substantial producer of uranium, provides our competitors with a ridiculous commercial advantage.
This extremely detrimental position does not appear to be offset by any conceivable advantage to Australia from either an economic or ideological point of view.

It is essential that the Party take the next logical step, and allow Australia to develop its extensive and low-cost uranium resources in a manner consistent with both the market opportunities that do exist, and Australia's national interests.
That was not said by the Liberal Party of Australia; it was said by someone in the Labor Party. That is someone the Labor Party should be listening to.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the mining body.

—It is all right for the honourable member for Hindmarsh to try to interrupt the flow of this speech with inane interjections that mean nothing. Two members of the Labor Party say those things and the Minister does not provide any direction whatever, and the honourable member is simply going to ignore it. Some of those opposite are members of the neanderthal Left. The myth about there being no demand for uranium is an absolute furphy.
—I wish to take a point of order. I ask the honourable member to withdraw the word `neanderthal'.

—I withdraw. The Government has been mugged by economic reality. That is what it amounts to. That is why it had to change the contracts with regard to France and let them proceed. That is why at the National Conference the Labor Party will have to change its policy. The honourable member for La Trobe would be better advised to read carefully the reports by the honourable member for Kingston and Senator Collins because they say the very things the Liberal Party has been saying and which I said in this House in February. There is demand, and we ought to be addressing that point.

SPEECH.PARA: It is reasonable to expect that the additional uranium production will be needed from the early 1990s. The market is now in an historic transition phase, with supply and demand returning to balance and inventories declining to manageable levels. That is the crux of the issue. Key utilities in the Western world and Japan are now starting to consider their purchasing policies for the early 1990s and onwards as they see the market beginning to tighten.

The Minister quoted some figures. If one looks at the figures from the Nukem data system, one sees that they show an increasing demand. I know that the Nukem data system might not be acceptable to the honourable member for La Trobe but he must prove that the figures it has put together are not accurate. They are the most accurate that can be found and are available from reputable sources in this building. I will ask the Minister for leave to incorporate the figures in Hansard so that members on the other side can show the people of Australia that there is no demand. It is only the honourable member for La Trobe and the Minister who say that there is no demand. Everyone else says that there is demand into the 1990s. Until such time as we take a decision to put ourselves in a position where we can take advantage of that increasing demand, we will suffer the things outlined in the report of the honourable member for Kingston-lack of jobs and lost export opportunities, as the Leader of the National Party pointed out. Australia will be the loser.

The question is: Have we the will to change? More particularly, have members of the Left the will to change? Members of the Labor Party have, as have members on this side of the House, the rest of Australia and the Aboriginal community. It is only the members of the neanderthal Left who will not change their minds. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the matter of public importance, I am impressed by the fact that members of the National Party of Australia and others refer to those on this side as neanderthal, given the recent shemozzle that took place in the coalition party room about the referenda, where the executive was going to recommend two Yes votes and two No votes-two No votes because of the neanderthals in the National Party who could not come to grips with modernising the Constitution. When it went to a full coalition meeting they became even worse neanderthals because they rejected all the proposals. One wonders where the policy development in the Opposition will come from. It has been in opposition for almost six years, and it still has not come to grips with the development of rational policy. The Opposition cannot get it right.

SPEECH.PARA: It used to be that when people wanted to influence both the Government and the Opposition, they would talk to the leaders of both parties. They would see Ministers and then see shadow Ministers. When people come to lobby the Opposition now they do not go to see the shadow people, they do not go to see Johnny Howard, because he does not make the policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. There has been a rightful insistence in the House that the honourable member for Kingston be referred to correctly. I would have thought it consistent that the Leader of the Opposition be referred to correctly.
—Order! The honourable member has drawn the matter to the attention of the Chair. I shall ensure that that practice is pursued.

—People no longer go to see the Leader of the Opposition; they go to see all the dissident members sitting on the back bench and ask them what they are going to do and whether they will muster the numbers when they get to the party room. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) cannot get the policy together. Look what he did! He gave a wink and a nod to Christopher Skase and said, `Don't worry, the television policy will be right'. What happened? He got rolled by the dissident backbenchers. Talk about factionalism! There are more factions in the Opposition than one would know what to do with; Opposition members could play cards with the number of factions they have.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the question of uranium. All of a sudden Opposition members have become excited because there has been increased activity in an attempt to influence the Australian Labor Party and this Government in terms of the policy on uranium because, in three weeks from now, the Labor Party will have a National Conference and the opportunity to change policy arises. At least the Labor Party does, every two years, create a document arising from its National Conference, which canvasses all the policies of the party and lays them down clearly. It provides the opportunity for all the people in the community who want to influence a party to come forward and attempt to influence it. So there has been a development of different papers both within and outside the Party. People want to influence the Labor Party. Therefore, some people exaggerate what the potential might be in the uranium industry. I instance just one, the recent one, that suggests we could have $600m more. It is not being suggested that that much potential exists out there, that there is that much money to be made and that there are that many contracts to be made. It is suggested that there is a difference between Canada and Australia; Canada gets $600m more for its sales of uranium than does Australia. Some people are saying, `What if we had the $600m? What would we do with it?'.

That is a nonsense argument, because one would have to assume that Australia's existing miners, those companies that own the mines, have not been out there attempting to get contracts. Of course they have. Our existing mines are not working and producing to full capacity. Does the Opposition think that those companies would not be out there trying to get more contracts and sell more uranium so they can lift their production? Of course they are out there competing in the market. However, so are all the other uranium producing countries. They are all bidding and under-bidding and getting prices. We know that Ranger is working at about half capacity.

What is the sensible policy that the Opposition wants to adopt? What it wants to do is to simply open up the system so that everyone can open up a mine. If one has a bit of uranium, one can open up a mine; or one can bid and sell; and there is unlimited potential out there. That is just nonsense. Under that policy, one would end up with an industry that was as unstable and as unprofitable as the coal industry, because that is what has been allowed to happen in the coal industry. Everyone has been able to go out and do his own thing and to undersell and underbid someone else, and what one ends up with is an unprofitable and unstable industry.

The Opposition already knows that the existing mines are selling uranium and are not working to full capacity. It knows that that potential is there. Nobody denies that there is still potential out there for contracts. However, we already have mines and we have the capacity to increase production.

There is a need for proper development of the industry in a way that allows for proper consideration of all the issues. However, what the Opposition would like to do is to say, `Look, uranium is no different from coal; it is no different from iron ore; and it is no different from bauxite. We will just mine it, sell it and not worry about the consequences or about any other problems there might be. We will just treat it the same as any other mineral'. Of course, to do that is to ignore the reality of the world. Everyone knows that uranium is different from any other mineral, because its by-products are used to produce nuclear weapons. The waste material, after it has been used, creates enormous environmental problems that have yet to be resolved. But the Opposition says, `Let us not worry about that. Let us just have an open mines policy. Let everyone do what they want out there. Let us ignore the reality of the real demand'. Let us assume, as the Opposition would, that what we should do is to just look at the potential demand and the maximum use that everyone can make of it-`Let us look at what France can do. Let us look at its maximum use'. The reality is that no country uses to the maximum what it could potentially use. The demand is not there. It is of little use to Australia to produce uranium on the basis of the assumption that every country will use it to its full potential.

The reality is that some people have already worked on that, and that is why there are such huge stockpiles of uranium all over the world. About 4 1/2 years worth is stockpiled waiting because people have been producing based on nonsense growth and demand figures, which everyone knows the industry has been overestimating for the entirety of its existence. Everybody who is involved in the industry, particularly the mining section, overestimates the demand in order to try to justify why his particular interest or their particular mine should be allowed to open up. The reality is that those estimates have never lived up to expectations.

The real situation is the need-as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) said-to examine the uncommitted contracts that are real, those that exist. Honourable members know that Australia would have a potential to get some of those and that that potential could be accommodated easily within the capacity of the existing mines.

The Labor Party will develop a policy in three weeks time. It will rediscuss the question of uranium mining along with every other issue. Some people may believe that it will change; others, I believe, are fairly confident that nothing will change. However, the reality is that the Labor Party has a venue at which there will be open and free discussion of the issue. It allows for all areas and interested parties to contribute to that discussion. The Government accepts that industry has a right to put forward information. We also accept that opponents to the industry have a right to put forward points of view. The Labor Party considers all of those points of view at that conference. Having considered them, we will come to a decision.

When the Opposition is able to come forward and say, `This is how we develop our policy'-not how the National Party develops its policy, which will be different from that of the Liberal Party of Australia and not how the back bench develops its policy, which is different from that of the executive, and so on-and when it comes up with a constructive way in which it can develop its policy in the open public arena and indicates when it will do it and that it will review it regularly, as the Labor Party does, perhaps Opposition members can come forward in this place and attempt to make some criticism of the Government's policies.

There is nothing wrong with the existing policy, which has been formed over a number of years of consultation. It can be reviewed. People can put forward their contributions to it. But what we will always end up with is an industry which will be constrained, because it is a unique industry and because of the serious problems that can flow from its development. Also, we will ensure that Australia does not contribute to the oversupply that already exists around the world. There is a need for orderly development, and the Government will not necessarily listen to every carpetbagger who says that he has a contract somewhere around the world.
