Bill presented by Madam Speaker, and read a first time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Honourable members will recall that, on 19 March 1987, I introduced the Parliamentary Privileges Bill 1987 into the House following its passage through the Senate. This procedure was followed in recognition of the Bill's content and its importance to the functioning of the Parliament. It was the first occasion a Speaker had introduced legislation into the House. The Bill I have just presented marks the second such occasion. I wish honourable members to know that I do not intend that this should become a continuing practice but on this occasion I took the view that it would be inappropriate for these legislative changes, so specifically concerned with the administrative structure of the Parliament, to be initiated by a Minister. The proposals have been developed from initiatives of the Presiding Officers and our submitting them for the consideration of each House is, in our view, consistent with the independence of the Presiding Officers' positions and their administrative responsibility exercised on behalf of all members. This course of action meets with the approval of the Executive Government and the executive of the Opposition parties.

The administration of the Parliament has, since Federation, operated under a number of separate administrative units. These units are currently incorporated in the Public Service Act as the Departments of the Senate, the House of Representatives, the Parliamentary Library, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, and the Joint House Department. The purpose of this Bill is quite simply to reduce the number of separate departments serving the Parliament from five to three. The Bill seeks to amend the Public Service Act 1922 to replace the Department of the Parliamentary Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department with a new Department of Parliamentary Services. It also seeks to create a new office of Secretary to the Department of Parliamentary Services to administer the new Department. The other provisions of the Bill are consequential or transitional in nature.

By way of background, I remind honourable members that in May 1987 the President and I outlined proposals to restructure the administration of the Parliament to all senators and members, as well as to the heads of the parliamentary departments, unions and staff associations. Detailed reports on aspects of the administration of the Parliament were commissioned by us. These reviews related specifically to information systems, parliamentary relations, public relations and certain staffing and accounting services. Some administrative adjustments have been made following these assessments. Despite these adjustments, as recognised by the Presiding Officers in 1987 and since then, effective long term rationalisation was dependent on structural change which would require a change in the legislative basis of the Parliament's administration.

The main objectives of the proposed restructuring should be stated to the House. They are: a less fragmented, more effectively coordinated administration in which personnel and resource management are given greater emphasis, especially in the joint areas; the maintenance of services to senators and members, and enhancement of scope and standards where possible in a climate of severe resource restraint; the containment of additional costs arising from the provision of services in the substantially larger and more complex new Parliament House; a better balance of managerial, parliamentary, procedural and other specialist viewpoints, and more flexibility for Presiding Officers to adapt structures and staffing to meet changing circumstances, for example, experience in the new Parliament House environment, blurring of functional boundaries with developments in information technology, contracting of some services and limitation of resource allocation. Regular consultation with the party leaders and the parliamentary departments has led to a general level of acceptance that structural change, to the extent provided by the Bill, is required to meet these objectives.

The President and I, as well as the Government and the executive of the Opposition parties, have concluded that a number of administrative arrangements flowing from the creation of the Department of Parliamentary Services cannot be written into the legislation. In order to assist the House in its later consideration of the Bill, I wish to outline arrangements which will be required to be put into place, initially. Mr President and I believe that in any reorganisation of the parliamentary departments we have an obligation to observe the overriding principle of preserving the integrity and constitutional positions of both the Senate and House of Representatives and the departments that directly serve them. Thus, the two independent chamber departments will remain, and, under the respective Presiding Officers, the Clerks will have independence in respect of finance, personnel and administrative services for their respective departments.

The new senior position of Secretary to the Department of Parliamentary Services will be responsible for coordinating administrative policy and managing the provision of certain common services in the Parliament, so as to ensure that the Parliament gains full value for money from its common resources. The Secretary will have overall administrative responsibility for the existing functions of the Parliamentary Library, the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the former Joint House Department and other selected common functions. These functions are to include:
Building and property, including engineering and gardening services,

the personal services to members and senators and the administrative control of accommodation, which will continue to be exercised by the Serjeant-at-Arms and Black Rod under the direction of their respective Presiding Officers,
catering services,
information systems,
public relations,
industrial relations, and
finance, personnel and administrative services for the new Department.

Parliamentary relations and parliamentary education will continue to be carried out by the two chamber departments. Parliamentary relat- ions will be located within the Department of the House of Representatives and parliamentary education within the Department of the Senate. These offices will report jointly to the Presiding Officers.

Clause 12 of the Bill ensures that the current occupants of the positions of Parliamentary Librarian and Principal Parliamentary Reporter will continue in these positions and that their current salary status will be preserved. They will continue to have direct access to the Presiding Officers for advisory purposes in their respective areas of expertise. Clause 12 also provides for the transfer of offices from the existing departments to the new Department and for the transfer of the present incumbents to those offices. Thus the positions of all officers will be protected. The President and I will be discussing with the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) the maintenance of separate, `one line' appropriations for each of the three parliamentary departments and consideration will be given to separate lines for the appropriations of the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Reporting Staff so that there is a guaranteed level of funding for them.

A Presiding Officers Advisory Board, consisting of the two Clerks and the Secretary to the Department of Parliamentary Services, will be provided in the new structure to facilitate the contribution of policy level advice by the Clerks to the Presiding Officers in respect of the common services areas. The role of the Advisory Board will require further consideration, including proposals concerning the chairmanship being rotated between the Clerks and for major changes in structures and operations of the Department of Parliamentary Services to be referred to it for consideration prior to submission to the Presiding Officers.

The President and I propose that these amendments to the Public Service Act be regarded as an initial legislative step. We believe that a separate parliamentary service Bill warrants future consideration by the Parliament. This proposal would include such provisions as are necessary to establish a new framework, attuned to modern needs, for the employment of staff to service the Parliament. The Bill would include staffing provisions quite separate from the Public Service Act as a further demonstration of the independent powers and authority of the legislature over its own administration.

I believe that what we are seeking to put in place in this Bill is the most appropriate administrative structure at present to cope with the challenges facing the administration of the Parliament following its occupation of the new Parliament House. I will be advising the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and the Opposition parties that I will be seeking speedy passage of the Bill early in the Budget sittings. I present an explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1988EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 April, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: -I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill concurrently with the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Employment, Education and Training Bill 1988. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we debate two education Bills of a customary nature, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill and the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, providing cost adjustments in educational grants to the States, together with a major Bill of fundamental significance to the future of education and training in Australia; namely the Employment, Education and Training Bill 1988. The first two Bills contain measures over and above the cost supplementation provisions, but these are either unexceptionable or of insufficient concern to merit objection. However, to highlight the failure of the Government to provide sufficient places in higher education to meet the demand by qualified students and the failure of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding to find a satisfactory means of adding non-taxpayer resources for the expansion of higher education, I foreshadow the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its failure to provide sufficient resources to tertiary institutions for them to meet the demand for student places, or to find a satisfactory alternative source of funds for tertiary education'.

I remind honourable members that the Wran Committee proposals, vigorously supported by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), represent yet another clear breach of promises by a government with an already notorious record of broken promises. The Government entered the last election on a platform of free tertiary education. It was a promise the Government had no intention of keeping. By way of contrast, at the last election the Liberal and National parties, recognising the need for additional non-taxpayer resources for the expansion of higher education, proposed an entirely new method of funding which would have enabled the universities and colleges to attract the additional resources they need through their own efforts.

Under our plan, students meeting nationally determined entry standards would receive their education under a higher education scholarship scheme. Over and above the scholarship places, the institutions would be free to attract whatever number of additional students they wished on whatever fee basis they chose. Not only would they be able to admit many of the 25,000 or so qualified students now excluded because of lack of places under the Labor Government's policy, but also they would be able to cater for the expanding market in continuing education. In an ever changing world, more and more people want to update or improve their understanding of various subjects, and many are able and willing to pay for this opportunity. As I visit today's universities and colleges I observe a potential for innovative and entrepreneurial activity in designing courses for this expanding market, an activity that is repressed under existing Government regulations.

In our 1987 policy, we also undertook to promote loan arrangements for those students not gaining a scholarship and needing support to meet the fees charged by an institution. Under our policy, the qualifying students would be guaranteed a free place and no student would be denied a place. Under Australian Labor Party (ALP) policy, foreign students can buy a place while Australian students are excluded.

Needless to say, the ALP attacked our 1987 higher education policy as a `fees through the back door' policy. It was nothing of the kind. It was open and honest, in clear contrast to the ALP approach of promising exactly the reverse of what it now proposes after winning the election. Intending students would have been quite thoroughly misled about Labor intentions had they read of the now Minister's comprehensive attack on the Fraser Government's proposals to introduce a modest fee system for second degrees, coupled with a student loan scheme. Let me quote the then shadow Minister for Education, now the Minister, in a speech to this Parliament on 21 October 1981:

None of those serious problems which confront us in terms of the policy for tertiary education are in any way alleviated-I suggest that they are greatly exacerbated-by the imposition of tertiary tuition fees generally. It is not just that we are interested in opposing these fees for the group of students who will have to pay them. We are opposed to the re-establishment of the principle of tertiary tuition fees in general.

Perfidy of this order is not yet the norm in Australian politics, but this Government seems determined to make it so. When I hear the Minister's assurances as to the future funding of higher education arising from the imposition of the Wran tax I am reminded of its promise of continuing free tertiary education, and I give his assurances the same weight.

The fact is that the Wran graduate tax is a revenue measure, not an education measure. It is a new Labor tax, to be levied on those already paying more dollars in tax and higher marginal rates of tax. The Green Paper on higher education said that higher education should rely less on tax, yet Wran has proposed more tax. The Minister has said that the revenue derived from the new tax will go into a trust fund to ensure it is used for higher education, to provide places for the 25,000 students now excluded. Such an assurance would be worthless, even if one had, by virtue of his record, any confidence in the Minister's assurances. For a start, additions to the trust fund could be offset by reductions in the funds drawn from general revenue as part of each year's tussle between the Minister for Finance and the spending departments, and we all know Senator Walsh's attitude towards higher education funding. He is an unashamed high fees man, who will keep the shears clicking around the Minister's sheep. In addition, the delay in the build-up of tax revenue under the scheme, coupled with the offsets recommended by the Wran Committee, means that very few dollars can be drawn from the trust fund for some years. Students waiting at the gate to be admitted under this scheme will have grey hair and grandchildren before the Minister's promise is fulfilled.

What of Labor's much vaunted concern about equity? The Wran tax plan makes no distinction between rich and poor, except to say that the rich will be able to pay the fees up front with a 40 per cent discount, while the poor are indiscriminately lumbered with the tax for up to 20 years of their working life. Contrast also the provision of a student from a poor family with no previous history of higher education with that of, say, the dependent spouse of a wealthy man. The former will not exactly be encouraged to accumulate a future inescapable tax burden, while the latter can enjoy a free education merely by not working after the course is completed: equity 1988 Labor style! Of course one could also avoid the liability by going overseas after graduation, surely the kind of incentive we want to avoid.

Before turning to the main Bill, I note in passing that the Government is proposing an amendment to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill to provide for second tier wage increases. Whilst not wishing to deny academics their salary increases-and it has to be said that good academics are not well paid at present-the Government's support for second tier wage increases was predicated on the negotiation of productivity agreements designed to offset at least the additional cost. That principle seems to have been lost in this particular case. I am not aware of any such agreements having been negotiated in the tertiary education sector.

I turn now to the Employment, Education and Training Bill 1988, a most significant measure which proposes a completely new advisory framework within the area of the Minister's portfolio. It is a disgrace that this important Bill is being rushed through the Parliament at the very end of this session, with only two hours allowed for debate on this and the two other Bills in the House of Representatives before the gag is applied. Not only does this procedure deny honourable members adequate time for debate on the policy implications of the measure, but it also makes it impossible for the Opposition to move amendments and have them debated and voted upon during the committee stage. I had intended that the Opposition not oppose the Bill at its second reading but seek to amend it in committee, and then if the most important amendments were not accepted by the Government to vote against the Bill on the third reading. Denied this opportunity, I advise the House that we find the Bill unacceptable in its present form and we will vote against it on the second reading. I foreshadow that we will move a number of amendments in the Senate. I shall later ask that these amendments be incorporated in Hansard, so that honourable members will at least have the opportunity to see them, if not to debate and vote on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a shame. It is a pity you did not show them to me.

—The Minister asks why I did not show them to him. I have shown him the first set, but they have been progressively developed over the course of this last week or so because of the very large number of representations from people who are extremely concerned about the nature of the proposal. The Minister has enormous resources at his disposal. I do not, nor do the people who are making these representations to me. Therefore, it has been something of a scramble to get all the representations from the interested bodies and to draw up these amendments. The final draft of the amendments was only completed just before this debate was brought on.

SPEECH.PARA: With this Bill, the Government seeks to replace important advisory systems in the areas of employment, education and training with a system that is admittedly more streamlined, less messy and cheaper to run than the systems it replaces. In eliminating the untidiness that the Minister finds awkward and distasteful, it also eliminates any public avenue of dissent from the Minister's wishes. Two of the existing bodies to be abolished, the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC), although required to respond to Government guidelines, were able to initiate inquiries and report publicly and independently to the Government on school and tertiary education policy issues. Whilst not too many tears need be shed for the removal of the regulatory functions of the Schools Commission and CTEC which intruded far too much into the affairs of State governments and tertiary institutions, there is a need for informed advice, publicly offered to the Government, on educational issues. The future shape of our schools, technical and further education colleges, colleges of advanced education and our universities cannot be decided behind the closed doors of a Federal department or a Minister's office, or by boards or committees under the immediate and suffocating control of the Department or the Minister. Yet this is precisely what the new structure, headed by the proposed National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET), does.

The Board is to consist of not more than 13 persons, of whom five may be full time appointments, two will be drawn from the trade unions and two from business. Although there is a provision that at least seven of the 13 shall have expertise in education or training, some of those seven could be drawn from the five full time members or from the four trade union and business representatives. Thus, although the appearance of a majority of people with relevant expertise is given, there is a large majority of union, business and full time Public Service members: two plus two plus five equals nine out of 13. Although the full time members might be drawn from education or training backgrounds, they are most likely to absorb the Canberra culture and become creatures of the Minister. Indeed, since the Minister will choose them, they might well begin as creatures of the Minister. Another deficiency of the membership criteria for the Board is the absence of any requirement for people with scientific or technological backgrounds. This is a serious deficiency, for not only do these disciplines play a major role in education and training, NBEET also has responsibility for the Australian Research Council (ARC). If NBEET is to understand what the ARC is saying, it should have the necessary expertise amongst its membership.

There is such widespread concern about the make-up of NBEET within the educational and scientific communities that we propose to move substantive amendments to the Bill in the Senate to alter the composition of NBEET. We propose that trade union and business representation be reduced from two each to one each; that the maximum number of full time appointments be reduced from five to three; and that in addition to there being a requirement for a minimum of seven with expertise in education and training, there also be a requirement for a minimum of two from scientific research and technology. The Government's proposals for the structure of NBEET reflect its corporatist approach, allowing governments, trade unions and business to dominate its proceedings. Our proposal reduces the government, union and business combination from nine to five out of 13, providing a better balance of forces in a body having a profound influence on education and research in Australia.

Our next concern relates to the four councils that report to NBEET. These are designed to be well and truly under the thumb of NBEET and the Minister. According to our reading of the Bill, they could have as chairpersons full time members of NBEET, appointed by the Minister and on his payroll. There are no criteria regarding the expertise of the chairpersons. The councils can only consider and report on matters referred to them by the Minister or NBEET. They have no power of initiation or publication. Their reports to NBEET and the Minister can be censored on grounds of confidentiality or summarised by NBEET before they are published. They have no separate staffing, relying entirely on the Director of NBEET, who is an officer of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, for their staff support. To add insult to incapacity, they are required to take the advice of a curious appointee of the Minister called a counsellor, to whom I shall refer again later.

Grave concerns have already been expressed in the scientific community about one of these councils already set up on an interim basis, the Australian Research Council, which has the capacity, if not properly established and conducted, to do immense harm to Australia's scientific, research and technological developments for years ahead. We cannot stand by and let this happen without determined efforts to set at least certain minimal standards of powers and operations for the Council. The Minister would still have the capacity to nullify the effectiveness of the councils by administrative action, but at least he could not do so without considerable public fuss, provided our amendments are accepted.

We propose the following changes: firstly, all four council chairpersons must be part time. As part time members of NBEET also, they will have a heavy public workload, but at least they could have an independence from the Minister impossible for a full time appointee. Secondly, regard would have to be had to the relevance of experience and expertise of each chairperson to the subject matter of the Council. In the case of the chairperson of the ARC, the four learned academies-science, humanities, technological science and engineering, and social sciences-would have to be consulted before the appointment was made. Thirdly, each of the councils would be able to initiate inquiries and publish reports without the approval of the Minister.

Fourthly, NBEET would lose its power to censor council reports on grounds of confidentiality, or to summarise reports before publication. Fifthly, NBEET would have removed the severe limitation on its own independent action imposed by subclause 7 (2), which allows it to initiate a matter not referred to it by the Minister only if it `does not prejudice the performance of its functions' as required by the Minister. Sixthly, NBEET would be given the power to delegate any of its functions to a council. I stress that none of the above amendments relating to initiation and publication is a radical departure from Commonwealth Schools Commission or Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission practice. All we are attempting to do is restore the capacity for informed public debate on matters of vital concern to the whole Australian community. That facility was there before this Minister was appointed. It should remain during his tenure and endure after he has departed.

As I said earlier, the position of counsellor needs to be examined closely. Clause 56 of the Bill provides for the appointment by the Minister of up to four counsellors to give advice to the Minister on matters relating to the functions of the Board or a council. A council is required to consider advice from a counsellor. Thus counsellors may be completely outside the NBEET and council advisory structure, but may have very considerable influence on the matters within their purview. I would not deny that the Minister may need such persons to assist with complex matters requiring special expertise. It would be better, however, for them to report directly either to the chairperson of NBEET or of a council. We will move an amendment seeking to ensure that this happens.

The remaining matters I wish to refer to today relate to the work of the Schools Council. As with CTEC in the area of tertiary education, it is a matter of grave concern that the depth of expertise available in the former Schools Commission will not be available in the limited departmental support to NBEET and its councils. There is little we can do about that from the Opposition benches. All we can do is draw attention to the shortcoming and warn the Minister that he faces grave problems with his clientele in education in the future because of this deficiency.

However, we can at least by amendment require the Schools Council, in the exercise of its functions, to consult with and cooperate with those who actually run our schools, in both the government and non-government sectors. In addition, we believe that we should reflect the growing concern among parents, employers and the community generally about educational standards and discipline in schools. Accordingly, we seek to add to the objectives to be borne in mind by the Schools Council these two elements-that is, educational standards and discipline-which are missing from the list of objectives carried over from the Schools Commission.

The Bill, in addition to setting up the NBEET structure, also provides for the transformation of the Commonwealth Employment Service from an independent body to a component of the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The Opposition does not oppose that, but I will leave it to my colleague the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), shadow Minister for employment, training and youth affairs, to deal with that section of the Bill.

As I said earlier in my speech, it is a disgrace that such an important measure as this should have to be dealt with so hurriedly, without the House of Representatives even having time to consider detailed amendments. We will need to leave that task to our colleagues in the House of review, itself under threat from this Government's referendum proposals. If ever there were a case for a Senate not tied to the House of Representatives, this must be it. The NBEET structure seeks to gather excessive powers over the future of our whole education and training system and our research and technology into the hands of the Minister. It represents Labor corporate statism at its most sinister. It must be resisted in this Parliament, and by virtue of the powers of the Senate, we are hopeful that it can be resisted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to address the three education Bills before the House because beyond doubt education, particularly higher education, can be the key to open the door to career opportunities. That was shown in a national survey undertaken by the Careers Council of Australia, which revealed that 3.6 per cent of graduates in the labour force were unemployed in 1987 compared with 9.1 per cent of the labour force as a whole. Although at times statistics can be unreliable, these were backed up by other work undertaken by the Sydney University.

SPEECH.PARA: Every Australian who is willing and qualified should have access to this key. Higher education has many benefits which are all so difficult to evaluate in monetary terms. Not only can a university degree or a college diploma be the key to the world of more interesting jobs-although certainly not exclusively so-but also the gaining of higher education qualifications in itself brings benefits such as the added confidence necessary to break the cycle of acceptance of limited job opportunities and to enter new fields of endeavour, and no-one who desires it should be denied the opportunity of participating in higher education.

The reality in Australia today is that tens of thousands of people are annually denied access to our institutions of higher learning. Not only is the concept of free education a myth, because taxpayers fund tertiary courses to the tune of approximately $10,000 to $70,000 depending upon the degree, but also access to higher education, at the price of tax payments and the higher education administration fee, is severely restricted. The assumption that since the Whitlam Government abolished up-front tertiary fees the doors of learning and career opportunity have been open to those who qualify for entry is erroneous. No statistics are available to reveal the number of young Australians who enter the work force at leaving level as a result of parents' inability to forgo their supplementation of the family budget, but empirical evidence suggests that this runs into the thousands. Up to 20,000 students are on record as being denied access to higher education every year as the tertiary entrance (TE) score is used to impose a quota on entry; nor can one assume that these students are not intellectually equipped to manage a course of higher education. But retention rates to year 12 under this Government have increased from 36.3 per cent in 1982 to a current 53.1 per cent. As a result of this growth and the limited tertiary places available, a distorted situation has evolved whereby the top achievers in TE not only absorb university places available in law, science, medicine and economics but also encroach on the humanities places and flow on to secure places in diploma courses in colleges of advanced education and technical and further education, positions that were once the domain of the applicants who are now missing out. Stable workers with creditable results are being kept out of our institutions.

For this reason the Federal Government has taken a long, hard look at Australia's education system and the way it operates. For the sake of the army of young Australians who are missing out on the drive for higher education, we must turn our backs on the comfortable political option of skulking in the shadows and merely maintaining the status quo.

Although the contribution of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) on the new National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) and its make-up was thoughtful, we reject the alternative of scholarships and tertiary fees suggested by the honourable member, whose comments on it were way out and hypocritical. Certainly we do not have free education, but when one is discussing access to education, the up-front fees which the honourable member for Mackellar would have us believe are modest will keep out thousands of young Australians whose parents, or themselves individually, would not be able to afford any fees up front. Scholarships do not fill the bill; they would be a reversal to the days of decades ago when thousands upon thousands of students were kept out of the education system and only the elite and more affluent were allowed in. The Government cannot accept such recommendations or policies.

The system needs a shake-up. There should not be two populations-those who have access to our nation's higher education and the projected growth, and those who do not. The Bills, specifically the Employment, Education and Training Bill, which enshrines in legislation the new education board, NBEET, that is designed to oversee the necessary changes, are a part but just a small part of the overall shake-up.

I shall briefly comment on the two States grants Bills. The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988 provides additional funds for adjustments for cost movements to existing grants for 1988 appropriated under the principal Act in line with agreed Government procedures. It provides funding to meet the additional cost to higher education institutions of the 3 per cent superannuation claim. It also enables emerging costs in the States to be met. Under section 15 of the principal Act higher education institutions are entitled to supplementary funding to meet increased superannuation costs. An increase in the provision in the legislation has become necessary because of a higher than anticipated rate of retirements in some States. Ten medical schools will each receive some $55,000 under the Commonwealth's contribution to the drug and alcohol coordination program. Nine of these have already put forward agreed proposals for participation in the program. I am very pleased to commend that Bill and particularly that program to the House.

The States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1988 amends the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act to supplement existing financial provisions to take into account an increase in price levels. It has a number of other roles. It modifies eligibility provisions of non-government schools for grants, changes the conditions of eligibility for non-government schools to receive establishment grants and restricts eligibility for grants under the general education element of the English as a second language program to persons who have permanent residency status in Australia. It also amends the definition of full fee paying private overseas secondary students to apply to part time as well as full time students, and corrects minor drafting and printing errors in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act.

The Bill provides an estimated $21m increase in appropriations for the schools program in 1988, bringing the 1988 schools funding to an estimated total of $1,760m. The Government has been providing funds for additional higher education intakes since 1984. Queensland has really benefited from moves under this Government. The Federal Government has made a more than proportionate allocation to Queensland, following assessments of current levels of participation and unmet demand, likely future demand and the need for opportunities in regional areas. As a result of this policy, the number of higher education places in Queensland is estimated to have increased, between 1983 and 1988, by over 11,000 or 32 per cent, compared with a nationwide growth of 26 per cent.

The House will recall that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) in December 1987 released a policy discussion paper proposing a range of measures designed to achieve further growth in higher education and to extend opportunities to those who have not traditionally participated in higher education. This move followed the drawing together of the portfolios representing education, jobs and job training under the new superministry of employment, education and training. The move was taken because of a government perception that past neglect, when allied with economic and structural changes, had denied young Australians the opportunity to realise their full potential, both personally and in terms of national economic performance. To put it bluntly, they had not been getting a fair go. As the Dawkins-Holding report Skills for Australia described it, this benign neglect on the part of past governments and administrators had created an urgent need for structural adjustment in Australia.

The structural weaknesses in Australia's external position were compounded by the sharp falls since 1985-86 in the world prices of many of our traditional exports. We now need urgently to broaden our trading base by expanding our manufacturing and service sectors where appropriate, so that they can export more and compete efficiently with imports. To do this, we have to look not only at improved relative costs but also at non-price factors, and these include innovation, skills and technology. In this context education and training are to play a central role in responding to the major economic challenges which still confront us. Without disputing or belittling the achievements of the past, we must acknowledge the need for dramatic change in our attitudes to education and skills formation, and we must do so now. Our young people will be major beneficiaries of this change. In this context the Employment, Education and Training Bill, in enabling the establishment of the new National Board of Employment, Education and Training, represents a major milestone in the integration of policies and programs to improve the competitiveness and skills of the Australian work force. Previously the Government received advice on research, training, employment, higher education, schools and curriculum from a large number of uncoordinated advisory bodies in three separate portfolios.

This Bill consolidates these disparate structures into a single cohesive advisory body, the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, which will provide independent advice to the Government on employment, education, training and research policies and programs. The new advisory structure complements the improved portfolio arrangements, which for the first time recognise the critical interdependence between employment, work force training and education programs and policies.

Time prevents my going further into the details of the Board, but I am sure that my very able colleagues on this side will be going into further detail. I would like to complete my comments with the point that the build-up that led to the lack of places in higher education institutions that we have today took place over many decades. We do not want to return to a situation where, as the potential growth which is starting to occur becomes a reality, we do not have trained and educated people to take those places and have to follow the old trail of importing graduates from overseas. That does not make sense.

Sitting back and knocking the very difficult task that is before us also does not make sense. What we need in Australia is a coordinated effort. We need support from people on both sides of the House. We need support from educators, from educational institutions, from employers, from unions, from students and from young people, and we need to look at recommendations with one purpose in mind. This is what we are now doing as we look at the Wran recommendations. We want to ensure that equity and access to education become a reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to speak as the Opposition spokesman on employment, training and youth affairs. In the normal course of events, when responding to Government legislation an Opposition spokesman might be expected to speak for 30 minutes. It is not only convention; it is also laid down in our Standing Orders. But that will not be the case on this occasion because in this debate we have been led by my colleague the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I do not complain about the lack of my speaking time on that score, because of the excellent contribution that he made, and I am very happy to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to compound my personal problem by, in a sense, wasting some of my speaking time by talking about the way in which these Bills-the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Employment, Education and Training Bill-are being handled in this House. I say that I will waste some of my speaking time because I would like to have, and I hope in the future to have, more time to speak about the very substantial issues under the heading of employment and training that are raised by this legislation.

By using the word `waste' I have obviously made a personal judgment that it is worth while doing, because, whilst the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is no longer in the chamber, I hope he can hear me in his office. Perhaps on the basis of these remarks he will be encouraged to come back into the chamber so that I might through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, speak to him, in a sense, directly.

We on this side of the House find the way in which these Bills are being handled to be completely unacceptable; indeed, I would think it is both wrong and unsatisfactory from the Minister's point of view and from the Government's point of view. Prior to the July 1987 election I was the shadow Minister for education, and I can say from that background that this is not the first time we have had a cognate debate on education matters, when very important Bills have been grouped together. That in itself cuts down the speaking time and the time available to this House to consider those Bills. To make matters worse, this is not the first time that we have had a guillotined debate, where members limit their own speaking time voluntarily so that they can give their colleagues a go. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) did that, and I recognise her reason for doing that.

We stand foursquare with the Government in recognising the importance of education, employment and training matters; and we put forward in a very serious and considered way the proposition that in future we should no longer compound the errors of the past. In future we should no longer, without a great deal of thought, simply conduct a cognate debate on such matters-especially in these circumstances where we are dealing with schools assistance, tertiary assistance and the very considerable changes that are being made to the whole system of education and training in this country under the Employment, Education and Training Bill. We should no longer consider that we should automatically bring legislation such as that together in a cognate debate. Certainly we should no longer blindly accept that we should operate under a guillotine.

If this situation is not the fault of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, certainly he should have spent more time trying to persuade the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) of the desirability of conducting this debate in the absence of the guillotine. Why should I say that? I have said that this is not the first time we have had a cognate debate and I have said that this is not the first time that we have had a guillotine truncated debate. Let me also say that this is not the first time that the Opposition has been forced to foreshadow amendments and, hopefully, get them included in the House of Representatives Hansard but then the major debate has taken place in the Senate.

When I was shadow Minister for education I had to put up with that. Indeed, I accepted it in part because the then Minister, Susan Ryan, was in the Senate. So at least I could realistically accept the major debate going on in the Senate. We had the Minister in the Senate, and the Opposition was lucky enough to have some former Ministers for education in the Senate, Senator Peter Baume being foremost amongst those. But now we have this farcical situation with a major piece of legislation-I do not refer to the annual or biannual pieces of legislation, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill or the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill-the Employment, Education and Training Bill, which basically changes so many of the fundamental ground rules for the way in which we administer education, employment and training in Australia, which basically changes just how we will operate from a government point of view. We have the farcical situation where the amendments will be moved in the Senate, the major debate will take place in the Senate, and we do not even have the Minister or the Opposition spokesman in the Senate. I think that is ludicrous.

The Government is likely to pay a very heavy price for that ludicrous situation, because it is likely now that the Government will lose this Bill in the Senate. Instead of there being a very serious and detailed consideration of the thoughtful amendment put forward by the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Mackellar; instead of there being some horse trading across the table in this chamber, so that the Government might have had the chance of seeing its legislation passed, having accepted some of the Opposition's amendments, none of that will happen in this chamber. We will have a set piece debate in which people will make observations and comments, without the opportunity to debate specifically the amendments. We are now forced to vote against the second reading motion at the end of this debate. Of course, with the Government's superior numbers, the Bills will go to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Superior intellect, as well as the numbers.

—I cannot believe that the honourable member would regard my comments on this matter as humorous. I again make the point that the major debate will take place in the Senate. The honourable member's spokesman and our spokesman are not in the Senate and the Government looks like losing the legislation. I find that incredible. The point that I want to make-and I know that the Minister can hear me through the sound system in this building-is that serious thought needs to be given to this matter so that this circumstance does not happen again. We share the view that education, employment and training matters are some of the most serious policy considerations or areas of concern that any government or Opposition might contemplate for the better government of Australia. And while we fundamentally disagree with many of the changes that are being put forward in this legislation, at so many levels of rhetoric, we agree with what the Government is on about. We agree with the need to make education and training more attuned to industry needs and the like. This situation is cause for enormous regret. I cannot believe that the Government or the Minister could be happy about this farcical situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Ten minutes or more of my time has transpired. Let me use the balance to try to make a few observations about only the Employment, Education and Training Bill and specifically those aspects of the Bill that relate to employment and training. Before doing so, I want, in passing, to point out that the Opposition's approach to education is in stark contrast to that of the Government. We very strongly believe in the need to give educational institutions a far greater degree of autonomy and independence. Against that background, I endorse all of the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar. In the Senate-because we cannot debate our amendments in the House of Representatives-we will support amendments which will alter the composition of the new board, which will give less emphasis to full time appointments and which will give the councils a greater freedom of inquiry and report. We will support amendments in the Senate which will give less emphasis to union and business representation and the full time Public Service members of the board and the councils.

Our proposed amendments are central to our efforts to reduce the corporatist approach and to ensure that we devolve the emphasis away from a bureaucratically centralised structure, which is what this Government is all about. Our position is quite simple: devolution is important if the proposed National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) is to have what the Opposition believes to be an appropriate enterprise-industry emphasis. Under this legislation, as yet unamended, NBEET lacks the independence to advise the Minister adequately. Australia would be much better served by having a strong independent source of advice to government. What must be borne in mind in this debate is that industry is the ultimate employer, and any initiatives on a national training strategy must reflect the current and projected demands of industry. The key to seeing that training meets these current and projected objectives is the retention of a maximum degree of flexibility and diversity. We get that by having an industry-enterprise emphasis and not a centralised, corporatist, bureaucratic emphasis, which is reflected in this legislation.

We on this side of the House recognise that members of the Australian labour force must be equipped with broadly based skills, and they must have flexibility if they are to retain their place in the work force in Australian industry and commerce which is undergoing rapid change. Australia has been hampered in the past-and is still hampered-by a narrow skills base compared with its major trading partners. There is a lot of substantive evidence to back up this pro- position. The Economic Planning Advisory Council released a report this week entitled An Overview of Microeconomic Constraints on Economic Growth. It identified barriers to growth in education and training, amongst many other things. Just two of the areas which that report identified as needing attention were improved labour mobility by means of multi-skilling and mid-career training-two enormous issues out there in the work places of Australia which need to be fully debated if we are to face up to this legislation and its consequences, unintended or otherwise.

The 1987 departmental report entitled Meeting Australia's Skill Needs details evidence which identifies labour shortages in a wide range of skilled occupations. Australia has labour shortages in a wide range of skilled occupations at a time when the unemployment rate is about 8 per cent and industry and commerce are screaming out for skilled migration. The skilled migration debate is the other side of the coin of the employment and training debate, and we do not have time to face up to those issues in this debate.

The Economic Planning Advisory Council produced an earlier paper in 1986 entitled Human Capital and Productivity Growth and in 1987 the Australian Science and Technology Council produced a document entitled Education and National Needs, both of which documented the fact that Australia lacks the education intensive skill base that underpins the economies of other developed nations such as Japan, West Germany and the United States.

To be clear about the problem, I will make the point I made a few minutes ago. That lack of skill base is criminal at a time when almost 630,000 Australians are looking for work and unable to find it, the national unemployment rate is hovering around the 8 per cent mark, the youth unemployment rate is hovering around the 20 per cent mark and the average duration of unemployment at 45.3 weeks is 12 weeks up on the 1983 average.

I foreshadow not another amendment but an attitude of the coalition when in government after the next election. We will no longer accept the argument peddled by some Government spokesmen that we must somehow accept a high level of unemployment and that in the face of technological change and the competitive world situation, Australia must put up with it, we must like it or lump it. We will not accept that when in government. We will not have a skerrick of complacency about a social, economic and community situation which sees 8 per cent of Australia's population unemployed and nearly 20 per cent of our children unemployed.

I shall make a few other observations. The Opposition agrees with the Government's stated objectives on lifting school retention rates. However, if one lifts those rates, one must focus closely on whether the opportunities are available for year 12 school leavers to get a further education; whether opportunities are available in technical and further education for school leavers in years 10 and 11 and, hopefully, year 12 to enter the technical and further education (TAFE) training stream; or whether year 12 school leavers will find employment. Any objective analysis shows that if the Government lifts the year 12 retention rates, there will be enormous problems on those three fronts.

We hear talk about 25,000 places of unmet demand in higher education. It was the Opposition that got that on the agenda a couple of years ago when it spoke about 14,000 potential students who could not get places because the system could not take them. The problem is getting worse and will continue to get worse. If young people can be encouraged to stay at school to the final year 12, obviously their horizons will be lifted and they will consider going on to higher education or technical and further education. If vice-chancellors and directors of institutes and colleges talk about unmet demands, honourable members should talk to TAFE directors or principals. They do not talk about 25,000 places Australia wide; they talk about 100,000 places Australia wide. The Government has to do much more on that front to provide opportunities in school to work transition.

I shall make an observation about training. We have not yet seen it fully played out, but the Government is flirting with the idea of a training levy on employers, either voluntary or compulsory. I clearly and categorically state that that is not the way to go. The best way to encourage a greater training effort at the industry and enterprise level, and not at the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), big business, big government level, is by means of a lower corporate tax rate, a deregulated economic environment and a flexible wages policy that includes a training wage.

In the last few minutes of my contribution, I am happy to refer to the Metal Trades Industry Association and its proposal for an agreement with the metal trades unions on training, career development and award restructuring. It is a pioneering document, and that is the way to go. One reads in the document about training wages and other major reforms where industry, at industry level with its work force, and enterprise, at enterprise level with its work force, are able to maximise training opportunities for young people and adult workers who need retraining.
On the question of a training wage, if one looks at page 46 of the 1987-88 Budget Paper No. 1, the following statement in relation to improving the supply of skilled labour is made:
Setting apprenticeship and trainee wage rates in line with the work productivity of trainees would help especially in the initial training period.

We do not need just an Australian traineeship system whereby we eke out of the environment a few places for a few trainees in a few industries and a few enterprises. We need an across the board flexible wages system that allows for an across the board training wage, so that it is economic again for employers to put on young people and to pay them at a rate commensurate with their productivity while they are learning and getting the necessary training that will stand them in good stead for a lifetime of work.

What is set out in Budget Paper No. 1 is directly in line with the Opposition's commitment, which I shall repeat around the country until I am bored with my own comments. That commitment is to implement a training wage that will compensate employers for the time and effort spent in providing workers of all ages with the skills they need in today's workplace. A training wage will do far more than any tinkering at the edges, any wage subsidy scheme or any Australian traineeship scheme to create much needed additional job opportunities.

The idea of a levy will give undue Government influence over the national training effort and make it far too removed from the workplace. The levy is straight out of the document of the ACTU entitled Australia Reconstructed, which is a manifesto and a blueprint for a centrally planned and bureaucratic economy. It is not the way to go and never will be. My only regret is that we will not have the opportunity in this place, where it should occur, to debate all of the aspects of this major legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members are used to hearing a certain amount of drivel from the Opposition, but the contributions from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) contained some high octane drivel indeed. One wonders whether there might be something in the water on the Opposition side of the House to have given both those honourable members a dose of amnesia this afternoon. They seem to have forgotten what went on in this House during the Opposition's period in government. During that period, cognate debates on these types of Bills were a matter of course; they happened year in and year out. The time allowed for these debates this afternoon, although not as characteristically generous as the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) would normally make available, is certainly more than the Liberal Party of Australia ever made available during its period in government.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members seem also to have forgotten that major changes in Federal bodies in education-changes in the administration of the Curriculum Development Centre and the Education Research and Development Committee, changes to the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission in 1981-were not the subject of separate discussions in separate Bills. Those matters were all brought in in the report of the review of Commonwealth functions in 1981.

The amendment the honourable member for Mackellar has moved attempts to condemn the Government for its alleged failure to provide sufficient resources to meet student demand or to find alternative sources of funds for tertiary education. It ignores the Australian Labor Party's record in government and the Opposition's record in government. It misrepresents the Liberal Party's policies and it misrepresents the recommendations of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding.

I direct the attention of the House to the record of this Government in providing student places in tertiary education. In its first four years, this Government provided an additional 36,800 new places. In the last four years of Liberal government, 8,100 places were provided; 36,800 were provided under this Government a little after the time when just over 8,000 were provided under the Liberal Party. The policy on which the Opposition failed last year, in July, provided for no additional places in the tertiary sector. It provided that any extra places could be paid for by fees up front negotiated between students and institutions or by loans. Where is the equity in that proposal? Where is the access for underprivileged groups in society under that proposal?

I remind the House that the report of the Wran Committee is set firmly in the context of expansion of the sector proposed in the Green Paper. The Green Paper proposes that the number of graduates per year should rise from the present 88,000 to 125,000 by the turn of the century. At the current rate of graduation, this implies that by the turn of the century, there will be between 180,000 and 200,000 additional places. Currently the Commonwealth spends around $3 billion on the tertiary sector. That is not counting almost $2 billion in student assistance. The extra places, based on current graduation rates, would cost of the order of $1.2 billion and, clearly, that money cannot come from the Budget.

The excellent analysis of the Wran Committee identifies the beneficiaries of the system: society, industry and graduates themselves. It concludes that each should make a contribution. Society will continue to do so through the general taxation pool. The role of industry in making contributions is to be investigated by a tripartite committee. Finally, the recommendation of the Committee is that graduates, when they are in a position to pay, should make a contribution. Bearing in mind that tertiary graduates enjoy lower unemployment, more satisfying jobs and a higher level of salary than average, it is not unreasonable to expect that the major beneficiaries of the system should make a contribution. I find the critics of the Wran recommendations short on style and short on substance. The honourable member for Mackellar this afternoon was certainly no exception.

I wish to turn now to deal specifically with the programs covered by clause 22 of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill. Clause 22 provides for $2.47m for the States for programs of adult education, including adult literacy programs. The extended adult illiteracy in Australia is not known with any accuracy, but a survey carried out in Sydney in 1974 by Dr Judith Goyen found that 3.7 per cent of native English speaking respondents were functionally illiterate. They were unable to follow simple STD telephone dialling instructions and classified housing and employment advertisements or to read a job application form. The finding for those respondents born in non-English speaking countries was a staggering illiteracy rate of 43.3 per cent. Overall, 9 per cent of the sample lacked `survival literacy' skills. An extrapolation of Dr Goyen's 1974 figures to the 1981 census suggested that at that time there was a total of 1.189 million illiterate adult Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —The hidden problem.

—Exactly. Bringing those figures up to date with the 1986 census, one can reason- ably conclude that there are 1.272 million illiterate adult Australians. I shall quote briefly from Dr Goyen's comments on her study. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: What is perhaps surprising is that any of those educated in Australia or some other English speaking country should have failed this simple test. If 3.7% fail a test that demands little more than the reading of words and sentences, then one can predict that a much higher proportion would have failed a test that demanded the reading of passages of prose. That is, a substantial proportion of the adult population must be of ``marginal'' literacy when it comes to reading the many notices, forms, instructions and information leaflets that form part of our everyday life.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could not even read Hansard.

—That is right-and what a shocking loss! There is no single cause for adult illiteracy. The Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, in its 1985 report entit- led A National Language Policy, listed the most common explanations-poverty, broken schooling, illness, change of school, emotional upset, cultural deprivation, poor teaching at school, lack of adult education and lack of adherence to the concept of education as a continuous process throughout life. These were all identified by that Senate Standing Committee as possible explanations for adult illiteracy. To that list we must add what one researcher has referred to as the `onslaught of the audio-visual age'. It is quite clear-I think we can all accept this-that the impact of television and radio and telephone have been forces leading many in the population away from reading as an activity to listening and watching.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of adult illiteracy have very wide effects indeed. They affect participation in employment, in industry and in society. At the work place, deficiencies in literacy diminish skills of the work force as a whole and, therefore, indirectly affect national economic growth. At a personal level, illiteracy restricts personal advancement and flexibility in the work place. There is clearly a reduced ability to transfer to other jobs. Those in the workplace who are unable to read and understand simple safety instructions are obviously more prone to industrial accidents.

Some time ago, the South Australian Literacy Board made a film called Can't You Bloody Well Read. The title came about as a result of an incident in a factory in which the foreman went berserk when he saw a worker had ignored a warning sign and was using a power tool without the safety guard. He yelled, `Look mate, can't you bloody well read?'. He could not, and hence the film.

Illiterates suffer higher rates of unemployment. A survey of adult literacy students in Victoria showed that that group had four times the average rate of unemployment experienced in Victoria at that time. Those illiterate people who are in work often tend to be concentrated in unskilled and semi-skilled occupations. Of course, as those jobs tend to dry up, as those jobs requiring lower literacy skills decline, those people also suffer decreasing employability. In society as a whole, those with low levels of literacy are more likely to be dependent on welfare. They are less likely to take full advantage of leisure opportunities available to them, and simple activities such as shopping and banking become very difficult, and tasks such as voting become well nigh impossible.

The remedies are quite clear. There is a need for more literacy programs. In 1986, apart from the adult migrant education program, there were only 440 adult literacy programs across Australia. The funding that this Bill provides will certainly assist this process, but adult literacy has been left to the States for far too long. There is also a second remedy-the need for use of plain English, particularly in Government publications. I shall again quote briefly from the comments of Dr Judith Goyen. She said:

As the Government brochures that I look at appear to be more difficult than the test passages used in the surveys, it is possible that an even greater proportion of the population would have difficulty in reading Government publications.

Shortly there will be a booklet dealing with the Yes and No cases for the referendum questions. It will be distributed to each and every household in Australia. Based on the figures that we have, more than one million Australians will be unable to read that booklet and, therefore, exercise their democratic rights. All honourable members would have encountered people in their electorate offices who have experienced great difficulty with various departmental forms. It is not a bad exercise, as a local member, to actually try to fill out one of the forms, to go into a Medicare office and try to fill out a Medicare claim form, or to examine the forms from the Department of Social Security or the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, to realise just how difficult they can be. These forms have improved in recent times. The design has become clearer, but there is still room for improvement and for more care in their preparation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in plain English.

—That is right. A couple of weeks ago in a local newspaper circulating in my electorate and in the electorate of the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) there was an article by Telecom Australia inviting people to apply for free access to directory assistance. Honourable members will recall that directory assistance is to be charged for shortly, but certain groups will not be subject to the charge. People who can establish that they are disabled or print handicapped can apply to Telecom and their telephones will be exempt from the charge. Telecom is using an interesting process to identify those people who qualify. The second paragraph in the article in my local newspaper says that persons who find it difficult or impossible to read may apply for an exemption. That is a great start. I went along to the local post office and picked up the form `Application for Directory Assistance Exemption for a Private Telephone'. The first few lines are not too bad. They ask for one's given names and family name. I suppose that one could battle through that. Then the `name of lessee of service if different from above' is asked for, and a few other particulars. It then says:

SPEECH.PARA: I declare that the details given on this form are accurate, and that I am Print Handicapped in line with the definition of the term `Print Handicapped', as given over the page.

Over the page there is quite a bit more. One has to read halfway down the page to find out where one fits in to the print handicapped category. Adult literacy comes in here. I know that Telecom has a difficult job, but newspaper articles and producing forms like this to identify the print handicapped is perhaps not quite the way to go about it. Given that Telecom spends quite a bit of money on television advertising, I would have thought that it would not have been beyond Telecom to have run a television campaign on this matter so that the print handicapped could apply for the exemption they are clearly entitled to. I realise that it is difficult to communicate with the print handicapped, but the challenge has to be met.

I know that we cannot incorporate cartoons in Hansard, but a lovely cartoon appeared in the Bulletin in 1985 on exactly this point. It shows a perplexed gentleman looking at a brick wall on which there are two posters. The first poster says, `Illiterates meeting this Saturday night at 8.00 p.m.', and the second poster says, `If you couldn't read the last notice, please turn up anyway'. It is a serious problem. Over one million adult Australians are affected. It is a problem that demands a nationally coordinated effort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the comments of my colleagues the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) on the important issues raised in these three Bills, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill and the Employment, Education and Training Bill. I hope to speak at more length on these vital matters at some other time. In the limited time available to me I want to deal specifically with the case for establishing a tertiary education institution on the mid-north coast of New South Wales. I have made representations on behalf of the Coffs Harbour City Council to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I take this opportunity to thank the Minister for his courtesy, and his personal staff for their helpfulness in arranging a meeting for me next week to meet the Chairman of the Higher Education Council. I raise this matter now because it is absolutely vital for the future education needs of the people of northern New South Wales and, in particular, the north coast that this move is included for funding in the 1989-91 triennium.

SPEECH.PARA: The case for establishing an institute of higher education on the mid-north coast is absolutely compelling. The north coast region, from Taree to the Queensland border east of the Great Dividing Range, has the fastest growing population of any region in New South Wales. Within the north coast region the mid-north coast is the fastest growing sub-region. Coffs Harbour city is estimated to have a population of 50,000 by June 1988. It is estimated that there is a population in excess of 100,000 within commuting distance of Coffs Harbour, sufficient to generate 1,000 tertiary students locally in the region.

The north coast region already has a population equivalent to that of Tasmania. The north coast region has the lowest per capita provision of higher education places of any region in New South Wales, including the western suburbs of Sydney, which have been singled out to get special treatment. On the statistics, the north coast is far more deserving than the western suburbs of Sydney. Lack of contact with a higher education institution leads to reduced awareness of educational and career opportunities stemming from advanced study. Hence, school-leavers' goals are not directed towards university or college of advanced education courses. The cost of transport and accommodation inhibits many young local people from seeking a place in a distant higher education institution. Increasing difficulty in gaining admission to a higher education institution prevents qualified young people from enhancing their future career prospects.

Opportunities for part time higher education study are totally lacking on the mid-north coast. We have very high unemployment rates, especially of unskilled young people, on the north coast which point to a need for expanded education and training opportunities to enhance employability. Coffs Harbour city is very accessible. It is a transport focus, being at approximately the centre of the north coast region. It is located directly on the Pacific Highway and the main north coast railway and has a recently upgraded jet airport also heavily used by commuter airlines. It is well served by inter- and intra-State coach services, some 44 a day.

Coffs Harbour has the existing infrastructure to support and service new major developments such as an institute of higher education. The allocation of a magnificent site of 80 to 120 hectares has already been made to Coffs Harbour City Council as a free gift by a major developer specifically for a higher education campus to the value of $2.3m. The land is there already. We are ready to go. Student accommodation of 400 to 600 places is immediately available in the older tourist units and flats during term time. This would complement the holiday lettings.

There is strong community support within Coffs Harbour city for the establishment of a higher education institution there. The project also has the strong backing of Coffs Harbour City Council and of neighbouring, fast-growing shires. A public meeting held in Coffs Harbour on 23 March attracted 600 people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred?

—Given the population of Coffs Harbour, if we translated that 600 to Sydney terms we would be talking about a meeting of many thousands of people. The New South Wales Minister for Education and the Higher Education Council have given approval in principle to the development of higher education courses in Coffs Harbour. The proposed campus site is considered to be magnificent-it is-and could be shared with new technical and further education developments. The City Council has been encouraged in its negotiations with existing institutions in regard to `parenting', a move which would be approved of by this Government. In particular, the University of Newcastle and the Hunter Institute of Higher Education, formerly the Newcastle College of Advanced Education, have been most supportive. Senior staff have already had several discussions in Coffs Harbour, and the University of New England has expressed interest as well.

SPEECH.PARA: While an extensive range of traditional courses, with support facilities, may take time to develop, existing local resources could enhance some specialist studies perceived to be particularly relevant to this area. These include business studies and new technologies, specialising in tourism management, small business, accounting, computing, and technical advances; sub-tropical horticulture and marketing, specialising in intensive practices such a hydroponics, tropical and sub-tropical fruits and nuts with export potential, tea and coffee, naturally occurring oils and some chemicals. We would also be looking, perhaps at courses in resource management, specialising in marine science; visual and performing arts courses; and social and welfare studies.

The region has a high aged population. In my electorate of Cowper the population aged 65 years and over is approximately 50 per cent higher than it is in the rest of Australia. We have a lot of children. We have high unemployment and severe drug problems, as has the rest of Australia. So social and welfare studies would be most appropriate. The region contains the remnants of local tribes, sacred sites, burial grounds and middens, so Aboriginal history and archaeology courses would also be appropriate.

In summary, the case for the establishment of a university or other higher education institution in Coffs Harbour in the electorate of Cowper is compelling. It would provide and extend educational opportunities in full and part time study and become a centre for research. It would develop as a focus for enhanced intellectual and cultural experience for the general population. It would provide a boost to commerce and industry. It would provide an extensive range of employment opportunities. It would provide welcome additional facilities which would be available to the whole community. It would complement tourism and, being established in the region of the fastest sustained population growth in New South Wales, it would be well located to help meet the need for additional places for potential higher education students. This will be especially necessary as the effects of the Government's policy of encouraging school students to continue studies to the end of year 12 become apparent.
