I appeal to the Minister to exercise vision and to make provision for funding this exciting and necessary educational development in the 1989-91 triennium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my contribution to the debate on these three Bills I intend to concentrate on the Employment, Education and Training Bill and in particular the provisions contained in it for a restructuring of higher education. The Employment, Education and Training Bill is a key part of the long overdue reform of our education system. The Bill establishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET), four specialist advisory councils, and the Commonwealth-State Consultative Committee to provide the details and advise upon the reforms advocated by the Government in its discussion papers on higher education and training. This Bill is thus at the centre of the greatest changes to higher education in decades.

SPEECH.PARA: That a major shake-up in higher education is necessary should not be in doubt. Australia needs more graduates and a more appropriate mix of graduates. The Review of Efficiency and Effectiveness in Higher Education concluded that Australia's output of graduates in selected fields of study lagged by up to 45 per cent when compared with the leading North American countries. When all graduates, including those of two-year courses, are taken into account, Australia trails the United States of America by 33 per cent in proportional terms. The trend towards a greater proportion of graduates in technical and professional fields, which has been quite dramatic in the United States since 1970, has also been slow to occur in Australia.

A significant expansion of higher education is necessary for our future economic growth and for the achievement of greater equity of access to our higher education system. Substantial inequities in access remain for some groups in the population, particularly people from financially disadvantaged backgrounds, people from rural and isolated areas and Aboriginal people. Women's involvement in certain undergraduate disciplines and postgraduate study generally remains very limited. These inequities can be most effectively addressed by planned expansion of the higher education system. The indicative figure for growth in higher education used in the Government's policy discussion paper is 125,000 graduates per year by the year 2001, which would increase the proportion of the labour force with a degree or diploma from 10 per cent in 1986 to 15 per cent in 2001. This figure would still leave us significantly behind the comparable output of graduates in Canada and the United States and other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries.

To achieve the ambitious growth objectives required, our higher education system will need to question many of its traditional values and overcome its infamous inertia. A rapid increase in youth participation, improvement in graduation rates and an increase in access of adult students will all be necessary. To achieve this, institutions must look at a range of issues including admission standards, course length and content, course mix, bridging arrangements, timetabling and attrition rates. I also support the Government's view that changes in the structure and organisation of higher education are desirable. The division between universities, colleges of advanced education (CAEs) and the technical and further education (TAFE) system serves no relevant purpose and indeed is detrimental in many ways to the demands of a modern higher education system.

Growth in higher education will also require swift responses from State governments. They must assess their commitment to growth, particularly in two-year courses in TAFE and, together with non-government authorities, they must assess their policies on curriculum and teacher education. It is also essential that employers increase their involvement in higher education through participation in course development and assessment, and allowing access to their equipment and staff through cooperative education programs. Industry clearly has an obligation to increase its financial contribution to higher education. While the National Board of Education, Employment and Training and its subsidiary councils can focus attention on these desired changes in higher education, it is clear that the attitude of State governments, industry and the institutions themselves is crucial to the success of the Government's objectives.

I am pleased to say that in South Australia the State Government is at the forefront of moves to use higher education resources more effectively to address our pressing economic and social problems, and to meet the increasing need for an educated and skilled population. The State Government issued its own discussion paper on higher education in South Australia, including options for restructuring, in December 1987. The State Government will shortly release a White Paper on its preferred restructuring proposals and the Government intends to legislate on this matter later in the year. The South Australian Government has also recently released a report on immediate post-compulsory education which investigates higher education selection criteria, the nature of studies for all students in the immediate post-compulsory education years, and how higher education requirements may be derived from such studies. It is also generally recognised that the South Australian TAFE system leads the country in many important respects, so I am confident that these necessary changes in higher education will proceed with the cooperation of the South Australian Government and its agencies.

Gaining the desirable level of cooperation and financial support from industry for higher education will be a much more difficult challenge. This may present special problems for the smaller States, which do not house the head offices of major corporations. The question of industry support poses one of the threats to success of the Government's policies on higher education and training. In its response to the discussion paper on higher education, the University of Adelaide asks, `Won't the growth in graduate output, if it can be achieved, turn out to be a burden for the country economically unless there are major changes in the attitudes and managerial skills of private sector employers?'. These are matters which the Government must confront. It is the TAFE system which has a particularly vital role in this area because, of all the educational sectors, TAFE has the strongest and most direct links with industry. In South Australia TAFE is responding rapidly to the demands of industry and has introduced a number of new initiatives which I believe will be followed throughout the country. For example, through TAFE business enterprises the State Government has entered into contracts with Commonwealth Government agencies and private firms to enable the two-way transfer of technological skills. In the case of higher education institutions there is widespread agreement with the general thrust of the Government's reforms as outlined in its discussion papers. However, there are a number of specific matters on which institutions express doubts and their enthusiasm for reform inevitably recedes when the institutions are faced with the prospect of rapid change, or when existing empires are challenged. Not surprisingly, proposals for the consolidation of institutions have generated the most heat.

It is worth emphasising why the restructuring of higher education is necessary. The so-called binary system of higher education arose when a second tier of institutions-colleges of advanced education-were created out of the old teachers colleges and technical colleges. This second tier expansion followed the creation of a number of new universities modelled on the existing universities. The problem with the expansion was that it produced some institutions which had insufficient enrolments to provide effective educational servicing and there was evidence of some wasteful course duplication. In addition, the CAEs were not funded for research as were universities, and their status was lower. CAE academics generally carried heavier teaching loads and were provided with fewer resources, such as library facilities, than their university counterparts. In spite of their lower status and funding the CAEs recruited many good academic staff, designed some excellent programs, and produced some fine grant funded research. However, the existence of a discriminatory binary system of higher education tends to work against the achievement of equity and appropriate growth in graduate output.

It has long been recognised that there is a need for system-wide acknowledgment of the importance of students being able to progress along the educational continium and for institutions to facilitate this by adopting a more flexible approach to the granting of credit. Such a system of credit transfer is an important step in reducing wastage and improving the access of disadvantaged groups to higher education. The discussion paper on higher education makes many worthwhile suggestions as to how this objective can be implemented. However, fair credit transfer arrangements will always be difficult to achieve in a system where there is a difference in status between components of the system. Under the proposed new unitary system it will still be important for higher education institutions and the system itself to have links with State TAFE authorities. The discussion paper recognises this and recommends that TAFE offer two-year full time higher education courses as a provider in its own right, funded by the States and with a capacity to deliver courses on a contract basis through other institutions.

While most institutions have welcomed the Government's proposals to scrap the binary system in favour of a new unitary system, the older institutions naturally wish to preserve their traditional strengths. I believe the Government is correct in supporting the development of a funding system that responds to institutional performance and the achievement of agreed goals so that institutions will no longer be able to continue without penalty those longstanding practices which act against the public interest. Many institutions are naturally suspicious that the proposed new funding and staffing arrangements present a challenge to institutional autonomy and cherished academic freedoms, but the simple fact is that the present system encourages a level of wasted resources and lost opportunities which can no longer be tolerated. There is too little accountability for large sums of taxpayers' money, and I support the discussion paper's assertion that academic freedom should be no protection for inadequate performance or lack of commitment. I have every confidence that higher education institutions will soon adapt to the fundamental national objectives set out in the discussion paper and discover that within this basic framework they can have the greater freedoms promised-that is, more flexibility at the institutional level to determine courses to be offered and research undertaken; greater institutional control over resources; and decreased government intervention in funding and management.

There are two further areas concerning the work of NBEET and the other bodies to be established under this legislation which I wish to mention. Firstly, there is the development of reliable performance indicators for higher education. The discussion paper concedes that far more developmental work needs to be done, particularly on a comprehensive, nationally consistent statistical base. It is regrettable that in so many areas where the Hawke Government has introduced long overdue and far-reaching reforms so little statistical information was available to help with the preparation of such measures. Secondly, there is the division of responsibilities between Federal and State governments. Unfortunately, as the discussion paper points out, there are few definitive and generally accepted criteria for distinguishing between matters of national and State concern in higher education. The nation's system of higher education must clearly respond to national objectives while serving both State and regional needs. The TAFE system must also have regard to broader national considerations. Clear potential exists for conflict in priorities and procedures between the Commonwealth and the States, particularly in the case of CAEs. The discussion paper points out that the important issue is to establish a process of consultation and the essential requirement is development of an effective advisory and consultative mechanism between each State and the Commonwealth to facilitate the planning process and to advise on State priorities.

In conclusion, the Employment, Education and Training Bill is a major element in the restructuring of higher education in Australia. The institutional arrangements established by this Bill, combined with the policy prescriptions of the Government's discussion papers, can provide a higher education system which makes the maximum contribution to the growth of the Australian economy and produces greater equality of opportunity for all Australians. With cooperation from the States, industry and institutes of higher education, the creation of the National Board of Education, Employment and Training and its subsidiary councils will mark the beginning of an important new phase in the history of Australia's development. I commend the three Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills before us tonight are the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill, and one Bill to nationalise education advisory structures-the Employment, Education and Training Bill. They are subject, as the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has indicated, to amendments by the coalition. They are considered to be primarily machinery Bills, with the exception of the third Bill, which contains some fairly bad news. The Bills reflect and serve the broader policy directions of this Government in regard to the education of young Australians. Therefore it is quite appropriate, I believe, for some comment to be made on that policy direction.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider, first, clause 3 of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill. That clause tells individual non-government schools that henceforth they do not have to tell the Minister when they are going to move to the premises next door. The need for such a clause-a very small step in coming to grips with red tape-clearly highlights the realities of the ridiculously overregulated non-government schools system. This week each member of this House received the latest issue of the Australian Parents Council Review. The Council points out in that journal that the Government's determination to limit parental choice of schooling is evidenced by the latest list of enrolment-limited schools, which shows 363 affected non-government schools in Australia-an increase of 12 per cent on the 1987 list. It also points out that the Government is not only discouraging expansion of parental choice, but also is interfering in curriculum matters. It forces non-government schools to-and I quote from that journal:

. . . adapt their curriculum to the Government's stated political priorities instead of allowing them to follow their own education priorities which over the years have resulted in their proud record of achievement.

It is not just non-government schools which are affected by the heavy-handed bureaucracy and the political interference of government. Our public schools suffer just as much from these burdens. We have a public school system which is overbureacratised, starting with the unnecessary Federal education bureaucracy and ending with the administrative directions to account-if honourable members can believe it-for every piece of stationery in an infants department storeroom. That bureaucratic burden contributes to and is compounded by the serious level of demoralisation in our teaching profession.

It is time we got off the backs of our teachers. Today a teacher bears the threefold responsibility of responding to government policy adhockery; responding to educational disadvantage from socioeconomic factors, particularly the increasing incidence of family breakdown; and responding to the fears of parents about the future employability of their children. It is time we restored the status of, and regular public praise for, the teaching profession. It is time we gave teachers a system which provides them with the flexibility, resources and public confidence to achieve the multidisciplinary objectives the public now expects. It is time we stopped mindlessly funding a rigid system which makes policy decisions and allocations, for example, as if class sizes on the North Shore of Sydney presented teachers with exactly the same problems as class sizes in western Sydney.

We have been quite unfair to teachers. We expect teachers not just to maintain but to lift literacy and numeracy levels. We expect schools to teach not only the basics but also computer literacy, foreign languages, science aptitude, consumer skills, reasoning skills and personal development. We expect value education from teachers but are vague about which values. We expect teachers to do all this with less administrative support and fewer resources. We expect teachers to do this in a community which blames them for social problems and regularly questions their professional commitment.

Let us be clear about this: the school is second only to the family in terms of its significance for our future. In many instances it must take up family responsibilities as well as its own. But the quality of our relationship with teachers does not correspond to the enormity of the social responsibility they are expected to bear. So long as we continue with unfair attitudes and expectations, inappropriate bureaucratic structures and backward professional management and development strategies, we will simply exacerbate education problems for our children. Our attitudes and this Government's policy approach to higher education are equally open to criticism.

Consider the Employment, Education and Training Bill before the House now. The approach by the Government to the need to expand higher education is to expand the controls of the corporatist state through an education board which gives the officials of the Australian Council of Trade Unions a say on university administration and priorities. Contrary to the worldwide trends towards decentralised, small is beautiful strategies for excellence, this Government is about centralising control and the direction of tertiary institutions. Frankly, it is counterproductive for us to continue passing legislation which structures and funds the education bureaucracy that sees only a small amount of the funds trickle down to the local school and institution. Instead, we must adopt a school, institution and profession-focused policy that nurtures autonomy, pluralism and excellence. In that regard I acknowledge the policy contributions of my colleagues the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) and the honourable member for Mackellar.

I declare my conflict of interest in this matter. For a great part of my career prior to entering parliament I was a teacher. I have taught infants and primary and secondary students for many years. Let me say to my colleagues that they should spend a week in a classroom in a disadvantaged area, study the lessons of the great institutions of higher education, and they will soon understand my comments today. The legislative and policy basis for schools and higher education is flawed. Just as significantly, the signals we send out to teachers and students are confused and counterproductive.

I shall give two examples. The first is: what signal is the Government sending currently to prospective postgraduate students? It is this: it expects them to forgo 12 years of income; it expects their young families to suffer poverty level income in that period; it expects them to study in Australia within underequipped institutions; it wants their research to be relevant as determined by the government of the day; and it sees them as essentially free riders who should face additional taxation when they earn an income because, on the whole, it does not like unproductive, self-serving intellectuals.

The second example is this: my colleague the New South Wales Minister for Education is faced with permanent teacher shortages in western Sydney. He is advised that some teachers are abusing casual teaching to avoid classroom responsibility and to get high pay rates. He announced publicly that he will end this and he described it as a rort. Now the unintended signal to all those men and women who combine casual teaching with family care is, `You are rorting the system; we doubt your professional commitment'.

The key to improved basic skills, to retention rates, and to tertiary education intakes is not the expansion of bureaucratic control; it is not the expansion of the corporate state; and it is not public criticism of teachers and institutions. The way to achieve these objectives is to equip, empower and enthuse teachers to do the same for parents and students at the level of the local school, college and university. Unfortunately, today we will see passed machinery Bills that will fund and restructure educational policies and management which run counter to that approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer one of the criticisms repeated frequently by the Opposition in the vain hope that if it keeps telling a lie it might become the truth, I pick up one of the points made by the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) on the so-called corporatist state and the so-called centralising of power. The line the Opposition is pushing has no basis in fact. The Government is setting up a consultative board that in many ways is more open to scrutiny and more accessible than the system it replaces.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I turn my attention to the current situation in higher education in this country as the Bills touch on that area. The release of the Wran Committee on Higher Education Funding proposals in the past couple of weeks has shown that once again-as is stated in the document-the higher education system is still mainly the preserve of affluent people. If one were to make a comparison between 1988 and 1974, one would find that changes have been made but they were only minimal. Although I do not condemn the changes made in 1974, hindsight has shown us that if we are to stick with the current system, we will not achieve that particular aim. If the aim was to assist people from low income families to gain access to higher education, we started-I have always held this view and still hold it-at the wrong end. In many ways, the people on low incomes and from low income areas never reached the starting gates of higher education because they were dropping out on the way through the system, and the retention rates tend to support that argument. On Labor coming to government, the retention rate in secondary schools was 36 per cent, and now they are well in excess of 50 per cent. The Government will take them higher. The only areas from which those students can come is the working class areas. The Government has made a start in addressing the problem of ensuring that more and more young people from all areas are actually reaching the starting gates of higher education, and not only those who come from the more affluent areas.

One of the major criticisms I have of the present system is that the size of the student body is not determined by capacity or even by demand but by the allocation of the Federal Budget. I cannot see much of a future for a higher education system in which funding is provided in that way. The Wran proposal, which I shall discuss shortly, overcomes that problem. The basic question one must ask oneself is: how will education be funded? There is no disagreement among the people participating in the higher debate that education needs to be expanded, because it is true that the education system serves the economy in which it is placed. Although Liberal-National Party governments were in power for 35 of the 40-odd years after the Second World War, they were happy to run an economy based on sending rocks, wheat and wool overseas and not many value added products. Therefore, the education system was tailored towards that. Australia had a low number of graduates in comparison with the countries it traded with and now the focus in Australia is to have value added to the raw materials in Australia and not to send them overseas for someone else to take the profits.

The whole of the focus of the Government, certainly in areas of taxation, industry policy and now education, is to ensure that Australia has a system that accommodates that fundamental change in the economy, having put some decency back into the taxation system to ensure that Australia promotes investment rather than capital gains or speculation and by looking at industry policy in a more meaningful way, and ensuring that the education system is more attuned to providing Australia with the skilled people it will need in the future, rather than relying, as it did in the past, on importing the skills from overseas.

It was a fact that Australia bludged when it came to training its young people. We always took the view that it was easier to send overseas for the skills and import them rather than to train our people with appropriate skills. That was an inward-looking policy and the focus of everything the Government is doing now is to ensure that our people are trained and retrained. That is the way of the future. Other countries that have followed that path are doing much better than Australia.

The basic thrust of the Wran proposal is forgotten, because the basic thrust of the Government is to expand the educational system. We are going from a situation where currently about 88,000 students graduate from our higher education institutions to a position where we want over 125,000 to graduate. The basic argument, as I said before, is about where the resources will come from. There is an argument that they should come from the Budget, that is, the taxpayers should fund the whole area of education. I personally do not hold that view, and I have not done so for quite a while.

I think that there is a community benefit in higher education and that the community should pay for it. Under the proposals of the Wran Committee, the community will still underwrite 80 per cent of the cost of higher education, with industry and the students themselves picking up the other 20 per cent. I think that is equitable, because industry does get a decent return on its investment from the higher education system; but in exactly the same way the participants in higher education really get a head start in life that is with them for the whole of their working lives and they certainly do very much better, in terms of remuneration and access to jobs, than people who do not go on to higher education.

I honestly believe that the attitude to education has changed dramatically since the 1970s. I think people now recognise it for what it is, namely, a sound investment for their kids. For example, if we look at the long waiting lists for places in private schools we realise that parents are prepared to pay up to $5,000 a year to have their children attend private schools. The main reason they are doing that is to make sure that their kids get into higher education institutions. It seems to me to be a mad proposition that parents who are prepared to spend up to $5,000 a year on their child's education in secondary school will not make any contribution when it comes to tertiary education. I honestly believe that people nowadays will make that investment and I do not think it is asking too much of them to ask them to help fund the education of our young people, certainly in the context that we are going to expand the system to accommodate the 13,000 to 20,000 young people who currently cannot get in.

For that reason I support the Wran proposal and what it stands for. I believe that the Committee has recognised in its proposal to the Government that there may be a deterrent in bringing back fees. I agree with that, because it is very hard for people on low incomes who want to go into tertiary education to be confronted with a high up-front cost. The Wran proposal does not have that. In fact, it takes the money back much later in life, when the recipient of the benefit of higher education can afford to pay it back. As I say, it is based on only 20 per cent of the cost; and, although I do not think we will get 20 per cent back from the student, he will certainly make his contribution.

Taking all of that into consideration, it is amazing to look at the amendment moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). He talks about the Government's failure to provide sufficient resources to tertiary institutions for them to meet the demand for student places. I was not lucky enough to hear what the honourable member had to say, but one thing I can presume with great accuracy is that he would not have put up a solution. Anybody who reads the report of the contribution he made this evening will, I am sure, find that. The Opposition really has more front than a double decker bus. I am told that the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free) had a look at the retention rates and the increase in our higher education institutions under the former Government compared with those under this Government. Without knowing those facts, I know that the former Government came a distant second when it came to performance in that area.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is talking about cutting $11 billion to $13 billion-that is, $11,000m to $13,000m-off government expenditure. When we talk in figures of that magnitude and when we start looking at areas in which resources such as those can be cut, it seems to me that education would be high on the list. Knowing members of the Opposition as we do and knowing the opportunists that they are, we know that they would not say that they would cut pensions and they would not do it immediately. There are many other areas which are just as sensitive as that but which we know the Opposition is too gutless to tackle. But, of course, education is a sitting duck because all anyone has to do is sit on his hands and do nothing, and over time the higher education sector will actually be starved of those funds. If the Opposition wants to cut $11,000m to $13,000m off government spending, I cannot see any future for an expansion of the higher education system under the coalition.

The Liberal Party of Australia is the only party in Australia that is still talking about full tertiary fees. Its position is that institutions should be allowed to take on students over and above those who are publicly funded, by allowing them to pay full tertiary fees. That is a very discriminatory policy in that, as I have said, people on low incomes would not be able to attend those higher education institutions because they just do not have the money. It seems to me to be a crazy proposal to put up, but nothing from the Opposition surprises me nowadays.

Just recently, I noticed newspaper reports of the honourable member for Mackellar talking about his education policy. If my memory serves me correctly, he said that he would give that area back to the States. The Opposition would say, `This is how we are going to cut off the $11 billion to $13 billion. We will stop spending money and somehow all those costs will disappear'. Of course, that is nonsense. The Commonwealth might be saving itself that money, but it would be putting the onus on the States and they would have to come up with the money. Maybe the Opposition is going to fund the huge spending proposals that it is talking about by simply getting out of the system altogether. I look forward to the Opposition's education policy because, if the other policies are anything to go by, it will be a real lulu.

TALK.START.PARA: —We remember their tax policy.
—The Opposition has had a number of tax policies and it has had six or seven health policies. It will have three or four education policies before the next election; there is no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation before us also establishes the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET). As I said before, the whole focus of that is to make sure that we actually get more participation from the wider community, because NBEET does replace a number of bodies, such as the Schools Commission and the Tertiary Education Commission, that used to serve governments. I believe that the changes are for the better because we are now bringing all of those educational offerings under one umbrella. We are starting to get people who are out in industry talking with the educators-rather than having them set up in their ivory towers here in Canberra-and the NBEET proposals will do that.

It is also important to realise that the community will have greater access to the Board and its councils than ever was the case with either the Tertiary Education Commission or the Schools Commission. For the first time all advisory bodies in these areas will reflect the Government's commitment to tripartisanship, that is, that both employers and unions should be represented directly and not indirectly as they once were. As well as having this strength, the legislation makes it clear that the operations of the Board and its four councils will be open to public scrutiny. Everything that is discussed and proposed by those councils will be tabled here by the Minister and will be available to the wider community so that it can have a direct input. That refutes everything that the Opposition is talking about-this corporatist state. What the Opposition is big on is jingoism and what it is small on is detail and policy. It thinks it can float through the system by this jingoism rather than coming up with hard policies.

I could touch on many other areas; but I am watching the clock, as you are, Mr Deputy Speaker. I believe that the whole focus of what we are doing today is to assist Australia to become a more vigorous and more dynamic economy and that what we are doing complements every other major structural change that this Government has brought in.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I was not able to follow the entire debate, but obviously I want to thank those who participated in it. I would like to respond to some of the observations of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). The establishment of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training is an important change. I think the honourable member for Mackellar has recognised that it is a big change, even if he does not agree with all the provisions of the Employment, Education and Training Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to make the point that underlying this approach is the importance of the Government having coordinated advice across the range of employment, education and training policy areas. It is important to realise that many countries around the world are now trying to move towards a more coordinated approach to education, from initial education in the schools through to what people do in upper secondary school, the post-secondary environment, industry training, technical and further education and higher education.

At a recent Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development conference, which I was delighted to be able to chair, it was interesting to see how many countries are observing what is happening in Australia, generally with great approval of the way in which we have been able to bring these policy areas together, trying to coordinate our approach across that diverse range of education and training policy areas. In that context it seems to me important that, as far as our advisory structures are concerned-bearing in mind that it is important for the Government to have the views of both the education providers and, on the other hand, the users of the education system, whether they be industry or the community in general-we ensure that we have access to advice on the important issues which the Government will have before it, not the least of which, of course, is how to expend the something like $6 billion which is available within my portfolio to ensure that we do in fact meet the objectives which the Government has and, more importantly, the objectives that the community would seek us to pursue.

There is the question of how we get coordinated advice from those who are primarily involved with schools as well as from those who are primarily involved with other areas of education such as higher education, technical and further education, industry training and so on. If the Opposition believes that this advisory structure is different from those which it replaces, that is perfectly true. But this is deliberately the case because we are trying to bring some coordinated approaches to these policy areas. I note some of the points that the Opposition has raised in its amendments. In a sense I agree with the honourable member for Mackellar, it was a pity that we had so little time to give detailed consideration to his proposed amendments, because it may well have been possible for us to reach agreement on some of those issues-and I would still be happy to talk to him in the context of the further consideration that this matter will have in the Senate later on. Obviously, there are some difficulties with some of his amendments. I do not wish to traverse those here this evening.

In summation, I think it is important that we establish this board. There is the question of whether or not it has to be a statutory board. The bodies which it replaces were partially statutory and partially non-statutory. The statutory ones were the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission; but there were also certain non-statutory bodies such as the Australian Council for Employment and Training and, of course, the Australian Research Grants Committee, and a number of other committees which existed by way of administrative decision rather than by way of statute. But it is certainly my wish that this board be established with a statutory framework.

It is also my wish that we should be able to move quickly to establish it at least on an interim basis, and then, as soon as the Bill becomes law, we can finally establish it on its proper statutory foundation. There is a great work load for this body to undertake, both in relation to the reforms we have in mind for higher education and also in other areas of the education and training system. I hope that once this House has passed this measure-and, of course, the associated Bills that we are discussing here tonight-we can move quickly to see this body firmly established.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I move:
(1) After clause 7, page 2, insert the following new clause:
``7a. After section 15 of the Principal Act the following section is inserted in Division 1 of Part II:
Recurrent grants may be increased to assist institutions in meeting Second Tier Wage Case decisions

`15a. (1) The Minister may, on or before 30 June 1988, determine, for the purposes of this section, that expenditure of a specified kind by prescribed institutions, being expenditure incurred, or to be incurred, in giving effect to:

(a) a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission making a second tier adjustment of salaries and wages in accordance with the wage fixation principles set out by the Commission in its National Wage case decision of 10 March 1987; or

(b) a decision of a State Industrial Authority making a second tier adjustment of salaries and wages in accordance with wage fixation principles laid down by that Authority that are consistent with the wage fixation principles referred to in paragraph (a);
shall be relevant second tier wage expenditure.

`(2) Where the Minister is satisfied that a prescribed institution has incurred, or will incur, relevant second tier wage expenditure, the Minister may, on or before 30 June 1988, determine an amount of additional financial assistance payable in relation to the prescribed institution in respect of the year 1988, and, subject to subsection (3), the amount specified in Schedule 1, 2, 5, 6 to 7 (as the case requires) in relation to the prescribed institution, shall be deemed to be increased by the amount so determined.

`(4) In this section:
``prescribed institution'' means:
(a) a university in a State;
(b) a college of advanced education in a State;

(2) After clause 14, page 4, insert the following new clause:
Reports by the Minister
``14A. Section 48 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting `, 15A' after `15'.''.

In introducing these amendments, the Government has recognised two things. Firstly, it acknowledges some progress in negotiations for the second tier national wage increases for both general and academic staff in the higher education sector. Secondly, it recognises the rights of workers to have negotiated salary increases paid as early as possible. The program to be funded as a result of this amendment is designed to provide interim additional funding for institutions providing higher education courses that will not be in a position to achieve immediately the productivity gains that are a condition of the second tier decision.

The Government's decision that bridging funds should be made available in the short term is to ensure that institutions are in a position to pay the salary increases while the productivity gains are achieved. To benefit from that program, the parties will need to resolve any differences speedily. The industrial processes are such that the current negotiations may stall and the parties may seek arbitration. I am seeking to ensure that the parties pursue the negotiation process to finalisation, with the outcome of an agreed settlement which satisfies the Commonwealth's higher education objectives.

The amendment requires me to determine the funding to be provided to the institutions in relation to the second tier increase for the 1988 calendar year by 30 June 1988. Institutions will need to seek funding in sufficient time for payments to be made by 30 June 1988. Although I consider that arrangements to provide adequate funds should be in place so that the recipients of the wage increases are not in any position of uncertainty pending amendments in later legislation, I do not believe that the parties should be in a position to delay indefinitely decisions on the final outcome or to obstruct the negotiation process. Any request for funding after 30 June will need to be considered in the Budget context.

The timing of the provision of funds after 30 June will be subject to legislative provision in the Budget session of parliament and, in the normal course of events, funds would not be available to institutions until late 1988 or January 1989. The Bill is expected to pass all stages of the current session of parliament. The additional amount to be included through this program will be some $46.3m. I ask that the amendments circulated in my name be adopted. Any requests for funding after 30 June will need to be considered in the Budget context.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has kindly explained to me, in addition to his speech, what he intends by the amendments. It is an important principle that anybody who receives a second tier wage increase does so as a result of a productivity agreement. Of course, there have been negotiated through industry productivity agreements which, in a number of cases, have enabled employers to reach settlements with employees and which have allowed the costs of the second tier increase to be offset or more than offset by the agreement. This is necessarily quite a difficult thing to do in the area of tertiary education but, nonetheless, the Opposition recognises that the Minister is putting some pressure on the institutions, and possibly more so on the unions involved, to come to a speedy settlement in terms of productivity arrangements and, in that sense, the Opposition has no objection to the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

I have to point out to the Committee that, in addition to these 16 amendments, I have another. To have debated these amendments properly I would have introduced them one by one, and had them dealt with one by one. That would have taken quite a long time. It is only because of the guillotine having been applied to this legislation by the Government, forcing one of the most important pieces of legislation in some time through this chamber in minimal time, that it is not possible for me to deal with these matters adequately in this chamber. As I pointed out before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, they will have to be dealt with properly in the Senate. Tonight all I can do, in effect, is formally to move 16 of my amendments together, instead of dealing with them one by one, and explain as many of them as I can get to in the short time allotted to me. I think it is a disgrace that we are handling this Bill--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have just wasted two minutes. See whether you can waste another one.

—If the honourable member for Bendigo thinks of this as a joke he had better go somewhere else. The first amendment to clause 7, on page 5 of the Bill, I will link with the second amendment. It omits the words, on line 6 `but subject to subsection (2)' and also omits subclause (2). The purpose of these two amendments, taken together, is to enable the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to have a reasonable prospect of initiating matters without having them referred to it by the Minister. It is part of the general framework of this Bill and the intention of the Government that the National Board of Employment, Education and Training (NBEET) be very much under the thumb of the Minister. These provisions make it impossible for the Board to carry out any functions which it believes are of importance and which have not been referred to it by the Minister, only if the performance of that function does not prejudice the performance of its functions under paragraph 1 (a), in other words, those functions that have been put upon it by the Minister. By removing these two provisions we bring the Board back into the same kind of condition as its predecessor bodies, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) and the Commonwealth Schools Commission, which could initiate inquiries of their own without having the Minister's approval.

SPEECH.PARA: The third amendment, to clause 7, page 6, adds a new subclause (7):
The Board may delegate any of its functions to a Council.

There are four councils reporting to the Board. It seems sensible, in order to be able to spread the workload amongst the various bodies in a sensible way, that the Board have the capacity to delegate any of its functions to a council. The fourth amendment, to clause 9, page 7, lines 33 and 34, omits paragraph (6) (b). Paragraph (6) (b) relates to the powers of the Board to summarise reports received from the reporting councils. If the Board receives a report from a council where the council has been asked by the Board or the Minister to report on a matter, the Board may give merely a summary of that report to the Minister, and then it is only the summary of the report that is subsequently published in the Parliament.

There may well be many matters which the councils might consider to be important, where they want a full report published. The Board would have the capacity to provide a summary and include in the summary whatever it liked. If we take, for example, the Australian Research Council, which may put up a detailed matter on research or technology, the Board may not have a full appreciation of the import of that report and may summarise it in a manner which could destroy the intent of the Australian Research Council. That would be unfortunate. So we believe that the Board should not have the capacity to summarise reports from the councils.

The fifth amendment relates to the capacity under this Bill for the Board to eliminate any report or part of a report for publication that it believes need not be disclosed because of confidentiality. Again, this is a means of gagging the subsidiary councils. They may bring forward for subsequent publication matters which they regard as being of importance. The Board can decide that the matter is a confidential matter and it is not included in the report which goes on to the Parliament. So, by omitting subclauses (10) and (11), we remove that power of the Board and again we bring the Board back into line with the practices of the old CTEC and the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The sixth amendment, to clause 11, page 8, is very important, relating to the membership of the Board. The Government has provided that the Board shall consist of not more than 13 members. Of those 13 members, five may be full time members, two may be people from trade unions, two from business and at least seven shall be persons having expertise in matters relating to education or training. Here we get to the heart of balance of power, as it were, on this Board. Under the Government's proposals it is possible for five full time public servants, plus two trade union representatives, plus two business representatives-a total of nine out of 13-to dominate the proceedings of the Board against the interests of those from education, training, research or technology. We therefore propose that the structure of the Board be changed so that the maximum number of full time appointees may be three and not five, and that there be one representative from trade unions and one from business. We believe that they should be represented, but not unduly. So therefore the Board may have a maximum of five full time public servants, plus union and business representatives, out of 13, leaving a greater possibility of representation by people who know something about what is happening in the educational, scientific and technological research spheres.

We agree that seven shall be persons having expertise in matters relating to education and training. In proposed subclause (d) we say that at least two shall be persons having expertise in matters relating to scientific research or technology. People in the research and technological communities are very concerned indeed that they might not have people on the board, which is the powerful body reporting directly to the Minister, who have an understanding of their particular problems.

Amendments 7, 10, 11 and 12 would give the councils the opportunity to decide for themselves some items of their agenda in addition to those given to them by the Minister. Under the Minister's proposals, the councils have no capacity whatsoever to initiate matters for themselves and we believe that they should have. The Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission had that power and we believe that the councils ought to be able to initiate matters and also to publish.

Amendments 8 and 9 refer to the Schools Council. In amendment No. 8 we want to include in clause 24 in the objectives that have to be taken into account by the Schools Council two additional objectives over and above those that have been passed on from the old Schools Commission, which were set many years ago and which do not reflect the need to raise educational standards of schools. Nor do they reflect the need to maintain discipline in schools. These are two areas which are of great concern to parents, employers and the community generally. We believe that these two points should be reflected in the formal objectives that are laid down for the Schools Council. We also want to make sure that the Schools Council, in the exercise of its functions, will consult and cooperate with persons, bodies and authorities conducting government and non-government schools. That was a requirement in the Schools Commission Act and we believe it should also be a requirement for the Schools Council under this Bill.
Amendment No. 13 refers to the power of publication of a council. After paragraph (b) of clause 30 on page 16 we want to add sub-clause (c) as follows:
may authorise the publication of any comment or submission made to it, of any document presented to it, or of any report made by it.

This is an important addition to the changes that we propose in amendments 1 and 2, which enable the Board to initiate matters. It is also important to add to the changes in amendments 4 and 5 which restricted the power of the Board to summarise or to delete reports from councils because of their confidentiality. In this case we want to give the councils a clear right to authorise the publication of any matter that they deem should be made public. If they do not do that, a public debate on matters of great importance in the areas covered by the Council will be precluded in a way that it has not been under the previous legislation.

Amendment No. 14 deals with clause 31 and the constitution of the councils. Its effect would be to ensure that the chairperson of a council is appointed having regard to the relevance of the experience and expertise of that member to the responsibilities of the council. There is nothing in the Bill at the moment which would ensure that the Board member appointed as chairperson of the council need have any particular expertise or experience in the work conducted by that council. This amendment would ensure that that is the case. The amendment also would make sure that the person is a part-time appointee and not a full-time employee or somebody under some appointment by the Government. We believe that it is important to have independent chairpersons of these councils, thus relaxing the obviously intended grip of the Minister and of NBEET on this whole set-up which is part of the objective of the Bill as it stands. We do not agree with that. Just about everybody who has anything to do with this whole area out in the real world does not agree with that. Amendment No. 14 will ensure that the chairperson of the council is a part time and independent appointee and also a person chosen because of the relevance of his experience or expertise to the work of that council.

Amendment No. 15 deals with the insertion of proposed new clause 31a which relates particularly to the appointment of the chairperson of the Australian Research Council. This is a particularly important appointment in relation to which the scientific and technological community has a worry about whether its interests will be fully understood. Also, those in the humanities and social sciences wish to be sure that the person who heads this important body is someone in whom they have confidence. The amendment makes it a very reasonable requirement, which is found in a lot of other legislation, to consult with various learned bodies before an appointment is made. Proposed new clause 31a reads:

An appointment of Chairperson of the Australian Research Council shall only be made after consultation with the Australian Academy of Science, the Australian Academy of Technological Science and Engineering, the Academy of Social Sciences in Australia and the Australian Academy of the Humanities.

We regard that as being additional to the requirement that the person has expertise and experience in the area. This is another safeguard to ensure that the person who is in charge of this very important body has the widespread confidence of the learned communities.

Amendment No. 16, the last in this group, refers to the deletion of paragraph (1) (a) from clause 42 and the substitution of other words. The consultative committee is designed to create a link between NBEET and the States and to be a point of reference about the objectives in employment, education and training with all the State functions that are associated with this policy area. The Chairman of NBEET naturally ought to be the Chairman of this committee and not the Secretary to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. We believe that the Secretary should certainly be a member of the consultative committee but it seems to us ridiculous to omit the Chairman of NBEET, or anybody directly from NBEET other than the seven other persons, whoever they might be, who will be the representatives of the States. NBEET representation should not be excluded from the body which is supposed to provide the consultation with the States. I say this without any disrespect for the Secretary to the Department. It is well known that I have the highest possible regard for him. I just do not think the thing will work if NBEET has to rely on the Secretary to the Department as its point of contact with the States. Therefore, we wish to add a new clause as follows:
the Chairperson of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, who shall be the Chairperson of that Committee;

We then include subclause (a) as (aa) to ensure that the Secretary to the Department is also included on the Board. The seven other persons would be representatives of the States and Territories, then the thing ought to work properly. Those are amendments No. 1 to No. 16 inclusive, which I would have preferred to have moved seriatim, had discussed seriatim and voted upon seriatim with the chamber having had some reasonably long consideration. Nonetheless, we have to defer any sensible consideration of these matters to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will reply briefly to the amendments moved by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). The point is, of course, that the Employment, Education and Training Bill has been around long enough for the shadow Minister to have taken up my offer to have discussions about his concerns regarding the provisions of the Bill. I made it perfectly clear some time ago that I was happy to discuss with him any appropriate amendments he might have. Unfortunately, he did not see fit to discuss the proposals with me, which I think is a pity, I have always said that I am not intransigent on some of these questions and I would have been happy to discuss some of them with him.

SPEECH.PARA: In some respects his proposals are misconstrued. In some other respects they may have some merit. But I was intrigued by the ease with which the honourable member was able to move from precedents in relation to the bodies this Board will replace to ignoring precedents in relation to those pre-existing bodies. The major pre-existing bodies he has referred to-the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) and the Commonwealth Schools Commission-were established for different purposes. They were established to be executive bodies which actually administered programs and provided funds to various bodies that were to carry out functions which the Schools Commission, for example, recommended to the Government and which the Government then approved. They did have a quite clear executive function. This Board and its councils have very little in the way of executive functions. They are there to advise the Government on the way in which programs ought to be established and administered. Therefore, to rely entirely on the functions, powers and structure of the old commissions is not entirely appropriate.

When the honourable member talked about powers and the right to initiate certain inquiries and publish reports, he was referring to those powers which existed in the pre-existing bodies. In regard to chairmen and full time members, he ignored the fact that both the Schools Commission and CTEC had full time chairmen. Indeed in the case of CTEC, five of its 11 members were full time. Yet he said what a terrible thing it would be if, on this Board of 13, there were up to five full time members. The honourable member really cannot have it both ways. If he wants to rely on precedents he can, but he cannot then abandon precedents when it suits him.

Another point I would like to make is that we do need, as I said before, some coordinated approach to the advice we are receiving. The honourable member bemoaned the fact that councils cannot initiate their own business. They can propose and, if the Board agrees, initiate their own inquiries. Of course, the Board itself, on its own motion, can initiate inquiries and publish reports on any matters it chooses. As well, there is an authority for the Minister to refer matters to the Board which it may in turn refer to councils for advice and report.

One has to realise that we are not establishing this elaborate structure so that the Board and these councils can go off on some wild frolic of their own. They are being established to provide advice to the Government. If they are not providing advice to the Government, what is the point of having them? The reason for having this advisory structure is so that the Government can be well advised by people who are knowledgeable in the various sectors of employment, education and training, so that their advice can be taken into account in the development of various Government programs and in the administration of those programs. The honourable member ought to try to appreciate that we are moving from one structure to an entirely different structure for an essentially different purpose.

I want to refer to one other matter the honourable member raised-that is, that some of the learned academies are very concerned about their interests. We established the Australian Research Council (ARC) essentially on the advice of the Australian Science and Technology Council, which has amongst its members some of the most eminent scientists and other researchers in Australia. They wanted this body established broadly in this way. I think most people see the establishment of the Australian Research Council as a great advance because it brings together a coordinated approach to the support of research across the range of disciplines and fields throughout Australia. The honourable member says that the problem is that there is no-one on the Board who understands the scientific area. He ignores the fact that the Chairman of the ARC will be a member of the Board. Therefore, he will be able quite clearly to represent the interests of the Research Council on the Board and ensure that concerns about research are taken into consideration.

There is an important distinction to be made in relation to the Research Council. It has two primary functions. The first is to advise on research policy in general and the second is to advise on the actual distribution of grants to researchers around Australia. We believe that the Research Council ought to advise the Board on research policy. In respect of who should receive actual grants to support their research, the Australian Research Council should, as its predecessor bodies do now, advise the Minister directly rather than go through another structure which may change its recommendations. The concerns of the research community are well protected in the structure we have proposed.

As I said, we would have been happy to discuss some of these provisions with the honourable member. Regrettably, that has not been possible. While we see that there would be some capacity to give further consideration to some of them, on this occasion I am bound to say that the Government will not accept the amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Carlton's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

Clauses agreed to.
