DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 April, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill. If there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet again I add my voice to those who have complained to the Government about its handling of the gag not only on the Bills honourable members are about to debate but also on the 13 other Bills it has guillotined to cover up its whole mismanagement of the exercise of running this House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill seek to give effect to the Government's road package. Incidentally, I notice that the Minister responsible for the package, the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris), has only just arrived in the House. The Bills seek to give effect to the Government's so-called fast track package of road freight reforms. This package has been some years developing. If this is the fast track package, I should hate to see the slow track package emerging.

Although the Government has made some progress in changes to its road package, it has made no real attempt to do anything on the railways or on the waterfront, especially with shipping on the waterfront; but despite 21 reports and countless committees, nothing has been done. As I listened to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pat himself on the back today during Question Time when he was saying what terrific progress had been made, I noticed that he forgot to mention the recently released Industries Assistance Commission report, which said that inefficiencies in coastal shipping are costing the community between $300m a year and $700m a year. The Minister forgot to mention that report, which was one that does not fall into the ambit of trade union directives to the Government; it is one that he would prefer to forget.

The reforms that are encompassed in the Bill are long overdue. It is a shame that, in bringing them down and in reaching the compromise or trade-off with the industry, which agreed with the changes in reaching that trade-off, the Government has taken the easy mark by doubling interstate road freight charges while ignoring much more important problems. These more important problems are much more expensive to the taxpayer-for example, Australia's grossly inefficient railways, which are losing approximately $8m every day. I want to draw the attention of the House and the people of Australia to what the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) had to say in this House last night when he was speaking on the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill. He said:
We agree that there are inefficiencies in our railways, in our workshops and on our waterfront.
He went on to say, when talking about the Minister's own Department of Transport and Communications, the Minister's bureaucracy:
This is all the rage amongst the new breed of economists, the theorists, the ivory tower merchants in the Canberra Public Service . . .
This is a member of the Minister's own Party talking about the Minister's Department. He continued:

The recent Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on coastal shipping is a case in point and I raise it here not because of what it said-it is not worth the paper it is written on-but because it represents the treachery of the ivory tower theorists in the Canberra bureaucracy.
I remind the Minister that a member of his own Party is talking about his bureaucracy. The honourable member for Grey went on:

And let me warn Australians that this privileged, isolated and ignorant army is everywhere. I am informed that such people have infested the bureaucracy with their economic theories and run together with their colleagues in all the major departments.

If that is what a member of the Minister's Party is saying about the Department that the Minister administers, I suggest that the Minister should have some words with the honourable member for Grey. Let them sort out who is making government policy-the people in their ivory towers in Canberra or the Government. I suspect that it will emerge that the Government is continuing in its rather sloppy management of this part of the Australian economy.

The increase in the speed limit for heavy interstate vehicles to 100 kilometres an hour, the revised driving hours in the eastern mainland States, the banning of smoking on interstate buses and the introduction of uniform mass limits of 42.5 tonnes across Australia are all positive steps which have the support of the industry and the coalition parties. However, the doubling of charges for interstate vehicles is an admission that this Government is impotent in dealing with the shambles which is the Australian railway system.

It is essential, if Australia is to improve its present continuing overseas trading difficulties, and it is imperative, if we are to recover from our economic malaise, that we be capable of transporting our goods and our produce to the rest of the world as cheaply and as quickly as possible. The quite impartial and `head in the sand' approach that this Government has adopted to our railways, our waterfront, our coastal shipping and privatisation is indicated by the fact that it is willing to enforce 100 per cent or more cost recovery on industries where it thinks it can get away with it, such as with the truckies or the aviation industry; but when it comes to getting its mates in the trade union movement and the lazy management administering the waterfront, coastal shipping and the railways to do more to improve the transport system, it does nothing. This Government is afraid of standing on the toes of those who are members of the cosy cartels working in a way that disadvantages Australian families and who are members of those cartels operating on the waterfront, the railways and Australian ships.

The change in charges in this Bill is a sorry indictment of a cynical and increasingly out of touch Government, willing to enforce an inequitable restructuring of the Australian transport system. We need to maximise the benefits from an efficient road transport industry that is subject to national uniform standards covering all critical areas of responsibilities and operations and not only mass limits. It is difficult to identify the rationale for delaying the widespread introduction of B-doubles. I guess that the Minister will say in his response-that is, if he gets time to make a response, because the last two times he has tried time has run out on him as a result of his own Party guillotining him-`Oh, well, that is something for the next package, for the next fast track package that we will bring out in the next five years'. I have to tell the Minister that, if the speed at which this fast track package has proceeded is duplicated or triplicated in his third package, he will never get a chance to bring it to fruition.

It is difficult to understand the rationale for delaying the widespread introduction of B-doubles. The National Association of Australian State Road Authorities review of road vehicle limits identified the substantial productivity gains-in some cases exceeding 20 per cent-which B-doubles can deliver. The Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport also concluded that there were significant productivity gains to be achieved from widespread use of B-doubles in the transport of grain. Other government studies have reached similar conclusions. B-double vehicles have been operating for a number of years in North America, where they are used to transport commodities that are in direct competition with Australian goods in international markets.

Knowing the difficulties we have with our overseas trading situation, it seems passing strange, if not incredible, that the Government should not have done something about B-doubles in this package. Every day that we delay the introduction of B-doubles is a further day for which we are asking export industries to compete under a major handicap, and every day is a further day for which we perpetuate the rail monopolies in certain parts of this country. It simply does not make sense, and I and the Opposition urge the Minister in one way or another to ensure that B-doubles can be used on a widespread basis as soon as possible.

The industry is keen to work with the Government to establish a code of conduct for the operation of such vehicles in order to facilitate their early introduction. The use of this legislation to ensure that these vehicles can operate on a national uniform basis is clearly appropriate within the timetable that I have asked the Minister to consider, that is, the introduction of B-doubles as soon as practicable.

The industry, as the Minister would know, has identified a technical drafting deficiency in respect of one of the clauses of this Bill. I note that the Government is moving to correct this deficiency. I point out that, as we have seen recently not only in this legislation but also, for example, yesterday with the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill, this can be described only as sloppy management by this Government. It just does not seem to be able to get things right, and it is further evidence of how out of touch with the Australian people it is growing.

The Minister's second reading speech foreshadows that the registration charges will be substantially increased from 1 July, particularly in respect of the higher mass limits established by the amendments in the second Bill that we are debating here tonight-the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill. There is concern that this legislation should provide adequate protection to prevent any attempt by the States to impose additional charges on federally registered vehicles. With the level of charges announced by the Minister, it is clearly inappropriate to permit a situation where the States attempt to double dip on this whole question of charges. Again I ask the Minister to give the House assurances, either when he replies, if he gets a chance, or in another way if he does not, that the arrangements that have been reached with industry and the States do not permit a situation where, this doubling of charges having been introduced, the States are then in a position to impose significantly higher charges themselves.

In this legislation there is now to be a much higher ceiling, up to $5,000, on the level of charges which could be imposed on mass limits of 42 1/2 tonnes. This is a huge jump from the level that existed before the amendments that are now proposed. We share the industry's reservations about where these charges and the cost recovery objectives generally could be heading if the Government were to accept a number of the Inter-State Commission's recommendations contained in its latest report on land transport cost recovery. I refer particularly to the Inter-State Commission's proposal that future cost recovery reviews should be undertaken on the basis of, firstly, removing the link between improvements in road transport cost recovery and the level of rail transport cost recovery; and, secondly, determining cost recovery targets on the basis of short run marginal cost pricing. Both of these proposals would provide railways with substantial advantages over road transport, and they would have the effect of unbalancing the playing field-in as much as it is possible to talk about a level playing field.

Elimination of the link between rail and road cost recovery would remove one of the few means of imposing pressure to improve the financial and operating performance of the railways around Australia. It would involve reneging on a principle espoused by the Minister's own National Road Freight Industry Inquiry. That inquiry also rejected the concept of short run marginal cost pricing, an approach which lowers the cost recovery target for railways from 100 per cent of full distributed costs to about 70 per cent, while there would be a negligible change in the road transport target. What the Interstate Commission proposes in this instance is that rail should be given, at the stroke of a pen, a comparative advantage of 30 per cent. No genuine commercial organisation can afford to follow the simplistic economic approach associated with short run marginal cost pricing. The Minister must give the House an undertaking that he will reject this approach out of hand.

We also see a need for the Government to facilitate a greater industry involvement in determining the future cost recovery analysis. There is a need to look more closely at the so-called fourth power rule, which holds that road damage increases by the fourth power of increases in axle weights. Much of the research on the so-called fourth power rule is being carried out at the Australian Road Research Board (ARRB), and that happens, as the Minister knows, to be in my electorate in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. Because it is in my electorate, I visit it from time to time. I am glad to say that the Minister was present at a function celebrating its tenth anniversary a couple of years ago. That was before the Minister became a non-Minister, then another non-Minister, before becoming the Minister again.

The appropriateness of this arbitrary formula must be questioned, as it is questioned at the ARRB. It must be questioned particularly in respect of the use of well constructed roads, whose greater integral strength means that road wear is much less than on older types of roads. As we have seen recently, weather can play its part in the deterioration of roads. Extreme weather, to which Australia is unfortunately often subjected, can cause far more road damage in a much shorter time than any amount of heavy vehicle operations. As the funds raised by this registration charge increase are to be exclusively used for road maintenance activities, it is also appropriate to highlight this Government's disgraceful record in regard to road funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is rubbish.

—We will come to that. Honourable members opposite have kept road funding at $1,245m for the last four years. That is a drop of 40 per cent in real terms-the most disgraceful road funding performance almost in the history of the country. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) inform us ad nauseam that a major priority for this Government in its third term of office is micro-economic reform. Honourable members opposite would not know a micro-economic reform if it came up in front of their noses. The only micro-economic reform for roads that that bunch is going on with is to take us back to the standards of the 1950s. As I said a moment ago, the Government's performance on road funding has been $1,245m, held constant for the last four years; that is a drop of 40 per cent in real terms. While I am on the subject, let me tell honourable members opposite about some roads which are being caused to be turned back from bitumen to gravel because of lack of maintenance funds. Honourable members opposite should listen to this so that they can get their performance on roads into perspective. The Moora-Coomberdale road in the eastern wheat belt of Western Australia used to be a bitumen road. But because the mob opposite would not give any funds for maintenance it is now a gravel road. Are honourable members opposite proud of that? The Kalannie-East Kulja road is the same. There are roads up near Moree in New South Wales, in north-eastern Victoria and in north-western Victoria where this is happening.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the initiative of the Australian Automobile Association and its State motoring organisations for commencing a campaign to highlight the tax rip-off that this Government is perpetrating on every Australian road user. As that campaign progresses, more and more Australians will join the Australian Automobile Association in asking where the roads are that our taxes are paying for. Since the Minister has come out of the box and is back at the table, let me ask him what he is going to do about road funding in the May mini-Budget. Is he going to take $50m off road funding? Is he going to absorb $200m of road grants to local government into the general purpose grants to the States? The Minister shakes his head; he is not going to do that. That is very very interesting because the information we have suggests that the Government is about to deliver another body blow to road funding by taking $50m off road funding grants and by absorbing around $200m.

The Government cannot seriously justify its continual cutting of road funding on the basis that it makes good economic sense. Roads are about the soundest economic investment that governments can make. They provide real returns by firstly generating greater productivity in the commercial transport industry; secondly, reducing travel times for all road users; thirdly, lowering maintenance costs for all vehicles; and, fourthly, saving lives and reducing road crashes. The Minister for Transport and Communications Support, who is at the table, not infrequently makes Press releases about road safety. Let me say to the Minister that one commentator, based on an analysis of what is happening in what are called the black spots in roads around Australia, has estimated today that the $50m that the Minister plans to take off road funding, which he will announce next week, will cost a thousand lives on Australia's roads up to the year 2000. We have roads ripped up. We have a decrease in road funding. We have a bypassing of local government. The Minister is presiding over economic disaster if he continues the road policy he has pursued to date. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for:
(1) failing to provide adequate funding for roads;
(2) failing to address the appalling state and low level of cost recovery of the Australian railway network; and
(3) increasing taxes on the transport industry'.

The railways around Australia have what are called clock-off days. They are simple: a worker arranges for a workmate to put the worker's card through the time clock while the worker goes somewhere else on full pay. At the Jolimont workshop in Melbourne, sickies are raffled, except when they are auctioned to the highest bidder. Do not tell me that there is no enterprise left in the State railway systems. Victoria has led the world in making sick leave an item of currency.

Railways around Australia are losing the nation more than $3 billion a year by the most conservative estimate. That is costing the average Australian household $600 a year. The national railway network is costing the nation $3,000m a year. A combination of Federal Government and Victorian Government weakness in dealing with union power, restrictive work practices, demarcation disputes, overmanning at all levels, lazy management and blatant rackets in our railways has now become a national scandal. Governments, including this Government, are involved in that scandal because they will not take action on behalf of the public against powerful rail unions. In Victoria, the unions insist that a number of attendants and a supervisor be employed on sleeping cars when their chief task is to bring passengers one cup of morning tea. In Melbourne, 600 guards are rostered for duty on suburban trains. They have no effective function, although they earn on average more than $30,000 a year. They usually just sit and read a book or watch the stations go by. That is costing the Australian community $20m a year.

Work quotas are sometimes known as dargs. I have used the word `darg' before, and a couple of people have come up to me in the corridor and asked what a darg is. The honourable member for Grey did not need to ask what a darg is because in his speech yesterday on the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill he said:
Now, of course, they come to talk about rorts, niche rosters, dargs, et cetera . . .

The honourable member for Grey knows what a darg is. In fact, everyone who has had any association with the railways knows what a darg is. A darg is a work quota normally set so the working day lies somewhere between four and six hours and the rest of the day is spent relaxing, working on hobbies or playing cards. Strikes in the railways are unusual, but there is a new form of coercion going on, and that is called the black ban. In answer to a question today the Minister for Industrial Relations told the House what a super job was being done on the waterfront. They are doing a better job on the waterfront than on the railways. The railways are costing $3 billion a year while the waterfront is costing only $2 billion a year. The Minister said what a great job was being done on the waterfront, but in talking about strikes he did not say that, on the waterfront, as in the railways, literally thousands of black bans are applied. It is those black bans that are leading to substantially reduced efficiencies on the Australian railway system. The application of black bans in the railways has been turned into an industrial art form.

It is time for this Government and this Minister to face up to the fact that something must be done about the efficiency of Australian railways. It is no good the Minister sitting there and saying, `That is not a matter for us; that is a matter for the States'. The Government is responsible for the economy of Australia, and the economy is suffering because of the inefficiencies of our railways. It is time for this Government and this Minister to get out after the States and require them to improve the condition and efficiency of their railways, to get rid of the rorts and restrictive work practices, the rip-offs and the indifferent and lazy management that is hurting every Australian family to the tune of $600 a year.

Not just the railways and the waterfront but the whole transport network is costing decent, average, hard-working Australians and their families about $10 billion a year or $2,000 a family. It is time that this Government and this Minister faced up to the mess in the transport system and did something about it. The Opposition welcomes the progress that has been made as represented by this Bill, but calls on the Government to do something about the level of road funding, about the railways, about the waterfront, about the entire transport network. I commend the Opposition's amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I have much pleasure in seconding the amendment. I support it and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this important legislation. Obviously, I support the legislation and reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). It is always interesting to hear the honourable member for Deakin speak. We must bear in mind that this is the man who, as a backbencher, before he was made a shadow Minister, advocated that there be no Federal funding for roads. Now, although he had the decency not to criticise the Government for what it has put into road funding, he is the man who, as a backbencher argued and issued Press statements saying that there should be no Federal money for roads. How the tune has changed now. The honourable member plays to the audience. It was very convenient to argue a couple of years ago with some of his mates, like the next leader of the Party, that there be no Federal money for roads, but now he comes in here and we have heard all the nonsense he has gone on with.

SPEECH.PARA: It was interesting listening to his speech. For a while I wondered what he was talking about. We heard about the railway system, the waterfront and the shipping unions. We heard about everything but roads. As I understand it, this legislation deals with interstate road transport. When the honourable member got on to roads, what did he use as an example? He used two obscure roads in Western Australia-I must admit I have never heard of them and I have never travelled on them-which he claimed went from bitumen to gravel. Going on the sort of evidence he usually uses, I would want a little more evidence before believing it.

I say to the honourable member for Deakin that I do not know of any bitumen roads that have gone to gravel. However, since the Hawke Labor Government has been in power, I know of many roads that have gone from gravel to bitumen. We have heard the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) talk about the Pacific Highway. I remember travelling on that road; I have seen it go from gravel to bitumen. Part of the national highway goes through my electorate. When I came there the people used to trundle through Marulan. There used to be a dangerous intersection at a place called Hoddles Crossing, which has taken lives. The historic town of Berrima was being ruined because heavy trucks were going through it all the time. All the towns in that area had trucks going through the main streets. What have we got now? We have the Marulan bypass and a marvellous interchange between the Illawarra Highway and the national highway at Hoddles Crossing, which I had the pleasure to open a couple of months back, much to the annoyance of the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). What do we have?

TALK.START.PARA: —And done very well.

—Yes; very well opened. We also have the historic town of Berrima. The approach to that town is about to be bypassed. The bypass will go on to a place called Welby. As I understand it, work will soon start-and I hope it will-on the continuation of that bypass from Welby to Aylmerton. That is what this Government has been doing. The Government will put its record in regard to the funding that it has put into the national highways against the record of the previous Liberal Government. This Government has nothing to apologise for in its record, which is good. It is a continuing record, because it has a Minister who understands the needs of the travelling public, the motorists, and the Government has put millions of dollars into the national highway system.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments proposed in the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill will enable the Hawke Federal Government to implement its part in the second package of reforms in the Australian road transport industry. This Labor Government is the only government in Australia's history to have attended to the problems of the national road freight industry. There was the May National Road Freight Industry Inquiry, and the Government has worked very closely with the State and Territory governments to provide sensible and productive reforms.

The package that honourable members are debating comprises increasing the national speed limit for heavy vehicles in non-urban areas to 100 kilometres per hour; revising driving hours in the eastern mainland States to reflect more realistic modern Australian conditions; and introducing revised registration charges and new registration categories providing for higher and nationally uniform load limits under the Federal interstate legislation scheme. Another aspect that we are dealing with is the banning of smoking on interstate buses.

Having served on the Standing Committee on Transport Safety, I must say that I know how important these measures are. In regard to uniform speed limits, one of the things we found out when we inquired into long distance coaches was that the transport would be travelling on the roads at different speeds, which would actually cause accidents; and that if it were able to have a uniform high speed, it would be a chance to eliminate some of the accidents. I need not tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, how important it is to ban smoking on interstate buses because, in another capacity, I know of the sterling role you played in having smoking banned on domestic airlines. I am actually a smoker; I have never smoked on aircraft. I smoke a pipe and, therefore, I am banned from smoking on interstate airlines. However, I do not see why people should be permitted to smoke on coaches either, because I believe it is an infringement on people's liberties. Also, it imposes extra costs on the bus companies, and so on. It is a move that the bus companies support. It is interesting to note that, like the airlines, the bus companies would not make the move themselves-although they wanted to ban smoking on the coaches-until the Federal Government made a move. That is an interesting and progressive step.

I listened to what the honourable member for Deakin said about coastal shipping and the waterfront, and I have read the Opposition's recent transport statement. I invite the honourable member for Deakin-as I have invited him many times before-to come with me to Port Kembla and repeat the garbage that he says in this House. It is very easy to come into this chamber and throw around accusations against unionists, railway unions and seagoing unions. I invite the honourable member to come with me to Port Kembla and repeat the garbage he says in this House and to justify it to the people he is accusing. That is the only decent thing to do. We can all stand up here and say anything we like. Some of the information the honourable member was giving this evening was as outdated as the attacks he has made over the past few months about the seagoing unions. He is about three or four years behind the times. For instance, what about multi-skilling? What about the reduction in the manning of ships? We hear nothing about that from the honourable member. The record of the seagoing unions is very good in what they have done in reducing not only disputes but also the man-hours on those ships.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you think of the IAC report?
—Order!
—Did you read the IAC report?
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will restrain himself.

—The honourable member for Deakin is very good in this House in getting all uptight and screaming out. I say that if he was an honourable gentleman, he would come with me to Port Kembla and repeat to the seagoing unions and waterside workers at Port Kembla the claims that he is making and justify what he says.

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing that the honourable member for Deakin did not talk about tonight was airline policy. It was more a speech about all forms of transport but road transport. I repeat what I said at the beginning; this Government has a good record. It has a proud record in road funding. It is a record in which we, as members, can take pride. The honourable member for Deakin was talking about his bitumen roads going to gravel. I could take him over many roads in my electorate that have gone from gravel to bitumen since this Government has occupied the Treasury benches. I support the Bills. I commend them to the House, and I reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I support the amendment. None of us on this side of the House would in any way vote against the amendment stating that this Labor Government is not supplying sufficient funds for road building in this nation. In Australia's bicentenary year the real road funding category has dropped down to 1982 levels of funding, and that has to be a disgrace in any Australian's language. Australia is one of the biggest islands in the world. It depends very heavily on its arteries of transportation, be they sea, road, air or rail. It is very important to maintain adequate funding for roads.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the second point in the amendment relates to the appalling state and the low level of cost recovery from the Australian railway network. Honourable members know that the buses here in Canberra are subsidised to the tune of $20m a year by the national taxpayer; most railway systems throughout Australia are heavily subsidised by State governments and run at horrific losses. If some sort of efficiency in the transportation system is to be achieved, honourable members should be examining very closely the way the railways are run. I must say that in the case of Queensland, the former transport Minister, Mr Don Lane, did an excellent job in this area, and he increased the profitability of Queensland's railway system. I only hope that other States will follow his lead and do the same.

An enormous amount of money is taken out of the States' consolidated revenue and paid towards the upkeep of the States' railway systems. Of course, the Federal Government also pays. Through the consolidated revenue in this place, the sum of about $50m is paid as a subsidy each year to maintain the national railway system. That is something that we ought to consider very seriously and attempt to update and make more efficient.

Of course, there are also increased taxes on the transport industry. The Bills that we are debating tonight are basically about increasing road registration charges. One may question and wonder why it is necessary to do that, considering the amount of funds and excise that all road users-in particular, the big interstate transport operators, the road train operators- must pay.

As a farmer I am fortunate in that I am exempt from paying diesel excise. I do not believe that we should pay it. The Labor Government has been in office for some years now. It has moved the import parity pricing arrangements from the world price for crude oil at the wellhead across to the pump. There has been a ridiculous jump from 6c to 21c per litre, indexed to inflation. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is not here tonight. That is a pity. Every six months the tax on interstate road users and every other road user in this nation goes up. Roughly only 5c is put back. Now 21.7c is collected in excise, indexed every six months. Most of the funds go into Consolidated Revenue and are spent in other areas-probably wasted on welfare.

Since honourable members opposite have been in government there has been a major increase in welfare spending in this nation. It is a disgrace. Australia is going down the drain, and they know it. We are spending $22 billion, $23 billion, $24 billion on welfare-non-productive welfare. That is why this country is going broke. A lot of the money we are spending on welfare comes from the excise taxes. Nearly $5 billion comes from petrol taxes. By the end of this year $5 billion will be collected from excise taxes which the Australian Labor Party has placed on the motorists of this nation. Yet it has the audacity tonight to present a Bill which asks the interstate and intrastate transport industry-the vital arteries of this nation-to pay even more taxes to maintain the roads.

The Government ought to be spending more money from Consolidated Revenue on roads. We are already supertaxing fuel, and not only at the wellhead. The excise on crude oil is $2 billion. Esso-BHP pays 82c in the dollar on its Bass Strait oil production. Nobody else in this nation pays that sort of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't like profits being made.

—Forget the profits! Honourable members opposite do not like profits. That is their trouble. They do not like anybody to make a profit. They hate the capitalists. For every dollar BHP makes in Bass Strait, the Government gets 82c.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable member bring his remarks back to the substance of the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am sticking to the Bill. I am right on this Bill. This Bill is to do with the Labor Party ripping the guts out of the fuel industry, charging Esso-BHP 82c in the dollar. Before the Government gets this crude oil to the bowser it charges 82c on it. Once the Government gets it to the bowser, it charges 20c per litre on it.
—Order! I am yet to be persuaded that the honourable member is talking to the Bill.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I will persuade you before I am finished that what I am saying is correct. The Labor Government is taxing the hell out of fuel users in this country, the people who use the roads. They are the people we are concerned about. The Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) is here tonight. He is not a bad bloke. Ten days ago he came up to Milmerran in the great electorate of Maranoa and opened the bypass-I thank him. He made a special effort. I am pleased that he has at least considered my electorate. Obviously, the Department of Transport and Communications does not give it a lot of thought, but in this case the Department did give it some thought. This very good bypass road, that skirts the township of Pittsworth--
—It has a good member.

—You are a good member and a good Minister. You came up and did the opening and we had a good day. That is part of playing politics in the electorate of Maranoa. Any Minister is welcome to come to my electorate. I assure them that I will look after them, providing they are spending some money out of Consolidated Revenue in my electorate. The only problem is that they do not spend enough. I will welcome the Minister at any time to my electorate of Maranoa. He is quite welcome to open all the bypasses he can possibly lay his hands on. I will distribute to my councillors every ribbon he cuts up. They will have smiles from one ear to the other. They might even vote against the Government's ridiculous local government referendum issue. It is absurd. It has nothing to do with local government.
—Order! The honourable member should be addressing himself to the Bill. I will wait for him to address himself to the Bill.

—I know I am straying a bit from the track but what I am saying has to do with road funding-local government, State government and Federal government. We are very concerned. We are voting No on all the referendum issues. They are an absolute farce. The wording is a farce. The Labor Government knows that they are a farce. Nothing in the referendum issues gives Federal recognition to local government. All it does is force the States to recognise it. There are only two States that do not-Tasmania and Queensland. I can assure the Government that by the time the referendum is held we will make sure that they recognise local government and the Government can withdraw the referendum from its voting pad. It can save the people the problem of filling out an answer to the question it is going to put to them and the $40m it is going to cost the Government to put this question on local government. I will get back to the question we are debating tonight-interstate road transport.
—We would all welcome that.

—I commend the Government for the gross weight provision it has introduced. In Queensland our State Government has allowed wheat farmers and people carting grain in bulk to carry an extra two or three tonnes, up to 45 tonnes, gross weight. The interstate road transporters are allowed to carry 42 tonnes gross weight. Up to that gross they take the weight of the truck, trailer, the axle weight-triple axles or tri-axles and six-tonne front axles. A whole set of criteria is laid down by the Department of Main Roads as to what they can and cannot carry on the roads. Wheat farmers are able to carry an extra three tonnes up to the dump-a short haul-which helps them in their business.

SPEECH.PARA: About 80 per cent of our national produce which is carried on some sort of transport is carried by road. So it is important to spend increasing amounts of money to rebuild and maintain our present road system and build new roads. It is important for us to have a proper weight system. There is nothing worse than over-loaded trucks rolling out on any sort of a road. They even go through cement bridges and all sorts of things.

We are probably getting a better system. I would like to think that we could get a system where we did not have to pull up the interstate road transporters and weigh their vehicles every 100 or so miles, as we seem to be doing with the regulations that are imposed in that regard. At least we are getting a system which will see that not too much overloading takes place. People know the maximum load they are allowed to carry. That is important. As I have said, unfortunately this Bill forces these operators to pay more road registration fees. This is one of the major problems we face and why we have moved this amendment.

The Minister for Transport and Communications Support is at the table. As I said, he has been up to Maranoa and has opened the bypass. There are some important roads in my electorate, particularly the Burke and Wills Highway which goes through New South Wales and Queensland, running from Broken Hill through the Warri Warri Gate across Coopers Creek and heading on through Bedouri, to Mount Isa. These are roads in the far outback of Queensland. I am being asked to wind up, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I definitely have to mention the Burke and Wills Highway. It is most important. The Minister has offered to come up and visit the far south-west of my electorate. I have offered to take him out to Birdsville. We will go to Nappa Merry and have a look at where the road crossing is. It is important that tonight I again mention the shire councils in western Queensland and western New South Wales that are seeking funding. We are seeking funds from the Federal Government for road upgrading and to have a national highway put in place. We look forward to this in the future. It is the sort of road project we should have in mind. I hope that the Minister is prepared to give some funding for this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill and to oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition. In doing so I reiterate the views of my good friend the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) when he spoke of the new-found love of roads of the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). As the honourable member for Throsby pointed out, when the honourable member for Deakin was a backbencher he was recorded as saying that the Federal Government should not fund roads. He seems to have recanted that position. I wonder what brought him--
—Who said that?

—It was the honourable member for Deakin. He said there should be no Federal funding for roads. I wonder whether he has recanted. Has he spoken to the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) about it? Has he said, `Do not fund Federal roads,'?
—No, not at all.

—There is a demonstration of the goodwill of the Opposition: it has someone representing it on the front bench who does not believe in what he is doing. He demonstrated tonight that whilst he can wax lyrical about the transport policies of this Government, if his coalition were ever in government he would not provide any Federal funding for roads. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), who spoke prior to me--
—A good member.

—He says that he is a good member. I am not a resident of his electorate: it is very difficult for me to say. He said that the Minister was welcome in his electorate. The honourable member for Maranoa visited me in my electorate and I must say that I enjoyed his company. It was just after that that he had some slight trouble when he returned to his electorate. I do not know whether it was because of the influence he came under when he was in my electorate, but when he left he seemed to have a good smile across his face. The speech of the honourable member for Maranoa had very little to do with these Bills. He is prolific in what he says about the social welfare system of this country. We know how archaic his views are. They are almost neanderthal when it comes to social welfare. He does not care about the poor or the impoverished and I dare say he does not care about roads.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The remarks of the honourable member for the Northern Territory are surely irrelevant to transport Bills.
—I have listened to the debate carefully. It is obviously a robust debate. I ask the honourable member for the Northern Territory to direct his remarks to the Bill, and I know that he will.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I was going to refer to the importance of social infrastructure to our community and part of the social infrastructure is social welfare payments, as are roads. We need to look after the interests of people who live in remote communities. The honourable member for Maranoa would know that apart from road funding and providing employment it is also very important to make sure that people in remote communities have sustenance and the ability to live. What is the unemployment level in his electorate? I imagine it is 12, 15 or 20 per cent. I suggest that he take some notice of the poor in his community. If he wants those people to vote for him-I dare say he does not because he does not care about them-he should address their issues of concern.

SPEECH.PARA: I come back to the point at issue here. The Minister pointed out in his second reading speech that these Bills continue the implementation of the recommendations of the National Road Freight Industry Inquiry which was initiated by this Government in 1983 and chaired by Mr Tony May. The inquiry recognised the importance of introducing uniformity into the rules and regulations governing interstate road transport. The implementation of its recommendations aims to improve the efficiency of the road transport industry, taking into account the needs of drivers, and also aims to recover more from the industry to cover the costs of road wear.

The amendments have two parts. One relates to cost recovery and the other relates to the reform of regulations. Road transport is essential to the economic and social well-being of the Northern Territory, my electorate, in particular, and to Australia as a whole. Anyone who has been there-the honourable member for Maranoa has been there, and I am quite happy to have him back there to show him more of the beautiful place-and seen the distances and isolation faced by many of the rural centres, will be aware of this. The honourable member also understands that although he has a large electorate, mine is 1.3m square kilometres, somewhat larger than his and somewhat more isolated. Of course, if we used the Opposition's principles for representation and democratic elections there would be five Australian Labor Party members for my electorate. Unfortunately, that is not the position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I want the people of Australia to understand that the Northern Territory has no more people in it than my electorate of Maranoa does. It has 80,000 people on the rolls--
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.
—and I have 80,000. I get half the amount of road funding that the Northern Territory gets.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—That is all I am concerned about. It is a disgrace.
—The honourable member will resume his seat. I again direct the attention of the honourable member for the Northern Territory to the question of relevance.

—Kangaroos are a very important problem in the Northern Territory. I notice them as I drive on the roads in the Territory. As previous speakers have said, it is very important to have safe roads which are well made with wide verges. The honourable member for Maranoa should know that if one drives on bush roads with plenty of kangaroos, emus and other wildlife one tends to hit them. If Opposition members count sheep and beef cattle as voters, I want to count the roos.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member should withdraw that statement. There are more kangaroos in Maranoa than there are in the Northern Territory.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa does not have a point of order.

—There are 80,000 voters on the roll in Maranoa and 80,000 on the roll in the Northern Territory. There are about five times more kangaroos. The dingoes eat all the roos in the Territory. There are a lot more kangaroos in Maranoa than there are in the Northern Territory.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat.
—As long as you accept that fact.
—I am sure the honourable member will not trouble us again with points of order that are not relevant to the debate.
—I will. If he gets out of order I will get up.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I challenge the honourable member for Maranoa to do a body count on the roads. As we all know, roads are very important to the social and economic infrastructure of Australia generally but very important in my electorate of the Northern Territory. There is a very small manufacturing base there and this means that there is a strong local demand for many items that need to be imported from interstate. Consequently, road freight is of vital importance in providing basic goods and services for Territorians. The Northern Territory Department of Transport and Works report entitled Estimates of Freight Demand by Surface Transport 1986-87 provides a concise picture of the importance of the road system to the Northern Territory economy.

SPEECH.PARA: It estimated that in 1986-87 714,000 tonnes of freight, excluding petroleum products, moved into the Northern Territory. Fifty per cent of this incoming freight went to the railhead in Alice Springs and was then transported by road. Twenty-nine per cent of it came by road alone and 21 per cent by sea. The bulk of incoming freight, nearly 45 per cent, was foodstuffs and refrigerated goods; that is, basic commodities for daily life. Freight out of the Northern Territory is also dominated by the road-railhead in Alice Springs-67 per cent leaves by that route with 25 per cent being transported just by road. The intrinsic importance of the road system to the Northern Territory is clear when intra-Northern Territory transport is considered. These movements are significant, estimated to total 339,000 tonnes, which is almost half the total freight entering the Territory from interstate or overseas. Road freight accounts for 98 per cent of all intra-Territory freight.

The road system to the smaller inland centres in the Northern Territory is of paramount importance. Towns such as Katherine and Tennant Creek, except for the minority of services that are supplied by air, are almost totally dependent on road transport. Most Aboriginal communities, as the honourable member for Maranoa ought to know, are similarly dependent. As well as providing the necessities of daily life, the road system is essential for Northern Territory industrial development. Distance has always been acknowledged as causing a prohibitive cost in the development of the Northern Territory and a good road system is essential to alleviate the burden. The road system provides the basic infrastructure for some of the Northern Territory's major industries. Take the tourist industry, for example. Despite the Country-Liberal Party's claim that the Northern Territory's economic prosperity lies towards our northern neighbours, the reality is that the bulk of the Northern Territory's tourists come from interstate. Only 17 per cent come from overseas. Nearly half of the tourists visiting the Territory enter by road. Once in the Territory, 87 per cent use the road system.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I could go on at great length but I understand that time is very limited. The road system provides for more balanced development for the Northern Territory economy. It is important to remember the extent to which transport facilities provide some of the basic infrastructure for economic development, especially in this climate of antagonism to Government spending. It is a means by which the Government substantially underwrites the private sector, as the honourable member for Maranoa ought to know. Commonwealth road programs have provided vital energy for social and economic life in the Northern Territory. The Australian bicentennial road development program has been a major source of funds.

I will conclude my remarks very shortly, but I want to point out the importance of road funding to the Australian community. Roads and road transport-related activities employ 500,000 people, or about one in 13 in the Australian work force. Every $1m of road construction expenditure generates about 61 person years of employment. About 77 per cent of all domestic freight is moved by road. The competitiveness of Australian exports is dependent upon a good and reliable domestic transport system. Roads provide the main form of transport for domestic tourism-82 per cent of travel-and 43 per cent of travel for international tourists. Road-based public transport carries 64 per cent of all public transport passengers in Australia. By the year 2000 total travel will grow by 60 per cent and road freight will nearly double. The total cost of road accidents to the community is approximately $3 billion per year. Australia has built over 800,000 kilometres of road, valued at almost $100 billion.

For the sake of the honourable member for Maranoa and other members opposite, let me say that in real terms, in 1987-88 prices, making a comparison between what was spent in the Northern Territory in the last five Budgets of the Fraser Government and the first five Budgets of the Hawke Government, there has been an increase of 93 per cent, from $118.5m to $228.2m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) established a very good argument as to why roads are important to the social and economic future of Australia. He pointed out to us that they are very important, particularly in country areas. They are the lifeblood of country Australia. The thing he failed to point out to the people of Australia was that in the last five years this country has been governed by the Australian Labor Party and that during that time the Labor Party has not raised the level of road funding in a way that is commensurate with the needs of country Australia and of our economic and social future. We have seen a reduction in road funding of 25 per cent in real terms in the last few years.

SPEECH.PARA: Next week the people of Australia will see, so we are told, in the May mini-Budget to be brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), an additional reduction in road funding of another 10 per cent in real terms. This kind of reduction cannot be sustained by the people of this country. We see around the country bitumen surfaces on country roads being ripped up-roads that are bitumen surfaced and dirt surfaced that cannot be maintained as they should be. People are involved in needless accidents because this Government is not prepared to put its money where its mouth is and provide sufficient funding for our roads. I am reminded of the deficiencies of this Government in terms of road funding by an article by Mike Steketee that appeared in today's Sydney Morning Herald. The headline of the article reads, `Road funding cuts cost 75 deaths a year, says motorists' group'. It reads:

Cuts in road funding during the past three years have resulted in an average 75 additional fatalities and 2,500-3,000 more accidents throughout Australia each year, according to the Australian Automobile Association.
It says the figure will rise because of the latest drastic cut to be announced in next week's mini-Budget.
More people will be killed on our roads because of this Government's penny-pinching attitude towards the funding of one of the most important facilities in this country. The article continues:
Its secretary-general, Mr Bruce Lunn, said yesterday the figure for increased fatalities was based on the delays in improvements to road safety.

Road safety is a key issue throughout our community. The National Roads and Motorists Association will tell us that, if the quality of a road is improved to top standard, the number of accidents on that road will be reduced by 85 per cent. The people of Australia are interested in these sorts of figures. Road accidents cost the nation $5.7 billion last year. That is a cost that we can no longer afford. It is a particularly relevant issue in my electorate of Gilmore because the busiest highway in Australia, the Hume Highway, runs through it at Goulburn. A large number of interstate transports travel on it. I believe that a statistic some years ago indicated that a semi-trailer travelled down the main street of Goulburn every 70 seconds every day of every year. That highlights the need for good roads.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill will increase the maximum permissible weight an interstate transport may carry on our highways. It will also increase the maximum permissible speed at which one of these vehicles can travel on our roads. Whilst these things are of great benefit to road transport operators, they also highlight the fact that when the axle weight of semi-trailers and the speed at which these trucks can travel on our highways are increased, we also increase the rate at which our highways and roads deteriorate. That is why road funding is a key issue in this debate.

The electorate of Gilmore has for a long time looked forward to having better roads. In 1982 when the Australian bicentennial road development (ABRD) program was first announced, people were promised that the Goulburn bypass would commence in 1984 and be completed by 1988. There is no sign of it today. In fact, we will not see any sign of it until the 1990s. During this delay there have been unnecessary deaths on a road that should bypass Goulburn. On the Cullerin Range bypass between Goulburn and Gunning, one of the most dangerous sections of road in Australia, we see major accidents every week. Why? Because the Government is not providing sufficient funding for our roads. Why? Because the Australian bicentennial road development fund has had money taken from it that should have been spent on roads.

When Labor first came to power it said, `We will try to take the money out of the ABRD and spend it on other matters'. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) highlighted how the Government had wasted money that should be spent on roads and allocated it to other areas. Hundreds of millions of dollars paid by the motorist at the petrol bowser through the ABRD scheme has not been spent on roads, as it should have been. In the process needless accidents have occurred. According to the Automobile Association of Australia there are an extra 75 deaths a year and 2,500 to 3,000 needless accidents a year because the money that the motorist pays at the petrol bowser to this Government is not being spent on roads.

We are paying in excess of $5 billion at the petrol bowser each year towards improving our roads, but that money is not spent on roads. About 20 per cent of it goes towards improving the roads. This Government will be judged on that policy when it goes to the people at the next election. The people in country Australia are sick and tired of driving on roads that are not up to a satisfactory standard. They are sick and tired of having accidents that should not happen. They are sick and tired of hearing rhetoric from Government Ministers about the wonderful job they are doing to improve our roads.

In the next two years this Government has an opportunity to establish its credibility with the people who use our roads-the motorists and the country people of Australia. I doubt whether it has the will or the determination to do that. I doubt whether it is prepared to allocate a greater proportion of the fuel excise that is paid at the petrol bowser towards our roads. I assure the people of Australia and the Parliament that we on this side of the House, the Liberal and National parties, are determined to do a better job for roads. We are determined to allocate a greater proportion of the fuel excise towards roads. We are determined to give a greater priority to roads throughout Australia so that we can save lives, improve the quality of life in country areas, prevent needless accidents, and ensure that the future of this country-to use the words of the honourable member for the Northern Territory, the social and economic future of this country-is preserved by the building of bigger and better roads for the benefit of this nation.
