DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH EMPLOYEES' REHABILITATION AND COMPENSATION BILL 1988

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the lateness of the hour, the Opposition is particularly concerned that this important legislation, the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill, should be brought into the House at such a time, especially since the substantial number of Commonwealth public servants who are currently beneficiaries under the legislation, as well as all public servants across Australia, will naturally be concerned to know that the Government is proposing to make some fundamental changes to the whole basis of compensation rehabilitation in terms of the responsibilities it has as the employer for the welfare and well-being of employees who may have suffered as a result of their employment.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation the House is debating was best described by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in his second reading speech when he said that it was the intention of the Government to introduce a new scheme of compensation rehabilitation for persons who are injured in the course of their employment by the Commonwealth. He went on to suggest that the new proposals were aimed at establishing `a more equitable and cost-effective compensation system with particular emphasis on the rehabilitation of injured employees'. At the outset I should state that the Opposition is of the view that the whole area of Commonwealth compensation leaves much to be desired. The Opposition supports certain aspects of the legislation. On the other hand, the Opposition is gravely concerned about at least two aspects of the legislation. Those aspects are, firstly, the question of the removal of the right of common law access; and, secondly, the question of retrospectivity in relation to the payments that are made to people who are long term beneficiaries under the existing 1971 Act.

I will start initially with what the Opposition regards as the good features of the legislation. It proposes to place greater priority on rehabilitation rather than pensions. It is fair to say that it has been the experience over recent years, both in Australia and elsewhere, that undue emphasis on pensions as distinct from rehabilitation has had the result that many people who may well have been able to go back into the work force, although not necessarily at the same level or doing the same job that was previously their responsibility, have been unable to do so. That is clearly an objective of much greater significance than encouraging people to leave the work force. One of the fundamental weaknesses of the 1971 Act is that unless it is possible to replace the officer in exactly the same position he previously held, virtually automatically he is regarded as being a long term retiree and compensation beneficiary. Under the existing legislation, no attempt is made to see whether it is possible in the context of the entire Public Service to place that person in some other function.

Furthermore, the legislation suggests that departments and employers, that is, statutory authorities as well as departmental management, should be responsible for paying premiums based on performance. That is, of course, a concept that is well developed in the private sector in relation to workers compensation but it is a new concept in relation to the public sector and one which the Opposition totally supports. Once again, it brings home to those who are responsible for the maintenance of adequate conditions of employment, including adequate protection of employees at their place of employment, the responsibility of paying the bills when, as a result of their negligence, people may well have suffered. We are yet to see what the premium base will be but at least it is a step forward in bringing home to the management of the Public Service that the cost begins and ends with those who are responsible for maintaining adequate standards of protection at the work place.

The legislation also attempts to remove double dipping and general rorting of the system. Under the 1971 legislation, there were numerous examples of people being able to claim benefits which under normal circumstances one would have to say there was considerable doubt that they were entitled to. For example, if a person left work at 4.51 p.m., which is the appropriate time in Public Service jargon, on a Friday afternoon and went skiing and subsequently broke his leg or his back, even if he were only temporarily incapacitated rather than being permanently incapacitated, he would be able to claim benefits under the Act.

One of the important amendments in the proposals before the House is that the conditions relating to movement to and from work are to be the shortest available route and to the place of one's normal residence. Again, the Opposition applauds that because it is clearly a worthwhile and significant reform. There is a whole range of areas where the legislation is clearly being misused to the ultimate cost of the Commonwealth and certainly not to the ultimate advantage of the efficiency and effectiveness of public administration in this country.

The legislation also reduces the ability of employees to exploit the existing provisions for deemed total incapacity. I have referred to that in relation to the provisions of the 1971 Act, which in many respects give employees little, if any, opportunity of getting back into the workforce, often under circumstances where they wished to be re-employed but where their previous employer simply did not want them back. While individual cases must be examined on their merit, it should be the responsibility of the employer, wherever possible, to replace people in the work force, although not necessarily in the same department or at the same level. In an area as broad and wide as the Commonwealth Public Service, it is not asking too much that a serious attempt be made to find people opportunities for re-employment.

Finally, the other important point of the proposal is that it provides a reliable income for compensation beneficiaries. I will discuss that in relation to the bad features-namely, the question of the abolition of common law rights. One of the issues in the legislation that should be discussed is the fundamental question as to what are the benefits as distinct from the disadvantages of encouraging people to take lump sum settlements that are often dissipated. On the one hand, many people are not used to using such substantial sums of money or the lump sum settlements are simply not adequate to provide long term financial security. On the other side of that equation is the issue of whether it is preferable to pay such people adequate compensation benefits for the period of their natural lives, both in terms of the employment period they have lost as well as the ultimate period of retirement. It could equally be argued that one of the weaknesses of the proposal is that the ultimate cost saving, which is one of the key elements of the Government's argument in favour of the reforms, will come from the savings that will accrue from a reduction of access to superannuation benefits rather than a reduction of access to salaries or any other area of benefits.

The major bad feature of the legislation-and regrettably it is on these two points that the Opposition must vote against the Bill in the committee stage-is that it places an unrealistic reliance on rehabilitation. As I said, time alone will determine to what extent that criticism is valid. It is a new initiative in Australia; it is based upon what can now best be described as a failed system in Victoria, in particular, and similar legislation to Workcare is on the statute book in New South Wales. However, the Opposition is not optimistic that to place significant reliance on rehabilitation will necessarily result in a fundamental or significant change in the number of persons who will be beneficiaries under the workers compensation arrangements.

The two elements of the Bill which the Opposition opposes most strenuously are, firstly, the abolition of common law rights, in particular their retrospective abolition for current beneficiaries; and, secondly, the establishment of an additional Comcare bureaucracy which is yet to prove itself and, I think it is fair to say, the Government's failure to provide opportunities to the private sector to insure Commonwealth employees.

However, since the decision has been taken by the Government today not to proceed with any aspect of privatisation, I suppose it follows that Comcare will therefore also not be subject to privatisation. The point needs to be made that in due course the injection of greater competition into this area, which will enable the private sector to offer competitive rates of insurance for departments and statutory authorities, could well be a method by which we will be able to make significant savings in the future.

One must look at the history of this proposed legislation to get the flavour of what its intentions presumably are. In 1975, honourable members may recall, the Whitlam Government endeavoured to introduce an Australia-wide scheme based upon no-fault compensation. That scheme was based upon a New Zealand model. But it is worth noting that in April this year the New Zealand Government announced a review of the scheme because an enormous cost blowout has occurred. Nevertheless, as I said earlier, Labor governments in both New South Wales and Victoria introduced similar schemes based upon the New Zealand model, which remove the right to common law and replace it with no-fault compensation.

In April 1987 the Department of Social Security outlined proposed changes to the Commonwealth employee compensation system and the reform package, including the abolition of the employee's right to institute common law negligence actions against the Commonwealth, was included in that report-and that, of course, is the basis of this proposed legislation.

Over the past decade, compensation claims in the Commonwealth Public Service have increased by no less than 200 per cent. I am sure no member of this House would regard that with equanimity. In fact, it is a major cost factor which is now, in terms of long term commitment, nearly $3 billion. Over the same period, compensation payouts have increased by 485 per cent, from less than $40m in 1977-78 to more than $215m in 1986-87. It has been under the Hawke Government that the expenditure blowout has occurred. From 1976 to 1982, the compensation expenditure increased from $21m to just over $75m. However, since 1983, when the Government came into office, expenditure has risen sharply to $215m. This represents a $140m increase in a mere five years.

Over that time, workers compensation claims by Commonwealth employees have more than doubled and in some departments claiming compensation appears to be more the norm than the exception. In 1985-86, 67,548 Commonwealth employees made successful compensation claims, out of a total of 546,386 employees of departments and Government authorities. That represents one in eight of the entire work force of the Commonwealth, or some 12 per cent.

From the annual report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation for 1985-86, one is able to see the stark realities of the problem facing us today. Up to 60 per cent of employees of some departments and authorities successfully claimed compensation payments. There are instances in some departments and authorities of successful claims for compensation payments for the most extraordinary reasons. I shall give the House one example. A person failed to gain promotion and was able to go through the procedures of the appeal mechanisms under the existing Act and claim that, because he failed to get promotion, he had suffered mental anguish. And-would you believe it?-for that he received compensation.

In the production section of the Department of Defence, for example, 30 per cent, or 4,737 of the 15,600 employees, succeeded with claims. In that department, only 14 failed to get compensation. In the Department of Primary Industry in that period, 31 per cent, or just over 1,000 of the 3,516 employees, made claims, and only 11 failed. In the Department of Territories, 25 per cent, or 879 of the 3,500 employees, made claims, and only 11 lost. In the Department of Housing 24 per cent, or 2,262 of the 9,413 employees, made claims, and a mere 26 lost. In Australia Post, 22.3 per cent, or 8,834 employees of the 37,330, made successful claims, and only 33 failed. Even in the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, some 22 per cent, or 234 employees of the 1,124, made claims, and a mere three lost.

Need I emphasise more clearly than that the stark realities of the fundamental problems we are facing in the area of workers compensation in relation to the Commonwealth. The report went on to reveal that 428 more Commonwealth public servants retired from alleged invalidity in that year than the 2,599 who retired through reaching the retirement age of 60 years or more. Is it not extraordinary that even in the areas of defence production in the Department of Defence, more people claim workers compensation who are clerks and in non-military categories than actual soldiers, sailors and airmen serving the Commonwealth? In fact, under the old Act, invalidity retirement provides a higher rate of pension than early retirement. I do not think it is stretching the imagination too far to suggest that that has been a most powerful reason why people in their early and later fifties have chosen to take invalidity retirement rather than to work out their normal time-for the simple reason that they get paid more.

Under the Bill, Comcare is to be the new Commonwealth Commission to administer safety, rehabilitation and compensation for Commonwealth Government employees. Comcare will replace the Office of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation, as well as having additional functions. The objectives of Comcare are said to be: to reduce the incidence of work-related injury and disease by developing better occupational health and safety measures; to provide mechanisms for prompt and effective rehabilitation of incapacitated employees, thereby minimising their incapacity for work and reducing the degree of permanent disability; and to provide adequate financial assistance and treatment to incapacitated or injured employees and to decide claims and deliver payments promptly.

The Bill goes on also to suggest that employers will be responsible for providing not only the mechanisms but also the opportunities by which ex-employees or employees who are on leave due to compensation problems will have the opportunity to return to work. What the Bill does not explicitly state is whether Comcare will have the judicial capacity to require departments to employ persons under these circumstances.

I make that point for one very important reason: experience in New South Wales in terms of workers compensation has been, over the years, that the private sector, generally speaking, does not wish to take back employees who have been on extended leave due to workers compensation matters. I suppose in many cases they simply see these people as bad risks; and those employees having often been the beneficiaries of lump sum settlements in the common law process, private sector employers do not see that they have any further responsibility or legal requirement to take them back. Therefore, for that reason, it is important that we do not necessarily draw too close a comparison between conditions in the private sector and those in the public sector.

The point I am emphasising is this: I am not convinced that the Bill as currently drafted will ensure that the maximum opportunity is taken within departments and authorities to ensure by any reasonable yardstick that employees are given the opportunity for re-employment. If that is not the case, it follows that the whole basis of this proposed legislation, which is rehabilitation rather than compensation, may well fall to the ground. As I said earlier, it is nevertheless a worthwhile step forward, one which we support. We will have to see how it works over a number of years and, if necessary, make subsequent changes.

I refer to the comparison between entitlements under the new Comcare proposals and those under the present scheme. Under the new proposals, weekly benefits will represent 100 per cent of pre-injury earnings for a period of 45 weeks. Under the existing arrangements, those payments are limited to 26 weeks. So there has been a substantial growth. Some people may argue that 45 weeks is possibly too long. We have yet to see whether, for less than permanent injuries, it is necessary for people to take that length of leave. It is a cost area which must be watched very carefully.

Furthermore, under the Comcare arrangements, after 45 weeks ex-employees will be entitled to compensation of up to 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings. In many respects that is a substantial improvement on the existing arrangements where there is a statutory limit of $185.70 plus $48.60 for a dependent spouse and a further $23.10 for each dependent child. The significance of that is as follows: the new arrangement of 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings is based on a salary differential, whereas the old arrangement was a statutory amount regardless of what one's income was. It goes without saying that many people with higher incomes suffered grievously as a result of the substantial drop in income which followed under the previous arrangement.

Whilst I am sure that all honourable members would share the view that, wherever possible, we should try to compensate people who have suffered grievous mental or physical injury often as a result of errors, misjudgment and so forth, or just sheer mistakes in the hands of their employer, the sad fact is that physical injuries can never be totally recompensed. There is no point talking about 100 per cent compensation. If one has lost one's hand, leg, any limb or any part of any limb, or one's health, that is a major loss which cannot be compensated for absolutely merely in financial terms. Therefore, society needs to understand that important point. Whether one is talking about lump sum settlements, going through common law process, or whether one is taking a predetermined tabulation of the quantities in relation to injuries, this is a fundamental problem we must address.

I will now refer to some of the other changes. The awarding of up to 90 per cent of a pre-injury salary for low income earners is a significant change because, as the Australian Public Service is currently constructed, lower wage earners tend not to have superannuation. Although legislation has recently passed this House in relation to 3 per cent productivity arrangements which will to some extent solve that problem, as a general statement lower income earners, especially part time or temporary employees of the Commonwealth, do not have and never have had superannuation benefits. Therefore, to some extent, the legislation gives them a greater level of benefits than it gives people at the higher end of the spectrum where superannuation elements are taken into account. As I said at the beginning of this debate, one can equally argue that a loss for higher income people by simply removing their superannuation rights is not necessarily the best way to overcome the question of costs in this area.

The final point in terms of benefits is that payments of greater than 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings will be made if an employee returns to full or part time employment at less than pre-injury earnings. That is a simple and equitable arrangement. If an employee's earnings are greater than 75 per cent, the person should earn that money.

There are various other changes in the legislation of some importance-for example, lump sums of up to $80,000 for permanent impairment of at least 10 per cent of the whole person. There is a further significant improvement in terms of the older Act in that a sum of up to $30,000 will be paid for pain or suffering. Under the old legislation there was no provision for any payment for pain and suffering.

I refer to some of the other very important elements of the Act. I referred earlier to the problem of common law. As I said, I suspect that in this area we have a fundamental intellectual problem regarding the perception of the role of common law as seen by the Opposition parties and by the Government. As I said, the Bill removes an individual's right to sue the Commonwealth. However, he can still sue a third party-for example, the manufacturer of an object which may have caused the accident in the first place. The Government has argued-and I question some of its premises, but this is the basis of its case-that the common law negligence action as it currently exists has certain characteristics which do not encourage rehabilitation. It claims that it requires a once and for all assessment that may take up to five years to obtain through the courts, during which time social security benefits are paid.

The Minister for Social Security, who is at the table, would be well aware that recent amendments to the Social Security Act, which he put through only a few weeks ago, emphasised that up to 50 per cent of lump sum settlements may be recouped by the Commonwealth where benefits have been paid over the period during which the court action may have been in progress.

Furthermore, the Government claims that such assessments often result in a delayed return to work because the claimant must demonstrate maximum incapacity until the settlement. It claims that when an employee has determined, with legal advice, to go down the road of common law it is therefore to his advantage to emphasise his incapacity. Clearly, for psychological as well as physiological reasons, during that period it is not possible to apply the requirement for rehabilitation. There may be substance in that argument, but the evidence is not clear cut. Again, these things must be seen on an individual, case by case basis.

The Government also claims that compensation amounts from common law actions are not certain-that is definitely so-thereby creating an adverse environment for rehabilitation. Of course they are not certain. The judiciary has to make the judgment as to what extent the person making the claim has suffered grievous physical or mental injury. Clearly, therefore, the quantum which we pay, if it is paid, will vary from case to case. One thing which needs to be emphasised is that the weakness of the proposed law is that people will be able to go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). If any- body has looked through the records of the AAT, he would have the gravest reason for concern. One of the principles on which the AAT was established was that effectively it was not meant to be a judicial tribunal-although everybody knows that it is. Secondly, it is not held to precedents. Consequently, a determination from the AAT in New South Wales may have no relationship whatsoever to a similar judgment made by the AAT in some other State. Yet that is the basis of the appeal mechanism which is allowed for in this legislation.

At the same time we are not allowed to take recourse to common law. One of the fundamental principles of British justice has always been that if an employee believes that he has suffered as a result of the negligence of his employer, he has the right to sue at common law. One can argue-and I think the Opposition would be quite happy to listen to this argument and make a contribution to it-that because of the cost factors involved there may well be a case for putting a ceiling on the level of compensation which may be achieved through common law. One could even argue that only a person with more serious physical or mental damage could have access to common law. These are open questions which need to be examined. The new New South Wales Government is looking at the issue now. It is an extremely complex area. It is often very difficult to determine compensation for what one person sees as being a serious physiological problem, as distinct from how the person who has actually suffered the damage sees his or her situation. Nevertheless, to remove the right of access is a fundamental infringement of what we see as a basic question of natural justice.

The other point which the Government claims as the basis of its position is that the present system inadequately tackles the cost of rehabilitation by focusing on past injuries rather than on future re-entry into the work force. I think I have adequately covered that question. We support the concept of rehabilitation-I emphasise that-but we do not see it as being the sine qua non of all aspects of reform in this area. It is undoubtedly significant but at the same time we must be assured that the judicial rights of individual citizens are adequately protected throughout. It is for that reason that at the appropriate time in the committee stage I shall move the amendment seeking the removal of clause 44, which abolishes common law rights for Commonwealth public servants.

I turn to retrospectivity of payments. It goes without saying that people who are permanently incapacitated and who have made their determination on how they are going to live for the rest of their lives should not now find themselves in a situation where over the next seven years they will lose, on average, about $1,000 a year of real income just to get them back to the 75 per cent of final wage, which was the basis of this proposal. We regard that as fundamentally inequitable and unfair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the shadow Minister for Social Security, the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), I give unqualified support to the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill. I think it is a landmark Bill and I think the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and his team ought to be congratulated for the many hours of negotiation and thrashing out that this Bill represents. I shall deal just briefly with the shadow Minister's principal objection to this Bill. It is typical of the Opposition that it always brings up industry protection measures on legislation like this. Of course it has to do with preserving the pre-emptive rights of the legal profession. The only thing that surprised me in the shadow Minister's comments was that he did not opt for a bit of incentivation, like the Americans, whereby the lawyers could perhaps go for a percentage, with their fees being based on the quantum of the damages awarded-the greater the damages, the greater the amount the lawyers get. If one establishes a scheme such as Comcare, with its increased emphasis on rehabilitation and returning people to the work force as quickly as possible, it is absolutely contradictory then to say that they also have common law rights, with all the difficulties they involve.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether we are talking about public servants or employees in private industry, the increasing oncosts that compensation represents are recognised and governments are being forced to move because of the unsatisfactory outcomes that common law rights have delivered over the years. The honourable member mentioned Transcover and the Victorian system of Workcare. Transcover is in New South Wales. He suggested that Comcare will come up against some of the same problems. But I point out that Transcover seeks to service not a select group of departments and instrumentalities as Comcare does but a whole variety of businesses. Therefore management of individual cases, the relationship between employers and Transcover, would be much more difficult than will be the case with Comcare and its client departments.

When we insist on common law rights it involves people going through the court process and being made offers in various stages of negotiations, and they are not confident about which offer should be accepted and which should not. I think the honourable member has missed the point. If we were in a perfect world the best form of workers compensation would be no injuries. We opt to aim for that objective but given that there are bound to be cases where workers are injured, I think Comcare will cover major concerns and make major improvements.

I would just like to say that the costs to the Commonwealth, like the costs to private industry, have escalated quite dramatically. Over the last 10 years there has been a 200 per cent increase in costs in real terms, or a 485 per cent increase in nominal terms. What I like about Comcare is its emphasis on prevention, its emphasis on occupational health and safety. I hope that some subsequent speaker on the Opposition side will acknowledge the concerns that the trade union movement has expressed and increasingly taken up in recent days about occupational health and safety. However, it is not only an employee responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the applications for compensation in the Trade Union Training Authority.
—I am sorry, but I do not understand the point that the honourable member is making.
—The Authority has a lot of compensation cases.

—If the honourable member opposite wants to make cheap points, that is his prerogative. The point I am trying to make-maybe the honourable member's supporters disagree with me-is that occupational health and safety remain a concern of and responsibility for employees and employers. It requires a determination on the part of both unions and management, whether in private enterprise or public enterprise, to ensure that proper health and safety objectives are met, that performance is monitored and improvements made.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to rehabilitation. I think that one of the outstanding features of the Bill-something which, I think, the shadow Minister in part acknowledged-is that currently there are something like 300 cases being managed under rehabilitation in the Commonwealth Public Service. I ask honourable members to look at the dramatic increase that is proposed in Comcare-something like 7,500 people are expected to be offered some form of rehabilitation assistance. This really is a dramatic change. I am sure that it is a change that workers in the Public Service will, and should, welcome. I know that as members of parliament who have some responsibility to those workers we on this side of the House welcome that changed approach.

As I said, I suppose the Bill has seven major features. One of those features is an emphasis on prevention. The second emphasis concerns facilitating the return to work of injured workers and providing practical assistance to Commonwealth employees who suffer injury through their work. This scheme will improve medical, social and financial employment service available to individual workers. I will run through some of the benefits which have changed dramatically. For example, in the area of rehabilitation, when a worker is off work for more than 28 days the agency or department employing such a person will be required to have a case management plan for that individual in order to sensitively and compassionately bring that person back, as far as possible, into the work force. Of course, this represents a streamlining of a lot of the legislation. There are certainly a lot of equity considerations in this package which I find outstanding.

As I said, I will talk a little about the benefits side. I think that the objective is to minimise the number of people who may be injured at work. However, where that inevitably happens and someone suffers a work related illness, injury or death, compensation benefits have been significantly improved. Lump sum death benefits will be increased from $57,780 to $120,000. Weekly benefits for children will be increased from $23.10 to $40.00. The period of 100 per cent of pre-injury earnings will be increased from the present 26 weeks to 45 weeks. Under the present situation, if a worker is unable to return to work after 26 weeks, his weekly compensation payment is drastically reduced to a low, statutory flat rate. Under Comcare, after 45 weeks, compensation will continue to be paid at 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings.

Those pre-injury earnings, incidentally, are not calculated on the worker's base income, but will take into account things such as overtime and allowances and the fluctuations in a year of the way in which a person might earn that income. In other words, profiles will be built up. For example, if a person happens to be injured while he is not working overtime or receiving an allowance which he would receive at another time, that will be taken into account. For so many lower paid workers in the Public Service who are dependent on overtime or allowances, this is an important step forward.

Lump sum payments for permanent injuries will also be increased. Up to $80,000-presently it is $57,870-is provided for in this legislation. Additional amounts of up to $30,000 will be paid for pain and suffering. This payment for pain and suffering will be on a no fault basis. The existing system allows for a pain and suffering component if the fault or negligence could be proved in common law. These lump sum payments for both permanent impairment and pain and suffering will be made in addition to the compensation payments outlined earlier. This is a significant departure from the present system whereby lump sum payments instead of weekly payments are paid to totally incapacitated workers.

Low income earners in receipt of compensation payments will be protected. A floor will be placed under earnings-related payments to low income earners. Where payments would have otherwise fallen below the floor-which, incidentally increases with the number of dependants-payments of up to 90 per cent of prior earnings will be payable. Household and attendant care services will be provided for under this legislation. One hundred per cent of attendant care of up to $200 per week can be paid. To maximise the benefit of the attendant care allowance and to avoid double taxation, the allowance will be paid directly to the provider. Under the present system the attendant care allowance is only $32.30 and it is paid to the worker, who must then pay the attendant. Fifty per cent of household care costs up to a maximum of $200 can also be claimed under Comcare. Medical costs will be paid by Comcare instead of by the agencies. This will ensure faster payment.

Injured workers will receive rehabilitation or retraining that was not previously available, a significantly enhanced work environment, improved lump sum payments for permanent impairment and pain and suffering, and a far better level of remuneration for a far longer period while actually off work through work-related injury or illness. I briefly take up a couple of points that the honourable member made and with which I agree. I think that both sides of the House welcome this Bill. I certainly do. We will have to see how it operates and make adjustments. That is the case with every piece of legislation that is introduced. I am sure that it will be the case in this regard. In conclusion, I fully support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an issue of enormous significance to the Public Service of this nation and to the nation itself, yet the Government is gagging legislation. It is intent on allowing just over one hour to debate it, at midnight on Thursday night, the last night of this week's sitting. The Government is clearly applying the jackboots in an attempt to limit debate on the fundamental flaws in this legislation. As we have already said, we support the thrust of the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill to the extent that it provides for appropriate levels of payment to employees who have suffered a work-related injury or disease and provides incentives to return to the work place following rehabilitation. But to the extent that the Bill seeks to remove an award already granted to an injured employee or to restrict a person's longstanding right of access to the courts under common law, we cannot support it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also seeks to stem the escalating costs of the Commonwealth employees compensation system. As has already been indicated in this debate by speakers on both sides of the House, there has been a rapid escalation in payouts. Since 1982-83, total annual payments made under the Commonwealth Government employees compensation scheme have doubled even though the number of employees covered under the scheme has decreased. In 1986-87, the Department of Social Security, which administers the program, paid out over $215m for 80,000 recipients who qualified for compensation payments for work-related injury or disease. Over the last few years, the rapid increase in the total Commonwealth payout for compensation cases indicates clearly that changes are needed. The compensation scheme must be fair and equitable without providing an incentive for employees to rort the system. The rapid escalation in costs is due in part to mismanagement and abuse within the system. There has been a lack of incentives for rehabilitation and there have been anomalies in the manner in which the current system has been structured.

In his 1986-87 annual report, the Commissioner for Employees Compensation states that the biggest single reason for a significant reduction in the rate of growth in expenditure for claims during that year was the fact that the Commission had brought a large proportion of claims processed under the direct control of the Commission itself through its branch offices. The Commissioner's comments regarding the importance of effective claims management for cost control within the system are given more weight by the fact that agencies still processing their own claims typically have a much higher claim rate than areas whose claims are processed by the Commission. Given that fact, I strongly recommend that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) give serious consideration to claims processing capabilities before exercising the authority given to him under clause 99 of the Bill which allows him to declare a Commonwealth authority to be an administering authority for purposes of this legislation.

I understand that Australia Post is one of the first in line to be considered for this administrative role. I remind the Minister that during 1986-87 Australia Post had one of the highest claim approval rates in the country and a claims disallowance rate well below the national average. So before rushing off and allowing these authorities to undertake their own claims processing, I draw the Minister's attention to the Commissioner's comments. If his comments are right, more needs to be done within those authorities to prove their capability to handle the claims.

As I have said, cost blow-outs in payments have also occurred because the compensation system has been used on occasions by departments to retire employees who have been determined to be in excess of the personnel needs of the department or by employees seeking to retire with more than just their normal retirement benefits. I have raised this problem before. The 1986-87 annual report of the Commissioner for Superannuation indicates that the largest single group of pensioners under the Commonwealth superannuation scheme are those who have taken invalidity retirement-36.6 per cent on invalidity retirement versus 31.1 per cent on age retirement.

The Commissioner for Employees Compensation has indicated that more than 26 per cent of permanent compensation cases are invalidity retirees who are receiving both compensation and superannuation payments and are receiving more in total Commonwealth compensation than they were while in the Commonwealth's employment. Unfortunately, a large percentage of these double dippers have been invalided out with diagnoses which at times prove difficult to substantiate one way or the other-diagnoses such as back injuries, sprains and psychiatric conditions. Undoubtedly many of those were genuine, but some we must be suspicious about. Fortunately, this Bill eliminates incentives which the anomalies of the current system provide for employees to seek this double compensation. Those anomalies were never intended. Equally, the incentives for employers to offer invalidity retirement to excess staff as a solution to the problem of excess staff has also been eliminated.

The system of compensation for Commonwealth employees should be such that there always exists a greater incentive to work than to take compensation payments in lieu of work. Over the years there have been widespread reports of abuse of the compensation scheme by employees who would rather take a prolonged sickie than work. It is not difficult to imagine from where these reports come. For example, the report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation for 1986-87 lists among the Commonwealth departments and authorities, the Albury-Wodonga Development Corporation. During the year on which the Commissioner reported, that statutory authority had 129 employees, and 56 workers compensation cases. I was a bit surprised to read those figures, so I endeavoured to find out what was happening in the Corporation, so I rang it up. Given the high figure of compensation cases, I was not surprised that no-one was there to answer the telephone.

The Bill contains provisions which, apart from eliminating simultaneous payments from both compensation and superannuation, also limits the amount of compensation payable under the scheme. The Opposition agrees with the basic thrust of the legislation, which is to pay ongoing compensation at more appropriate levels for work-related injuries or diseases. Such levels of compensation, as previous speakers on both sides of the House have said, must be kept under review. The scheme is new and we must ensure that it is equitably applied in practice.

Part III of the Bill places emphasis on rehabilitation of the injured employee and outlines the responsibilities of both the employee and the employer. One of the responsibilities of the employer is spelt out in clause 40, which requires the Commonwealth or the authority to take all reasonable steps to provide the employee who is undertaking or has completed a rehabilitation program with suitable employment or to assist the employee to find such employment. The language of this provision does not convey the urgency of finding employment for the rehabilitated employee that is conveyed to departments by the regulations which require departments to find new employment for staff who are redundant or excess to capacity.

This raises a real problem because already in the Public Service today are a large number of redeployees. There are thousands of redeployees who have become excess to capacity because of the amalgamation of departments, the great restructuring undertaken by this Government which was going to reduce the size of the Public Service. Even with the strict procedures set down by agreement between the Government, the unions and associations of employees, the redeployment procedures are more honoured in the breach than the observance. I refer to the problem of unattached and redeployed employees in the Public Service because I am aware that a stigma attaches to the rehabilitated employee, just as a stigma apparently attaches to the redeployed employee in the Public Service. Without a better program to re-employ these people, I fear that despite the best intentions of the legislation it will be a dismal failure. On the basis of the Government's record to date, we will just have more unattached paid public servants without gainful employment.

I want to concentrate the attention of the Minister on this problem. I have raised this problem before in the House. I have quoted the figures that have been promoted by the Public Service indicating that approximately 4,500 redeployees in the Australian Capital Territory and approximately 15,000 nationally on the Public Service payroll are looking for gainful employment. Those people are now going to be joined by the rehabilitation cases. I repeat that, unless the Government gets its act together, people may well be rehabilitated through this legislation but there is a very good chance that they will join the growing queue of Public Service employees who are sitting around in departments not gainfully employed.

The Minister responsible for the Public Service has admitted that there is a problem. It is high time the Government did something about it. Certainly I have highlighted it in this House on a number of occasions. So far we have seen no action at all. One of the responsibilities of the employee is spelt out, as I have said, in the legislation. Clause 40 requires the Commonwealth or the authority to:
. . . take all reasonable steps to provide the employee with suitable employment.

Already we have thousands of redeployees who are looking for gainful employment. I repeat that I have grave reservations as to whether the Government will be able to find jobs for the people rehabilitated under this scheme. If the Government is not prepared to concentrate on fulfilling that goal, the whole thrust of the legislation falls to the ground.

There are two other points I want to make. Firstly, clause 44 of the Bill attempts to eliminate the rights of access of employees to common law. Access to common law is a longstanding right that should not be abrogated for the sake of alleged expediency, economy and making life easier for the Commonwealth and its authorities, or on the grounds that the Commonwealth knows best in every case for the employee. We reject that submission by the Government. The right to pursue a remedy at common law where an employee suffers an injury as a result of the negligence of the employer is longstanding and should be retained, especially in the face of arguments as unconvincing as those that have been offered to date by this Government.

Division 3 of part X of this Bill introduces transitional rules which make certain provisions of this Bill applicable to former employees who have already been awarded compensation under the existing Act. This is the second point I want to make, on what I believe is another of the fundamental flaws in the legislation. We oppose the retrospectivity of these provisions which reduces the awards that are already made. An award once made in accordance with existing laws and regulation should not be diminished on the grounds of cost savings. We are therefore proposing an amendment to the Bill which would allow former employees on permanent compensation awards to remain covered under the pre-existing Act.

The transitional provisions of the Bill will apply to probably fewer than 3,000 recipients of permanent compensation. These recipients have been awarded compensation under existing rules. They have certain reasonable expectations regarding the continuity of these benefits and have made their life plans accordingly. Subsequently to change the rules for these beneficiaries in midstream is simply not fair. These recipients should be allowed to play out their innings and the new rules against payment of two benefits simultaneously should be applied to future cases.

TALK.START.PARA: —You say that in opposition.

—As I have said, the Opposition agrees with the thrust of the Bill, provided the fundamental flaws are remedied, as proposed in our amendments. I conclude with a response to the Minister's interjection. He suggests that there are two rules, one for when one is in opposition and another one for when one is in government. I believe that the two fundamental flaws in this Bill which I have alluded to-the common law and the retrospective action of this legislation-are principles which, regardless of which side of the House one is on, I would have thought this Minister, who talks so much about social justice and equity, would--
—I concede that on common law, but on the second issue there is a question of equity, is there not?
—Well, we have got at least one concession tonight. The Minister has conceded in respect of common law but he is prepared to take existing--
—Seeing that you are talking from principle; on that I agree with you.

—I am glad for at least that concession. There seems to be a sudden dawning at this late hour-the Minister has seen the light. Beneficiaries who have been subject to awards have made their arrangements as a result of those awards being handed down. The Minister now wants to turn around and change their entitlements which were made by tribunals. I think that is an extraordinary application of the law. There is no doubt that the legislation has retrospective action. Those people have already made their plans. I am firmly against retrospective legislation and I have voted against it previously in this House. I have even crossed the floor and voted against my own Party in relation to that principle. The Minister says that one maintains these principles only when one is in opposition, but one will not adopt them when in government. I suggest that the Minister look at my voting record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to speak at this very late hour on the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill 1988. I have had quite a bit to do with this Bill in discussions with the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and other people in the community, and I would like to thank him for involving me in those discussions at a very early stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Commonwealth employees compensation is something which should be important to every member of this House and the other House. A lot of people working for the Government certainly need proper protection and proper compensation. This important piece of legislation covers many Commonwealth employees. It is designed to improve long term benefits for these employees, particularly those who are unfortunate enough to have sustained an injury or incapacity during their work. It is also designed to provide an expanded range of services and better payments.

The point was made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) about the cost of the previous scheme that undoubtedly was expanding at a rate that could not be sustained by the Government. But, really, this Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Bill is not just a cost cutting measure, and it should not be seen in that light. It is going to provide Commonwealth employees with a much better set of circumstances should they be unfortunate enough to sustain an injury.

At present people have access to common law. Both the Minister and I have had discussions with a number of the people in the unions concerned who represent employees in this place and elsewhere and they obviously are worried about the loss of common law access. But that is not to say that they do not agree with the general thrust of this legislation. Some of them obviously have problems but others realise that what the Minister is proposing in this Bill is fair for their own members and fair for those people who work for us.

We definitely have a responsibility to ensure that waiting times are overcome, that people have speedy resolution to their problems and that, best of all, they have speedy resolution through rehabilitation to the injuries that they have sustained. That is one of the most important aspects of this Bill, because many of the injuries that are sustained by Commonwealth employees may in fact be worsened because they have not had a proper rehabilitation program.

Injuries such as repetitive strain injury (RSI), which I am sure every member of this House is familiar with in some form or another, have been laughed at for years and not taken seriously by employers across the nation, including Commonwealth employers. I suggest to the House that the danger of repetitive strain injury can in fact be minimised by the proper use of ergonomic furniture and proper employment practices. Part of the role of Comcare will be to advise employers in the workplace how they should be treating their staff and how their staff ought to be working. Obviously, if one has an RSI injury and runs around to 15 doctors-which obviously has happened in some cases-there will be a situation where one will not get appropriate treatment quickly. There is also a fear on the part of the employees that they will not be taken seriously by their employer and so they do not always report their injury for quite some time.

However, I suggest to the House that the type of legislation that is being debated tonight will overcome a lot of those problems, because Comcare itself as a professional institution will be able to assist our agencies, whether it be Australia Post, Telecom Australia or departments of the Commonwealth, to assist their employees out of their injury. That is the main basis for this legislation. It provides for extra payments for people. They get 100 per cent of their earnings for a much longer time-now 45 weeks-and after that period of time they will receive 75 per cent of their earnings. I think that most of the employees concerned will be relieved at that prospect. Also, they will receive additional assistance when they start returning to the work force-and this is an incentive for them to go back to work.

As I have said, the provisions of the Bill have been extensively discussed with many representative groups, and they do appear to agree with the general thrust of the legislation. It is hoped that this Bill will be followed by another Bill in due course that will deal specifically with the occupational health and safety of Commonwealth employees. I know that the Minister would like to have had that Bill introduced at the same time. It relates to this legislation and it is definitely necessary.

While redress under common law may no longer be an option, the improved benefits should make up for this loss in most circumstances. Furthermore, there will be fewer delays in payouts for people who are not able to be rehabilitated. Because rehabilitation will be the responsibility of the employing agency, early attention to workplace injuries is expected. Some unions have expressed concern about this aspect of the Bill, that is, the employing agency taking control of the rehabilitation process. That is because they do not have a great deal of confidence in the employing body to administer the rehabilitation program. However, I believe that their concerns can be overcome with careful education of employers regarding the objectives of the scheme. Comcare's supervisory and monitoring role is a valuable buffer in these situations. I am sure that where there is this lack of confidence on the part of some of the employees that will be overcome because of the advantages of the employer administering the scheme and also because of the advantages to the employer of making the scheme work in the financial sense.

The current scheme holds no incentives for the employing body to assess incapacity speedily, as I mentioned earlier. Neither does the current scheme provide incentives for workers to return to work early. On the contrary, there was previously an incentive to remain off work while awaiting consideration of a court case. That is not to say that workers were malingering. I do not intend that at all, but certainly where a court case was pending an injured worker would have been advised by his legal representative to ensure that he got the best payout possible. That payout was only going to be forthcoming if the person was still sustaining an injury. So, I believe that the current system certainly has made people's injuries much worse than they might otherwise have been.

The objectives of the scheme are to reduce the incidence of work related injury and disease, to provide prompt and effective rehabilitation, and to provide adequate financial assistance and treatment for incapacitated or injured employees. There is a very important minimum floor to protect workers on low incomes and an acknowledgment of the costs associated with family responsibilities in these circumstances.

The case management approach to rehabilitation, which we have discussed before, ensures early intervention. It involves line management and the planning of rehabilitation and return to work of injured employees. It allows progress to be monitored in each case, it reduces the cost of rehabilitation by encouraging in-house treatment and training services wherever possible and provides that the employee is actively involved in the rehabilitation process. I emphasise at this point that the employees will always be involved in discussions of the rehabilitation process and what is expected of them. It is of concern to some people that the Commonwealth Medical Officer's role under the previous system, probably more with superannuation than compensation cases, has been questionable. But I am sure that this will not be a problem because people will be able to have access to their own medical advisers as well as, obviously, to the one who is appointed by the employer.

The transitional management arrangements are fair, even though there is obviously a change in the structure of the income expected by people who have already left the Service. The fact that this is an earnings based system is also very important because people have lifestyles to sustain. People who have earned a certain amount of money have based their living on what they earn, and it is very important to attempt, as we are in this legislation, to cover the costs of those people's lifestyles and allow them to maintain them.

The value of injured workers is acknowledged by the focus of rehabilitation because an employee should not be made to feel useless as is so often the case at present. Employees and employers will both benefit from improved safety and rehabilitation. This will mean less injury, shorter periods of incapacity and thus lower compensation costs. Comcare will provide improved compensation benefits for half a million Commonwealth employees and will significantly streamline financial administration of the scheme. As I indicated before, 100 per cent of pre-injury earnings will be paid for 45 weeks, compared with the current scheme which pays only 100 per cent of pre-injury earnings for 26 weeks. After 45 weeks, 75 per cent of pre-injury earnings will be paid, whereas currently benefits are fixed at a low $185 per week and there is no reference to current earnings.

Increased benefits for attendant care and household services is another important aspect of this Bill which must not be overlooked, because so many people who suffer what might appear to be a minor injury are prevented from carrying out their own household duties and require assistance. I am very proud to be here to assist the Minister on this occasion and to commend the Bill to the House.

I am somewhat puzzled, Madam Speaker, that the Opposition, having been so constructive and having recognised that the Government has made a serious attempt to deal with the faults of the old scheme and the administrative problems that existed, has been critical of the legislation in two principal areas that really go to fundamental questions. First, the basic philosophy of the scheme is questioned. The Opposition cannot really have it two ways. If the proposal is from day one to try to have the worker returned to the work force and to his proper income and if there is a no fault compensation system and the object is rehabilitation, the last thing to encourage is an attitude of mind by the employee that the worse he feels and looks the more likely he is to somehow get more adequate compensation.

We have removed the common law provision not because it will save us money-although it will in fact make the scheme less costly-but because we see it as antithetical to the fundamental orientation in this scheme towards getting the worker back into the work force at the earliest opportunity so that he can feel independent and support his family. There is another point involved, but I do not have time to develop it fully. However, I find it absolutely extraordinary that both Opposition spokespeople have, on the one hand, acknowledged that the Government wanted to deal with double dipping and rorts, but on the other hand they have insisted in their amendments that we preserve the possibility of people continuing to receive not only compensation payments at an adequate level but additional payments as well.

I point out to the honourable member for Bradfield that there has never been any permanent commitment to pay people compensation forever. To suggest that is absolute nonsense. How the spokesman for the Opposition can talk about retrospectivity, as though somehow we have taken away from people something that is their inalienable, permanent right, amazes me. Indeed, the whole purpose of this compensation reform is to provide a right to compensation where it is needed and to provide income support at an earnings related and more adequate level while it is needed and no longer than it is needed. We want to provide the right transitional arrangements for people to get back into the work force.

I conclude by saying that it is extraordinary that, on the one hand, the Opposition should support the Government for attempting to deal with double dipping, yet, on the other hand, suggest that we should not have the transitional arrangements that we propose but rather should write into the legislation the continuation effectively of double dipping. I fail to understand that, given that the Opposition, particularly through the honourable member for Bradfield, grasped very sympathetically the fundamental philosophy of the scheme

The second matter, which we covered in the amendments to the first Bill, is the question of the right of beneficiaries who are already retired to have their rights protected. Some 9,000 people are permanently incapacitated under the 1971 Act. Of those, some 2,000 are already over the age of 65. Quite clearly, therefore, they have to all intents and purposes retired. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport and Infrastructure Support, upon notice, on 5 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps has he taken or will he take to ensure that the present Australian Public Service directives regarding smoking in the work place are fully observed at all times in all areas of his Department, including the Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance Centre in Canberra.
(2) What steps will be taken after 1 March 1988 to ensure that the proposed Public Service directives regarding smoking in the work place are enforced.
(3) Does he propose to take any disciplinary action for those public servants who do not comply with the directives; if so, what action is proposed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, directed to the former Minister, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) To ensure that the Australian Public Service directives on smoking in the work place are fully observed within the Department of Transport and Communications, a policy on smoking in the work place, incorporating guidelines issued by the former Public Service Board, has been endorsed by the Department's Executive. The policy provides for assistance to smokers through in-house quit smoking courses or financial contribution towards attendance at other courses.

(3) At present it is not envisaged that disciplinary action will be necessary. The preferred approach is to achieve a smoke-free working environment through consultation and co-operation between management, unions and staff and to encourage a spirit of support in the implementation of the Department's policy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 23 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How much granite was contracted to be purchased for the new Parliament House.
(2) Who were the successful contractors and what were the sources of their material.
(3) What specifications for granite were laid down in the tender specifications.
(4) What was the original contract price.
(5) How much granite has been delivered under each contract.
(6) What payments have been made for granite which has been delivered.
(7) What quantity of granite which has been delivered has been rejected.
(8) Have payments been made for the granite which has been rejected.
(9) Has any rejected granite been left with the Commonwealth or any Commonwealth authority.
(10) Has any rejected granite which has been retained been used by the Commonwealth or any Commonwealth authority; if so, by whom and what price was paid for the rejected granite.
(11) Has any rejected granite been sold by the Commonwealth or any Commonwealth authority; if so, to whom and at what price.
(12) If any rejected granite has been neither sold nor used, what will be done with it.
(13) Is any rejected granite still being held by the Commonwealth or any Commonwealth authority; if so, where is it stored.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 April 1988 I provided an answer on the advice of the Parliament House Construction Authority (Hansard, 28 April 1988, p. 2367). The answer to the second paragraph of part (11) was incorrect. The paragraph should state:

ANSWER.PARA: Public tenders were called on 31 October 1987 for the disposal of approximately 600m3 of the residual granite holdings of the Parliament House Construction Authority. Following evaluation of tenders, the highest tender for $25,000, that of UNEENA Pty Ltd, was accepted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 17 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps are being taken by the Government to improve the sentencing process, in view of the disparity and lack of uniformity in the sentencing of offenders.
(2) Has the Government had any discussions with the State and Northern Territory Governments concerning the improvement of the sentencing process.
(3) Has the Government considered the introduction of a permanent body to assume responsibility for the ongoing monitoring of sentencing decisions and the provision of information and services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is only responsible for the criminal law of the Commonwealth, the Australian Capital Territory and the External Territories. In relation to offences against the laws of a State or the Northern Territory, the review of the sentencing processes is a matter for the respective Governments. The Government is presently undertaking a comprehensive review of Commonwealth legislation relating to the sentencing of persons convicted of offences against Commonwealth law. In addition it is expected that the final report of the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) relating to its Reference on Sentencing will be tabled in the near future. Under its terms of reference, the Commission is required to have particular regard to the need for greater uniformity in sentencing.

(2) Yes. For example, the Government has entered into arrangements with all States and Territories other than Queensland, NSW and Tasmania to ensure that the widest possible range of sentencing options are available to federal offenders. In addition the Meeting of Correctional Services Ministers on 15 May 1987, endorsed a National Strategy on Prison Crowding. This strategy is published in ALRC Discussion Paper No 30 ``Sentencing: Penalties''. (Appendix `A')

(3) Yes. I refer the member's attention again to the terms of reference given the ALRC. The Commission is to have particular regard to the need for greater uniformity in sentencing and the desirability of establishing a sentencing council, institution or commission for this purpose. When the ALRC made its interim Report (ALRC 15) it recommended the establishment of a sentencing council. The Commonwealth has on a number of occasions sought the agreement of the States and the Northern Territory to establishing a sentencing council. The Government is now awaiting receipt of the ALRC final report on this reference.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 23 March 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Health and Medical Research Council completed its investigations, at the direction of the former Minister for Consumer Affairs, into whether the chemicals contained in plastic wrapping used in supermarkets are cancer-causing; if so, what were the results of those studies.
(2) Have major retailers followed the former Minister's advice which suggested that the PVC film wrapping in question should not be used for wrapping cheese and meats.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Health and Medical Research Council convened an ad hoc working group to investigate the matter. The working group has reported to the Public Health Committee and the report is expected to be released by the Council when it meets in June 1988.

(2) Major retailers have advised that their use of plastic films has been reviewed. They had contacted the plastics manufacturers to ensure that correct films are being purchased for appropriate purposes. Retailers are confident that the plastic films are now being used correctly and that all films used comply with the Australian Standard for Plastics Materials for Food Contact Use. The Plastics Institute of Australia Limited is also developing an education program to ensure that commercial users of plastic films for food contact are aware of correct usage.
